summary: Paul Merson reignited his spat with Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend after the 22-year-old was introduced with seven minutes left in Spurs’ goalless draw at Burnley, tweeting “#RubberDub #7minutes.” Earlier, Merson had questioned Townsend’s England selection in his Sky Sports column—only for Townsend to silence critics by scoring a late equaliser in England’s 1-1 friendly with Italy, prompting Merson to admit his error and congratulate him. Townsend then taunted Merson on Twitter (“Not bad for a player that should be ‘nowhere near the squad’”), but the pundit couldn’t resist another dig when Townsend’s club appearances remained limited.

Chelsea have submitted a formal summer offer—reportedly around £4 million—for 22-year-old FC Tokyo and Japan international forward Yoshinori Muto, who has scored 16 goals in 37 club appearances, earned 11 caps (1 goal) for his country, graduated with an economics degree from Keio University two weeks ago, and was named in the J-League’s best XI after netting 13 times in his debut season; if the transfer proceeds, he would become Chelsea’s first Japanese player and immediately join Dutch affiliate Vitesse Arnhem on loan, and club president Naoki Ogane stresses this bid is unrelated to Chelsea’s new five-year, £200 million shirt-sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds published in Pediatrics found that infants who received antibiotics in their first six months—or repeatedly before age two—were more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, with boys especially prone to weight gain (and slightly taller) than those unexposed. The researchers suggest antibiotics may alter gut bacteria, increasing nutrient absorption and appetite, and warn that such effects could be contributing to the childhood obesity epidemic, underscoring the need for judicious antibiotic use in infancy. Previous studies also link early antibiotic exposure to eczema and digestive issues, and growing concerns about over-prescription include the rise of drug-resistant “superbugs.”

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, lost his footing, slid sideways, knocked his bearskin against his sentry box, dropped his rifle and fell as hundreds of tourists watched and gasped; the guard quickly scrambled to his feet, blushed at the attention, and is believed to have slipped because of metal protectors on his boots. The incident was filmed by holidaymaker David Meadwell, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment beyond noting the guard had simply fallen while doing his job.

A&E, Lifetime and History are joining forces to simulcast a contemporary remake of the 1977 epic miniseries Roots—originally watched by over 100 million viewers—recounting the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and enslaved on a Virginia plantation. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, co-executes the new adaptation, which will draw more directly from Alex Haley’s Roots: The Saga of an American Family and involve scholars of African and African-American history for authenticity. Executive producers, including Mark Wolper, son of the original’s producer, emphasize passing the story’s mantle to a new generation that has witnessed both historic strides, such as Barack Obama’s presidency and 12 Years a Slave’s Best Picture win, and ongoing racial tensions.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 he was pinned to a chair, groped and pressured into an attempted orgy by palace aides, prompting him to quit immediately; his complaint was initially ignored, and only last year—after renewed inquiries into historical VIP paedophile cover-ups—did the Palace forward his allegations to Scotland Yard, which is now investigating, while the Royal Household says it will cooperate fully.

Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced they’re expecting their first child in a rap video set to the ‘90s sitcom The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme, which has garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views; in the clip—filmed in five takes—they drive around rapping about buying a house in Happy Valley, Oregon, trying to conceive for two months, discovering a positive pregnancy test, and at the end share a sonogram of their unborn baby. They told KPTV they made the parody so far-away loved ones could learn the news and were surprised by its viral success, and after a gender reveal they may shoot another video. Jesse, a great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, previously featured in a separate clip capturing his reaction to Melissa’s announcement tag on their dog, and similar Fresh Prince parody announcements have appeared elsewhere.

A gray jacket-and-skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in key scenes of the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, part of more than 150 items from the movie drawn from James Tumblin’s private collection; originally slate blue-gray, the costume has faded with age, and Tumblin acquired it in the 1960s for $20 after rescuing it from disposal. Other top lots included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit ($55,000) and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The auction celebrated memorabilia from the Oscar-winning adaptation of Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel—recently marking its 75th anniversary—starring Leigh, Gable and Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy slipped from his mother’s arms and fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit pit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday afternoon, suffering minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury before his parents pulled him to safety; firefighters and paramedics later treated him and he was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness reports, said the child had been dangled over the railing, but the cheetahs neither approached nor harmed him. The exhibit was closed after the incident, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A decommissioned yellow Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham—which hasn’t functioned since all 300 fixed cameras in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 due to outdated technology—has been mysteriously turned to face a nearby house. Birmingham City Council, already developing a pilot program using digital cameras at select sites, confirmed it is aware of the misaligned device, will send an engineer to investigate, and may remove it entirely; the house’s owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced, with the six-time Olympic champion declaring himself “fit, healthy and ready to run” and eager to uphold Jamaica’s storied relay tradition and make his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle said he was “extremely pleased” Bolt was available for selection and predicted “sprint magic” on the track, while the full Jamaican team roster will be released shortly.

Neymar and team-mate Dani Alves, accompanied by Neymar’s sister Rafaella, attended Barcelona’s EuroLeague basketball El Clásico, where Barça narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85–80—though Real still top the group on points difference. Earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1–0 victory over Chile at the Emirates, enduring several tough challenges, and before the international break Luis Enrique’s Barcelona had beaten Real Madrid in the football El Clásico to move four points clear atop La Liga. The footballers now return to league action against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Italy is facing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting Mediterranean crossings, with the Italian coast guard rescuing 8,480 people between Friday and Monday and receiving 20 distress calls on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants missing after survivors said their vessel of 550 capsized 80 miles off Libya, but the coast guard, which has rescued 145, found no evidence of such an incident despite air and sea searches. The International Organization for Migration reports over 10,000 arrivals in Italy in the first quarter of 2015, including some 2,000 rescued off Sicily in early April; most migrants hail from West Africa, Somalia and Syria and transit through Libya. At least 480 have died so far this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded smugglers’ boats and crews abandoning ship.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger says he does not know exactly why Alexis Sánchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased the £32 million Chilean forward, courted by several elite clubs after Barcelona decided to let him leave, opted for the Emirates Stadium, where he has made an immediate impact with 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool’s interest may have been used as leverage by Barcelona during negotiations over Luis Suárez and praises Sánchez’s qualities, work-rate and ability to reshape games. He downplays transfer speculation linking him to Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling, while acknowledging Brendan Rodgers has done well to rebuild his side following the departures of Suárez and the injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt cycling’s UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London’s Olympic Velodrome, aiming to surpass Australian Rohan Dennis’s 52.491 km mark set in February. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who celebrated his 35th birthday on April 28, will ride for a crowd of 6,000 with tickets (priced £49, £39 and £29) on sale from April 19 via Sky Tickets and live coverage on Sky Sports. Wiggins, whose track résumé includes three Olympic golds and the world time-trial title, ended his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, will race the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his own team, and is targeting an eighth Olympic medal in Rio 2016’s four-man team pursuit. “The Hour Record is a holy grail for cyclists,” he said, hoping to inspire others to challenge themselves.

Serena Williams rallied from a set down to beat Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off on clay but the U.S. still went down 3-2 after Williams and Alison Riske were routed 6-0, 6-3 in the doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, condemning America to World Group II. Williams called the match an “eye-opener,” admitting she isn’t yet adapted to clay despite her hard-court dominance and two French Open titles, and vowed to work on her consistency. U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez acknowledged the need for greater effort but remained optimistic about the depth of American players in the top 100 and a return to the elite group next year.

River Plate have expressed interest in re-signing Manchester United loanee Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian saying “we dream of Falcao” and “the doors are open,” though any deal would be complicated. The Colombia forward spent eight years at River Plate—joining at 15 in 2001 and scoring 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances—before moving to Porto in 2009. He has struggled at Old Trafford this season with just four Premier League goals and it is unclear whether United will exercise their option to buy or he will return to parent club Monaco. Internationally, Falcao has recently scored three times in two games to equal Colombia’s all-time scoring record of 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19-year-old X Factor finalist known for her powerful vocals and glossy long hair, has been announced as the official face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry-shampoo campaign—her first brand collaboration. Photographed against a blurred city backdrop in various hairstyles, from loose waves to a tousled half-ponytail, Henderson appears in sleek black and sheer outfits, while the international campaign, created by MILES agency, features a TV ad set to her single “Mirror Man.” Henderson, who regularly uses Batiste products, expressed her excitement about the partnership, which her management’s CEO Mark Hargreaves hailed as a natural fit between the platinum-selling artist and the UK’s top dry-shampoo brand.

Family and friends of 26-year-old Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by Officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after a vehicle and foot pursuit during which Siler—wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant—armed himself with a weapon, are outraged by a Kenosha Professional Police Association–funded billboard featuring Torres and his dog bearing the message “Thank you for your support, Kenosha,” calling it disrespectful and demanding its removal. Torres, who is on leave while the state Division of Criminal Investigation probes Siler’s death, had ten days earlier shot and wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives; that shooting was later deemed justified by District Attorney Robert Zapf.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were slain in a clash Monday near the southeastern town of Negur after the militants, who Iranian officials say crossed in from Pakistan, attacked border posts. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal, which claims to oppose Iranian influence and has targeted Shiites in Pakistan’s Balochistan region, took responsibility for the assault; it has carried out previous incursions into Iran, including a deadly October 2013 attack that killed 14 guards. Iran has urged Pakistan to apprehend the surviving attackers, and Pakistan’s government has condemned the incident as terrorism, launched an investigation, and pledged to bring any militants who fled back into Pakistani territory to justice.

Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told parliament that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, only birds or other mundane objects, when jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified aerial phenomena. His statement came in response to questions from flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki—founder of New Japan Pro Wrestling, ex-WWE star, 1976 Muhammad Ali opponent, TV personality and “basketball diplomat”—who asked whether any research into alien visitors existed and if aircraft had been mobilized against them. This exchange follows earlier political debates, including a 2007 inquiry into the constitutional legality of defending Japan against a space invasion.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his left leg and buttocks after the porcelain toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed, shattering on the floor; too embarrassed to call for help loudly, he phoned his traveling companions before emergency personnel arrived and took him to a local hospital for several dozen stitches. He initially told friends he had been squatting to avoid touching a possibly unclean seat, then told police he had been sitting—apparently to evade compensation liability—while authorities concluded the poorly built fixture’s failure was accidental and reminded users that airport toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden bathroom camera that investigators traced to him; prosecutors say he used the device to film her—and others—over a three- to four-year span, including 41 videos (34 showing victims showering) with some close-ups of children’s genitalia. The girl reported that Rebbie had molested her in her bedroom from ages nine to 13 and secretly watched her undress or sleep. Rebbie faces charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy; he admitted filming multiple juveniles and purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old. Held on $500,000 bail, his preliminary hearing is set for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new series, featured in his book roughly titled Daughter and Salaryman, pairs po-faced teenage daughters in casual clothes with their sharply suited fathers as the dads leap energetically into the air beside them. Aoyama says the jumps let typically serious “salaryman” fathers reveal a fun, heroic side, evoking excitement and hope, and the resulting images—some with subtly pained expressions from older dads—have generated widespread online interest despite little other background information.

Kevin Pietersen kicked off Surrey’s county championship season at the Kia Oval by taking a place at the end of the front row for the team photo, where he alternated between deep reflection and joking with photographers, even briefly turning his camera on them. His return to Surrey—where they open their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19 and face Oxford MCCU this Sunday—comes just days after England’s managing director Paul Downton was dismissed, clearing the way for the 34-year-old to press his case for a sensational recall to the England Test side ahead of this summer’s Ashes on home soil.

Relegation-threatened Ceahlăul Piatra Neamț have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week: after being fired on Wednesday and then reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, he was removed again following a 2-0 loss to mid-table FC Botoșani that left them 16th and six points from safety. The 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma right back, capped 25 times by Brazil, had replaced Florin Marin in January as Ceahlăul’s third coach of the season and will now be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinović.

Radamel Falcao, who joined Manchester United on a season-long loan after recovering from a serious knee injury, has managed just four goals and faces an unlikely permanent move for £46 million, and his former Monaco team-mate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao now regrets leaving Monaco—even though he was unhappy there—because he would have played in the Champions League had he stayed.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a “very tall” man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Union Street around 12:30 pm on Saturday, wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and an oversized cartoon mask; security footage shows him seizing the till and about $1,500 in cash after demanding money from the owner’s daughter—who fled screaming “robber!”—before fleeing on foot without displaying any weapon; anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after admitting in a police interview to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts the previous April. Released on bail, she was arrested again on Monday and booked into Irving County Jail after a second 15-year-old pupil accused her of having sex with him in her car on the nights of January 18 and 19. School officials suspended her and placed her on administrative leave once the allegations emerged; she posted $50,000 bail on the new charges, and her intended plea is not yet known. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

A viral video shows a large American crocodile gliding through Puerto Vallarta’s public marina in Mexico with a dead black dog wearing a red collar—belonging to a local bike‐shop owner—clamped in its jaws for hours; New Zealander tourist Tim Weston, who was holidaying there with his wife, recorded the scene and explained that a crocodile sanctuary lies 200 meters up the river that feeds the marina, and that such sightings are common in the mangrove‐built resort and even on its golf course; social media users reacted with horror, noting that urbanization has brought these six‐meter‐long reptiles ever closer to humans.

Steve Bruce remains confident he can steer Hull City clear of relegation despite their 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points above the drop zone with six games to go, including fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Bruce had targeted ten wins but has managed only six so far and is now hoping that eight or nine will suffice, blaming long-term injuries to key players such as Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass for their struggles. At St Mary’s Stadium, Hull started well but conceded a James Ward-Prowse penalty—after Sadio Mané briefly tried to take it—and a late Graziano Pellè goal. Southampton climbed to fifth under Ronald Koeman, who also plans to address squad discipline following the penalty incident.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after admitting he and some pupils altered SATs exam answers outside test conditions, leading the Department for Education to annul the entire school’s results. A local education authority investigation, prompted by a tip-off, found Guffick had asked pupils to change answers and had himself made amendments before submissions. Although he claimed the changes were for legibility, a National College for Teaching and Leadership panel deemed his conduct dishonest but not fraudulent. Acknowledging his remorse and cooperation, the panel and Education Secretary’s representative judged a prohibition order appropriate, with Guffick given 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper who has struggled for regular football since joining from Aalesunds in 2010—making just 19 Premier League appearances and now third choice behind David de Gea and Víctor Valdés—appears far happier off the pitch, enjoying time with his stunning model wife Misse Beqiri. The Danish international, who’s been dating Beqiri since 2012 and married her in a romantic beach ceremony in Mauritius last year, often posts their family snapshots on Instagram, where his Swedish beauty wife (of Albanian roots) also shares her modelling shots with over 17,000 followers, and the couple have a young son together.

The 13 glowing blue letters that hung above Yankee Stadium from 1976 until its 2008 closing, now owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, failed to sell at Sotheby’s despite an estimated $300,000–$600,000 value; the only bid of $260,000 came from a Sotheby’s employee to spur interest. Jackson, who bought them on a whim after the stadium’s final game, had promised to visit any U.S. buyer’s home to see the signage. Meanwhile, a late-’60s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after Sterling was photographed inhaling nitrous oxide and then, with Ibe, smoking a shisha pipe. Rodgers met with both players but will not discipline them, instead urging them to learn from the incident and move on. With Daniel Sturridge injured, Sterling is set to lead Liverpool’s attack at Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final at Wembley against Aston Villa, where Steven Gerrard returns from suspension. Rodgers emphasized that setbacks like last season’s near-misses in the title race and cup competitions are part of the journey to future success.

Mesut Özil returned to London after helping Germany to a 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia, posting a “Home Sweet Home” photo of himself relaxing with his dog, and is now focused on Arsenal’s Premier League clash with Liverpool; signed from Real Madrid for £42.5 million in 2013, he missed the Newcastle match through illness and faced untrue nightclub rumors, but since January has tallied three goals and four assists, and says he’s finally adapting to the demanding “English weeks” schedule and feels he “fits perfectly” into English football.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has ruled out replacing manager Luis Enrique, saying he’s “very happy” with the 44-year-old, who took over last summer on a two-year deal running until 2016 and is now six games from clinching La Liga. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s work preparing for both the Champions League and domestic fixtures, noting that Barcelona remain in contention for three trophies, and highlighted Saturday’s 2-0 win over Valencia at the Nou Camp, with early goals from Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool’s 24-year-old vice-captain, has agreed a new long-term contract at Anfield worth around £100,000 a week that will run until the summer of 2020, despite having 14 months left on his previous deal. Signed from Sunderland in June 2011 for £16 million, Henderson has flourished under Brendan Rodgers, contributing seven goals and 13 assists this season and emerging as a leading candidate to succeed Steven Gerrard as club captain. He is the third key player—after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho—to extend his stay under Rodgers, while talks over Raheem Sterling’s future are on hold until season’s end but are expected to resume.

Filipe Luis, who moved from Atletico Madrid to Chelsea on a three-year deal last July but has struggled to cement the left-back spot, has declared he is happy at Stamford Bridge and intends to see out his contract despite Atletico’s interest in re-signing him. Having featured for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, he and his teammates now return their focus to a demanding Premier League title run-in, with Jose Mourinho insisting on unwavering concentration across the nine remaining fixtures.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban and red card for accidentally striking George North with his knee as he scored for Northampton on March 27 has been overturned on appeal, with the panel concluding the collision was accidental and not foul play. Originally suspended for reckless conduct despite no intent, Hughes missed Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final against Toulon while awaiting the outcome. North, knocked unconscious for the third time in two months, has since been advised to rest for at least a month. The initial decision drew widespread criticism from figures including James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey and Joe Marler, and upon reviewing new evidence the appeal panel, chaired by Jeremy Summers, rescinded the ban, allowing Hughes to return to action immediately, though he is unlikely to feature until late April.

A series of intense red and orange sunsets over Seattle and parts of Oregon, Washington and British Columbia were caused by smoke from widespread wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which began when farmers’ grass-burning blazes were whipped into massive infernos by strong winds on April 14. Although rescue crews eventually extinguished the flames and dozens of villages were destroyed, atmospheric currents carried lingering smoke particles across the Pacific, filtering out shorter-wavelength light (greens, blues, yellows and purples) and allowing red and orange hues to dominate at sunrise and sunset; as the smoke clears, air quality will improve and the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her brand-new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchase, then recovered on April 1 when a tipster, Mick Sexton, alerted police—and returned it to her sporting spray-painted red rims, red side detailing and orange steering-wheel accents. Rather than complain, Schoenig posted a photo on Facebook thanking the thieves for “pimping out” her car, though she’s now having it professionally cleaned to remove lingering cigarette and marijuana odors. In gratitude to Sexton, who spotted the vehicle, she’s also created a smoothie called the “Sexton on Wheels” at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City’s squad stand to lose up to £500,000 each—around £12 million in total—if they fail to finish in the top four and thus miss the Champions League group stage, a provision built into their contracts to comply with Financial Fair Play; currently fourth after a derby defeat to Manchester United, they sit just four points ahead of Liverpool with upcoming matches against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea and Southampton, and manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the team’s season has “thrown it into the garbage” following seven losses and early cup exits, while their rivals United, now four points clear, believe they can still attract top talent such as Paul Pogba.

Manchester United’s Under-18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in their “mini-derby” at Altrincham’s Moss Lane before around 1,000 spectators, fielding a largely local, English side in a three-at-the-back set-up mirroring the first team. Callum Gribbin, who had previously gone viral for his skills, drew a foul on the edge of the box and curled a free-kick past City keeper Charlie Albinson just before the hour. City’s Marcus Wood went closest in the first half, and United’s Marcus Rashford squandered two chances, while Cameron Borthwick-Jackson rattled the frame of the goal in the second period. Late efforts from City, including a Javairo Dilrosun free-kick, failed to find the net. The win moved United to within two points of leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-hit City have lost both of their playoff fixtures. The match underlined FA chair Greg Dyke’s point on the need for more pathways for homegrown talent aged 18–21.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” and an inspiration after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England, while Hart himself celebrated his 50th appearance for his country. The Manchester City shot-stopper, ten years Buffon’s junior, told FA TV he is still learning and looking up to the veteran’s longevity at age 37, and expressed pride in reaching 50 caps at such a young age, vowing to continue performing for club and country to add even more.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food-delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver online and mobile orders in 67 cities, adding a nine-percent service charge on top of Postmates’ $5-and-up delivery fees; Postmates uses independent contractors in a model similar to Uber. Chipotle, which had previously declined third-party delivery offers, has recently seen presidential hopefuls Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton shopping in its outlets. Other chains such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s and Burger King are also rolling out or testing delivery services.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard—who was killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings—and whose daughter Jane was severely injured, have published a front-page Boston Globe opinion urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev now that he’s been convicted on all 30 related charges, and instead sentence him to life without parole with no right to appeal. They acknowledge the “heinousness and brutality” of his crimes, having endured days in court viewing graphic evidence, but say prolonged appeals will only force their family—and the city—to relive their worst day. The sentencing phase begins this week and is expected to last four weeks; Tsarnaev’s brother, Tamerlan, was killed in a police shootout in 2015.

A mystery billionaire has spent around £400 million and three years converting a Boeing 747-8—normally able to carry up to 600 passengers—into a flying luxury residence complete with multiple lounges, a state room, an onboard restaurant and kitchen, a large dining room, a conference room, and an “aeroloft” on the upper deck with eight full beds, plus a master bedroom suite, guest cabins, office space and hotel-style décor capable of accommodating several dozen guests in ultimate comfort.

SpaceX on Tuesday launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo ship to the International Space Station and achieved a successful ascent and Dragon enroute, but its first attempt to land the booster on a sea-based droneship ended in a tipped-over touchdown. Founder Elon Musk said SpaceX will keep refining sea landings en route to fully reusable rockets that could cut launch costs by up to 100-fold. After launch, the Falcon 9’s upper stage will deploy Dragon into orbit before burning up, and Dragon will dock with the station in a couple of days with 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research gear and an ISSpresso coffee maker. The crew will unload over five weeks, reload Dragon with some 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash for return, then send it back to splash down off California. This marks SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission—its second attempt after Monday’s weather-scrubbed launch—and the first private contractor to dock with the station.

Priscilla Presley, Elvis’s former wife, will witness the first wedding at the newly opened Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel in the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows, after collaborating with NBC’s Today show on a contest for one “Elvis-obsessed” couple. The winners—announced next Monday—will marry on April 23, receive a free reception and two-night hotel suite, round-trip airfare and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show, and must submit photos or video explaining why they deserve the prize. Presley helped design the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, and has insisted it be a first-class venue with no impersonators.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson, who along with goalkeeper Simon Mignolet made his 47th appearance of the season to equal a top-five European leagues record, believes Liverpool can still close the four-point gap on Premier League leaders Manchester City after a morale-boosting 2-0 win over Newcastle. Raheem Sterling’s skillful ninth-minute opener and Joe Allen’s first Anfield goal, capitalizing on a defensive error 20 minutes from time, secured the victory, and Allen admitted he thought Newcastle should have had a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Pérez. Henderson acknowledged recent disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal but insisted that continued winning performances could keep their title hopes alive.

Roma ended a four-month home winless run in Serie A with a 1-0 victory over Napoli, moving provisionally into second place four points clear of city rivals Lazio, thanks to a 25th-minute Miralem Pjanic finish from a rapid counterattack and a man-of-the-match performance by goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis, who thwarted numerous Napoli attempts—including saves from Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini. Napoli, whose own winless streak reached five games, faced tight security—Campania residents were banned from purchasing tickets and 1,000 police were deployed—because of past fan violence, but no incidents occurred. Roma were without Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli introduced Lorenzo Insigne late in his comeback from a November knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers, enduring a largely uninspired League One campaign, played out a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium, leaving little to excite fans or media alike. With both teams failing to break the deadlock, Doncaster’s media team distilled the match highlights into a remarkably brief 27-second YouTube video—just 14 seconds of actual play, featuring kickoff, a goal kick and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux’s video shows him gently cupping and stroking his blood parrot cichlid inside its tank, the fish repeatedly swimming away then returning to be massaged and even burying its face in his hand. Initially housed with two other fish that bullied it, the cichlid became more sociable after Giroux removed its tankmates and hand-fed it frozen blood worms. Over time the fish began to crave daily interaction—15-minute massage sessions—and responded by swimming up Giroux’s arm, circling his fingers, and lingering at the surface when he withdrew his hand. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid of midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan in 1986, appears to enjoy and anticipate this human contact.

Ben Stokes’s return to the England team at the Kensington Oval highlights both his fiery character and the need to channel his aggression positively: after fracturing a wrist punching a locker last year and clashing with Marlon Samuels in the second Test, Stokes responded well to a one-on-one meeting with coach Peter Moores and put in a composed performance thereafter. Despite a slight back niggle that could rule him out in Barbados, England are keen to retain his natural exuberance—as long as it yields runs and wickets—while managing him carefully so he doesn’t become typecast by his reputation. With the selection balance also considering Chris Jordan and second spinner Adil Rashid, England want to maximize opportunities for both exciting talents to mature fully at the international level.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the 33,000-capacity Cardiff City Stadium has been declared a sell-out after overwhelming demand following Wales’ 3-0 victory over Israel, which propelled Chris Coleman’s side to the top of Group B on goal difference alongside Belgium. Both teams sit on 11 points from five matches, with Belgium leading by superior goal difference, and Wales—energized by Gareth Bale’s free-kick brilliance and seeking their first major tournament qualification since 1958—will play at Cardiff City Stadium rather than the larger Millennium Stadium, partly due to UEFA’s 120-day venue rule and the squad’s preference for the more intimate setting.

England Under-17 coach John Peacock has named a 20-man squad for next month’s UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions—undefeated in qualifying—have been drawn in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland. They open against Italy in Burgas on May 7, face Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad features goalkeepers Paul Woolston and Will Huffer; defenders Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva and Tayo Edun; midfielders Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland and Arsenal debutant Chris Willock; and forwards Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi and Ike Ugbo.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, widely regarded as one of the Belgian club’s top youth prospects and already on the radar of Arsenal and Barcelona; having turned down a move to La Masia at age 12 to continue his education, he has kept impressing, prompting City—under Manuel Pellegrini—to negotiate a compensation package with chairman Roger Vanden Stock as they look to secure the emerging talent for the future.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, on March 28, having suffered fatal head and neck injuries. Scotland Yard arrested a 23-year-old man who has since been bailed pending further questioning, and Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is appealing for anyone who saw or contacted Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan, who described herself online as visiting from Miami in search of “upscale” clients and spoke of her love for London and Paris, also worked as an escort in Paris and Miami, though police have not confirmed whether her profession is central to the investigation.

Dawn, a woman who has suffered seven miscarriages and buried one child, Daniel James, discovered that a family friend and housemate, Jamie, had stolen £207 she and her partner had saved toward the £500 needed for their baby’s gravestone. Confronting him on The Jeremy Kyle Show, she enlisted a lie detector test, which confirmed his theft; further evidence emerged in a Facebook message in which he admitted taking the money but blamed his girlfriend, Carol. Devastated by the betrayal, Dawn broke down in tears and left the stage, lamenting that the stolen funds were intended as a final gesture of love for her lost son.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis—mostly women and children, along with some elderly and ill—who had been captured when the militants overran Yazidi towns in northern Iraq last summer. Peshmerga commander Rassol Omar and Kurdistan Regional Government official Nuri Osman said Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, and the freed captives were taken to Irbil. Estimates of those freed ranged from 217 to 228. Since its 2014 offensive, ISIS has killed, enslaved and displaced hundreds of thousands of Yazidis—an ancient Kurdish minority whose religion predates Islam—and provoked an international humanitarian response that included U.S.-led airstrikes.

Harry Kane, having broken into Tottenham’s first team and Roy Hodgson’s England side, is shortlisted for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards after scoring 20 Premier League goals this term; a new Copa90 animation—titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” and released ahead of Sunday’s awards ceremony—brings his best strikes and celebrations to life, including his long-range effort against Chelsea, headed goal versus Arsenal and his goal on England debut.

Jamie Carragher defended Brendan Rodgers as the right man to lead Liverpool despite a trophyless season and likely failure to finish in the top four, arguing that one game shouldn’t define a manager’s future and noting that many of Rodgers’s summer signings have yet to settle; Carragher said the squad is capable of improving next season with the right new recruits and expressed confidence in Rodgers identifying the team’s needs. He spoke after receiving a Beacon Award in London for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in deprived schools and aims to support youngsters from areas like his native Bootle.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly coloured Nerf toy gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security staff deemed it a security risk when it appeared on X-ray; he was also frisked before being forced to hand it over, leaving his parents—Phil and Hazel Hayward—unable to argue further as they risked missing their flight to Lanzarote. James’s father criticized the “over-zealous” checks as ludicrous, and upon returning from their 10-day holiday the family bought James a replacement toy off eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized and offered to post the original back to the family, defending the decision by citing government-set regulations that ban any hand-luggage items resembling prohibited or replica guns.

A 31-year-old man identifying himself as “Rich” from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, placed a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife, detailing that she must love pets, be a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good with her hands, a good cook, great in bed, enjoy the outdoors yet “also a princess when need be,” and willing to help around the house. He offers accommodation, a potential company car, phone, laptop, free gym membership of her choice, and promises to spend freely on his partner. In his own description, he’s athletic with brown hair, brown eyes, tattoos, 175 cm tall, “well endowed,” owns property, earns a good income, and enjoys travel, sports, fishing, camping, cars and bikes. Former partners need not apply, and Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke, backed by former England managers Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Göran Eriksson and Steve McClaren, is pushing Premier League clubs to raise the minimum number of home-grown players in their squads from eight to 12 and to redefine “home-grown” as having trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than 21. The ex-managers warn in a signed letter that failing to adopt these changes risks England falling further behind other football nations and hampering its World Cup prospects, noting that only 36.8 percent of recent Premier League starters were England-eligible and that the pool of domestic talent at the top level is shrinking. They cite the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane as proof of potential, but argue these prospects lack sufficient opportunity without the proposed reforms.

Demelza Poldark, who was only just showing last week, gives birth to Ross Poldark’s baby daughter within the first ten minutes of next week’s episode, prompting fans to remark on the jarring time jump from the pregnancy announcement in the previous installment to Demelza suddenly being eight months pregnant and then delivering moments later—a trend viewers had already mocked when Elizabeth’s pregnancy similarly spanned full term between episodes.

Leicester boss Nigel Pearson, buoyed by back-to-back Premier League wins that have moved his side to within three points of safety despite remaining bottom, has warned his players to stay focused on their own performances rather than obsess over relegation rivals; after Jamie Vardy’s injury-time winner at West Brom handed them a lifeline, Pearson stressed that their fate is in their own hands, urged caution against over-optimism and insisted that only by concentrating on their remaining fixtures can they realistically secure survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a new mammal migration record by swimming nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island, across the Pacific, down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico—surpassing the previous 10,190-mile round-trip record held by a humpback. Tracked by Oregon State University scientists, Varvara’s route included visits to three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she may be from that population rather than the endangered western group, of which only about 150 are thought to remain. This unexpected crossover raises questions about the genetic distinction between western and eastern gray whales and indicates a need for closer study.

On Japan’s Hokkaido Island, about 1,000–1,640 ft of seabed off the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu unexpectedly rose as much as 30–50 ft above sea level overnight, exposing a stretch about 100 ft wide. Geologists and local researchers attribute the emergence to a landslide triggered when melting ice and snow caused nearby land to drop and pivot the submerged section upward. Residents reported no tremors or sounds, and authorities—who do not link the event to the recent Kathmandu earthquake—do not expect further expansion. Marine life remains attached to the new land.

Gregory van der Wiel has dismissed reports linking him with a summer exit from Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his happiness at the club, love for the city and teammates, and desire to sign a new contract, despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match; however, PSG’s persistent interest in Barcelona’s Dani Alves could affect Van der Wiel’s future.

Carlos Tevez has informed Juventus he wishes to terminate his contract, which runs until 2016, in order to return to Boca Juniors this summer. Boca president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to finalizing the deal but stressed that Tevez must first end his Juventus agreement. The 31-year-old former Manchester City striker, who has scored 17 Serie A goals this season and helped Juventus chase a second consecutive league title and European success, has always planned to finish his career at the club where he began as a youth in 1996. Juventus, despite reluctance to lose the league’s top scorer, have accepted his desire to leave and are already seeking replacements. Argentina manager Tata Martino said Tevez’s club choice—Juventus or Boca—won’t affect his national-team prospects.

Bayern Munich overwhelmed Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena to overturn a 3-1 first-leg deficit and reach the Champions League semi-finals, leading 5-0 by half-time thanks to goals from Thiago Alcântara, Jérôme Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a Robert Lewandowski brace. In the excitement, manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his grey trousers—briefly revealing his underwear—and quipped afterward that he’d need to buy new ones, even ditching his blazer as the match wore on.

Ten people, including four children, were injured in a three-vehicle collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway 2 km south of Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were airlifted by Rescue 500 to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. Six others—among them an infant, two young girls, a man with hand lacerations and two uninjured females—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. Queensland Fire and Rescue crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free one person trapped in a vehicle. The affected stretch of the highway remains closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Second-placed Arsenal prepare to host league leaders Chelsea this Sunday, and playmaker Mesut Özil has already marked the occasion by showing off his newly acquired Apple Watch—complete with a #knightrider-style Instagram post—ahead of its Friday release; the 26-year-old, who has scored four goals in 25 appearances this season, is expected to start at the Emirates. Arsenal sit ten points behind Chelsea with six games left but have been bolstered by Jack Wilshere’s return from a five-month injury layoff, and club legend Ray Parlour has publicly backed the 23-year-old midfielder as “the future of the club” provided he can finally maintain his fitness.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will take charge of Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford alongside assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official, despite having sent off three players this season—City captain Vincent Kompany for Belgium’s Euro 2016 qualifier against Israel and two Manchester United players, Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw, in Premier League matches. Although he has faced accusations of bias toward Louis van Gaal’s side, Clattenburg has issued only two top-flight red cards this season, both to United. Generally regarded alongside Michael Oliver as one of the Premier League’s leading referees, he steps in as United, buoyed by five straight league wins, sit one point above City following their unexpected 2-1 defeat at Crystal Palace, with both clubs vying for second place behind Chelsea.

Federal MP Bob Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, has accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon—a former Labor member forced to quit after domestic-violence allegations and failing to disclose his criminal history—would resign and serve as “a little black puppet on a string,” a phrase he says reflects the racial assumptions he’s personally experienced; his statement, which compared Gordon’s potential role to how federal independents like Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott reportedly aided government agendas, drew social-media criticism for its terminology, prompting Katter to defend his choice of words as a deliberate rebuke of racial overtones while insisting Gordon would retain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but refuses to let it define her, creating upbeat dance videos—such as one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to challenge stereotypes, counteract bullying and stares, and show that she lives like any other teenager: walking, driving, attending college, and now speaking motivationally at local schools to inspire others to look past disability labels and recognize shared humanity.

Orlando City, coached by former Everton and Manchester City striker Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, have enquired about Manchester United forward Javier Hernández, whose frustrating loan spell at Real Madrid has not halted interest from eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan—which, along with United, value him at around £8 million; meanwhile United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted attention from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord after rejecting their initial terms.

A group of at least three people confronted a man pumping gas at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 a.m. on Saturday, attempted to carjack him, then poured gasoline over his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers remained inside; nobody was hurt but the vehicle’s front end was destroyed, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the incident as arson using surveillance video to track the suspects, who are still at large.

Charles Manuel, a Lamoni, Iowa, chiropractor, admitted to the Iowa Board of Chiropractic that he bartered sexual acts for treatments, performed exorcisms on patients and advised some to discontinue prescribed medications; he surrendered his license, agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least ten years and must prove the conditions leading to revocation no longer exist before resuming practice, despite having received three perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com.

The United States has formally protested to Moscow after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew deeming the Russian pilot’s aggressive, high-speed maneuvers “unsafe and unprofessional.” Russia’s Defense Ministry, via Sputnik, claimed the American aircraft was approaching its border with its transponder off and that the SU-27 circled to identify its tail number, a claim denied by U.S. European Command. The Pentagon and State Department plan to lodge a diplomatic complaint, marking yet another close encounter between these aircraft types—following a similarly perilous Russian overflight of an RC-135U near the Sea of Okhotsk a year earlier—and underscoring frequent NATO-Russia aerial interactions from Northern Europe to the Russian Far East.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen in the early hours of March 27 from the rear right passenger-side window of his vehicle parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City just days before President Obama’s Utah visit; despite being secured in a hard case locked to a truck safe with padlocks and chains, the thief broke the window, tied a rope to the case handle or cable lock, used another vehicle’s momentum to wrench it free, and pulled the window frame from the door. Two skid marks, rope fragments and the broken case handle remained at the scene; the agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools were also taken, some of which were later recovered at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel, located across from the state FBI office and near the airport, lacked surveillance cameras. The rifle’s serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified ahead of the presidential visit.

Luigi Costa, 71, stands accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 at a Red Hill, Canberra home, allegedly stomping on his head, cutting his throat and repeatedly stabbing him in the dining room. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa showed signs of dementia compounded by alcohol abuse, noting fluctuating mood during the incident—as evidenced by 000 calls placed “moment to moment”—and a trail of faeces indicating confusion. Mullen concluded that Costa’s brain was compromised, impairing his understanding of his actions and their consequences, a view challenged by the prosecutor’s suggestion of feigned memory loss. Costa’s mental state is central to the trial, as a demonstrated unstable mindset could lead the jury to deliver a not‐guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended the decision to allow Ross Barkley, rather than habitual spot-kick taker Leighton Baines, to take a 10th-minute penalty in their 1-0 win over Burnley despite Barkley’s effort being saved by Tom Heaton; Martinez explained that having multiple willing takers—dependent on who feels confident at the moment—can be beneficial, citing that Romelu Lukaku would have taken it if he’d been on the pitch, and praised Barkley’s willingness to assume responsibility, while Leighton Baines, who boasts a record of 15 successful Premier League penalties from 16 attempts, supported the choice.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico, after cleaning staff discovered them following a knock on the door; the cruise line said the deaths, reported at 11:30 a.m. Thursday, appear to have been a murder-suicide, and authorities including the FBI have been notified and are investigating.

Former Dutch forward and former Holland assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has begun his tenure as Curaçao’s head coach with a victory in 2018 World Cup qualifying, guiding the Caribbean side past Montserrat on a 4-3 aggregate after a 2-1 home win and a 2-2 draw away, the decisive goal coming in the 87th minute from substitute Charlton Vicento. Curaçao now advance to the CONCACAF second round to face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curaçao, was a World Cup semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and reached the semis again in 2014 as Louis van Gaal’s assistant.

Esteban Cambiasso, who amassed 15 major trophies during spells at River Plate, Real Madrid and Inter Milan—including La Liga, Champions League and FIFA Club World Cup titles—has declared that helping Leicester City avoid relegation would feel “like another cup,” equating it with his past triumphs. The Argentine midfielder signed a one-year deal with the Foxes last summer and, despite no wins since January, remains optimistic that the seven-point deficit with eight games left can be overturned. Speaking to BBC East Midlands Today, he emphasized the difficulty of the task but insisted his teammates have the quality to secure Premier League survival, adding that he is happy in the East Midlands and open to extending his stay beyond the current season.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two under-fives by different fathers, handed her babies to her 52-year-old mother Debbie at four months old after social services threatened to remove them, and now faces being barred from seeing them because she continues heavy drinking, drug use (including MKat), partying and unemployment; Debbie, who has raised the children alone and whose lie-detector test showed Gemma stole an iPad (which Gemma denies though admits past thefts), says Gemma “isn’t fit” to parent, the children call Debbie “mum,” and she’s prepared to ban Gemma from her home and grandchildren if she doesn’t change her lifestyle.

Chelsea’s opening goal against Manchester United saw controversy as captain John Terry’s forceful challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao went unpunished, allowing Chelsea to regain possession—Cesc Fabregas picked up the loose ball, fed Oscar, whose back-heel set up Eden Hazard to score. At half-time, pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness agreed Terry’s elbow-driven tackle on Falcao constituted a foul deserving a stoppage, with Souness highlighting the forearm contact, Henry expressing sympathy as a fellow striker, and Redknapp noting that even if Falcao could have stayed on his feet, the challenge should not have been ignored.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire Thursday morning on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas after a rear tire blew out, but everyone aboard—Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver—evacuated safely before flames engulfed the rear. CNN iReporter Michael Barnett recorded the blaze as traffic slowed, and Scott later posted on Instagram that the fire destroyed everything in the bus’s back lounge except her Bible, thanking those who helped extinguish the fire. Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing satellites covered in mirrors that harvest sunlight, convert it via semiconductors into laser beams, and beam that energy back to Earth to boost solar panels or restore power in disaster zones; initial trials in Scotland succeeded and next trials are planned in Portugal. Unlike fictional “space lasers” or even the proposed Riken-inspired ISS system for clearing sub-centimetre debris—which would use pulsed lasers to push junk into the atmosphere—Quarterman’s beams are too weak to harm wildlife or destroy planets, though he concedes that the question of who controls the satellites remains a potential concern.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with learning difficulties and autism, has been missing since 6:15 pm on Tuesday after disappearing from a private psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under a hospital order following his August conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and admitting to ten counts of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children; described as about 5 ft 8 in, heavy-built with dark hair (possibly clean-shaven), he is considered highly dangerous, prompting a police manhunt and urgent appeals for anyone with information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.63 million in gifts—ranging from a Ferrari, two Bentleys and a Range Rover to a $1.8 million duplex, a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender and a $12 lace thong—that she received from former Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling after his wife, Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling, sued her for allegedly targeting wealthy older men and misusing family funds; Stiviano argued the gifts were freely given, but Shelly Sterling’s lawyer hailed the ruling as a precedent allowing an injured spouse to recover “ill-begotten” gifts, coming on the heels of Donald Sterling’s NBA ban, $2.5 million fine and forced sale of the team following the release of his racist remarks toward Stiviano and African-Americans.

Thierry Henry has slammed Arsenal’s transfer inactivity, insisting they must sign a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and a top-quality striker this summer if they are to challenge for the Premier League, and suggested that Olivier Giroud—even with 14 league goals this season—cannot lead them to a title; he contrasted Arsenal’s approach with Chelsea’s mid-season acquisitions of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fàbregas and Diego Costa, which he says underpinned their league success.

A young woman testified in Sydney’s District Court about the lasting harm caused by years of abuse at the hands of Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sexual offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. She said she didn’t recognise the abuse as wrongdoing when it began and kept it secret until learning of his arrest compelled her to speak out. Since then, she has struggled with depression, self-harm and a suicide attempt, and fears for her future relationships and the stigma if others discover what happened. Van Ryn sat impassively in the dock, and the hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, the 19-year-old Arsenal and Germany Under-21 midfielder whose progress was halted by a serious knee injury sustained during the Champions League last-16 against Bayern Munich in March 2014, is closing in on a first-team return after more than a year out; he recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal’s Under-21s against Reading, his second full match in a week, and says he is feeling “better and better” and looking forward to the next game.

Graduate accountant Jacob Phillips, 23, died after leaping over a fence in the dark and plunging 70 ft down a disused cliff at Penarth, South Wales, when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. Phillips, who had been out drinking in Cardiff with friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson, discovered he lacked the cash to complete the ride home and fled with the others splitting up. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, chased Phillips briefly but halted when visibility failed. Disoriented and unaware of the sheer drop at the end of the Northern Promenade (also known as The Dardanelles), Phillips fell and was found dead the next morning by a dog walker. Recording an accidental death verdict, coroner Andrew Barkley noted Phillips could not have known the danger lying ahead. Phillips, originally from Barry and a University of Birmingham graduate, had returned to Wales for Christmas and worked for Pretty Green, the clothing label founded by Oasis’s Liam Gallagher.

Last summer’s HM Passport Office backlog left more than half a million applications delayed, yet only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April and January—totaling £203,066 at an average of £92.68—despite many holidaymakers paying an extra £30 for fast‐track service or missing trips altogether, such as one couple who lost nearly £1,500 despite applying ten weeks in advance. Ministers refused a blanket refund, arguing it would set a precedent, even though the Passport Office made a £42.3 million surplus between April and October and paid managers £1.8 million in bonuses in 2013–14 (averaging £499, with the highest individual bonus £3,500).

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched since the 1930s, is being auctioned on April 30 with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. Inside, it still features its original mint-green and black bathroom with vintage tiles and fixtures, a wood-panelled hallway lit by stained-glass windows depicting ships, a living room with coats-of-arms glazing, and a kitchen lined with its 1930s cupboards, glass-panelled door, brick open-fire and dated sink. A hallway shelf even holds retro tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar and Colman’s Mustard. Although the house has been double-glazed, auctioneers warn that the cost of renovation may deter developers, making it ideal for a family or antiques enthusiast.

Colin Kaepernick, who started his career backing up Alex Smith, took over as the San Francisco 49ers’ quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion and guided the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they fell to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there before relocating to Texas and later San Francisco; Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, linking the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at Secaucus exits 16E and 17 to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises division.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and around Colchester, Essex, and while attending Stanway School he met Graham Coxon and together they formed Blur, whose debut album Leisure was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Drawing on influences such as alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop, Blur achieved worldwide success with their self-titled 2001 album. Albarn released his debut solo studio album, Everyday Robots, on 28 April 2014, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and incorporating samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, also called Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia, hosting many of the country’s key national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails featured on their 1992 debut EP Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has received a BAFTA nomination.

Both the 2007 film Shooter and the subsequent TV series center on Bob Lee Swagger, a former Force Recon marksman. In the movie, Swagger (played by Mark Wahlberg) is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit, while in the TV adaptation, Ryan Phillippe portrays Swagger as an expert sharpshooter living in exile who is drawn back into action upon uncovering a conspiracy to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—all carried out by his followers at his instruction—and also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea; after his indictment, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who made his screen debut in a 1974 episode of Little House on the Prairie directed by his father Leo Penn. After his film debut in Taps (1981) and roles in Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), he gained critical notice in crime dramas such as At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). His lead performance in Dead Man Walking (1995) earned him his first Academy Award nomination and the Berlin Film Festival Best Actor Award. He received further Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), nicknamed “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time, who after retiring continued to shape the sport for three decades as an administrator, selector and writer.

L.A. Reid is a music executive who has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is an American drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007), having begun his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991; as of 2016 he performs in Prophets of Rage alongside Tim Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real and DJ Lord, and the passage also notes that Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series on CBS that aired from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, running 34 episodes across two seasons; CBS announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, four episodes into the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933–September 13, 2006) was an American Democrat who served as Texas state treasurer before delivering the keynote at the 1988 Democratic National Convention and then became the state’s 45th governor from 1991 to 1995, noted as the second female governor of Texas, an outspoken feminist known for her one-liners, and was defeated for re-election by George W. Bush; a different Ann Richards (October 1, 1935–April 1, 1982) was an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an independent EP in 2011 titled A Reminder.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927–October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios (24 July 1783 – 17 December 1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who spearheaded the liberation and establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Panama as independent, sovereign states free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil’s Triangle, is an ill-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous ships and aircraft have reportedly vanished under unexplained circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his NFL career backing up Alex Smith before taking over as the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion; he led the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens, and in his first full season as starter in 2013 guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they fell to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie (1964) is an American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal, openly sponsored form of audio or visual marketing communication used to promote or sell products, services or ideas, and is delivered through a variety of mass media channels—both traditional outlets like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor ads and direct mail, and digital platforms such as search results, blogs, websites and text messages.
Private Lives is a work by Noël Coward that debuted in 1930 as a three-act comedy of manners and was adapted the following year into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira in Chalkidice; at about seventeen or eighteen he joined Plato’s Academy in Athens and studied there until around age thirty-seven (c.347 BC), and shortly after Plato’s death he left Athens to tutor Alexander the Great at Philip II of Macedon’s request beginning in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz (born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer turned musician, inventor and entrepreneur, best known for creating the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and serving as CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson was the Los Angeles Lakers’ point guard for 13 seasons after being the No. 1 pick in the 1979 NBA draft following high school and college championships. He won a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie year and added four more titles during the 1980s. After temporarily retiring amid player protests, he returned in 1996 at age 36 for 32 games before retiring permanently. In 2009 Ebony named him one of America’s most influential Black businessmen, and he has since held numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black (lead vocals, guitar) and Kyle Gass (lead guitar, vocals); they released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006) and Rize of the Fenix (2012)—and first rose to fame in 1997 via their self-titled TV series and by opening for major rock acts.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) became King of Scotland as James VI in July 1567 and, upon the union of the Scottish and English crowns on 24 March 1603, King of England and Ireland as James I until his death. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciaries, and laws, he ruled both in personal union and strongly advocated a single parliament for both kingdoms. He largely succeeded in advancing this goal in Scotland but encountered significant opposition in England, most notably from repeated clashes with Parliament and the Gunpowder Plot of 1605.

Big Brother 2017, also called Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Born on 4 October 1967, Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster and voice‐over artist best known for narrating the UK’s Big Brother since 2000. He also performed continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, after which he continued narrating the revived series on Channel 5. His distinctive Geordie accent and voice‐over work have made him one of Britain’s most recognised voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state of 18,413 km² in the country’s east, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia and Bavaria, as well as Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships) and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec and Ústí nad Labem Regions). It is Germany’s tenth-largest and sixth-most populous state, with about four million residents, and its history stretches back over a millennium within a once entirely German-speaking area. Saxony, together with Saale-Unstrut, forms one of Europe’s northernmost quality wine regions and is one of only two German wine regions located in the territory of the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball stadium in Cincinnati’s East End neighborhood, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown launched her solo career by releasing the single “I Want You Back” with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon and Naseeruddin Shah, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the year’s second highest–grossing Indian film and earned nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead and had shot several scenes before her death, after which Raveena Tandon replaced her, and the film is also remembered for its chart-topping songs.
“Hourglass” refers both to a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and to the fourteenth studio album by singer‐songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer and actor best known for writing the 1987 action film hit Lethal Weapon and making his directorial debut with 2005’s Kiss Kiss Bang Bang.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film and the seventh and final installment to feature Roger Moore as MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea; it was formerly known as Irian Jaya (and before that West Irian or Irian Barat) and once encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music scene in 1999 with her debut album On the 6 and its chart-topping single “If You Had My Love.” In 2001 she became the first woman to top both the album and film charts in the same week with her second album J.Lo and The Wedding Planner. Her high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album This Is Me…Then but couldn’t save 2003’s box-office flop Gigli. After marrying Marc Anthony and starring in the hit Shall We Dance?, she welcomed twins in 2008.
