Following a lull, she resurged in 2011 as an American Idol judge and scored her biggest hit with “On the Floor,” one of the best-selling singles ever.

Working animals are typically domesticated creatures trained by humans to perform tasks, ranging from close family roles like guide or assistance dogs to labor-intensive jobs using draft horses or logging elephants. They also include livestock trained for milking or herding, where human-led cooperation is essential. Occasionally, wild animals are tamed and trained for novelty or entertainment, but they generally lack the reliable temperament and trustworthiness of truly domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen; Top Latin Albums is Billboard’s flagship weekly chart for Spanish-language full-length albums in the U.S. market; and Regional Mexican Albums is a Billboard magazine weekly chart focused on the regional Mexican genre in the United States.

Vedam is a 2010 Telugu-language drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring an ensemble cast that includes Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra’s 1605 novel Don Quixote, serving as Don Quixote’s squire and offering “sanchismos,” a mix of broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American sci-fi action comedy film directed by Ron Underwood and starring Eddie Murphy in dual roles.
Hedda Gabler premiered on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Henrik Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth (born 14 May 1961) is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly called Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students—including first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico—and is the country’s second-oldest active club after Genoa (1893); it has worn black-and-white striped home kits since 1903 and currently plays at the 41,507-seat Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in films such as Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), as well as in the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

Jenna Jameson (born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974) is an American entrepreneur, webcam model and former pornographic actress—dubbed “The Queen of Porn” and the world’s most famous adult entertainment performer—who began her career in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a professional basketball team in the National Basketball Association, competing as a member of the Western Conference’s Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000—initially via closed-circuit television and later on pay-per-view—produced first by the National Wrestling Alliance’s Jim Crockett Promotions and later by World Championship Wrestling; it grew out of JCP’s tradition of staging major Thanksgiving and Christmas shows at Greensboro Coliseum, with Starrcade (1985) marking the third annual show, Starrcade (1987) the fifth, and Starrcade (1997) the fifteenth pay-per-view event.

Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor best known for portraying Connor Walsh on ABC’s legal drama How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS’s historical drama Mercy Street.

South Korean singer and actress Seohyun, born Seo Ju-hyun on June 28, 1991, debuted in August 2007 as a member of Girls’ Generation and its subgroup TTS, one of South Korea’s best-selling and globally popular girl groups. Beyond her group activities, she has acted in Korean and original stage musicals like Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind and Mamma Mia. On January 17, 2017, she launched her solo career with her first extended play, Don’t Say No, becoming the third Girls’ Generation member to release solo material.

The Apple II, introduced in 1977, is an 8-bit home computer and one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products. Designed primarily by Steve Wozniak—with Steve Jobs overseeing the plastic case development and Rod Holt creating its switching power supply—the Apple II series (trademarked as “Apple][” and later “Apple//”) was manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Co-founder Stephen Gary Wozniak, born August 11, 1950, is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur.

A&E, originally known as the Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel and the flagship property of A&E Networks, a joint venture equally owned by the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company’s ABC Television Group.

L.A. Reid is a veteran music executive who has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group, founder and CEO of Hitco Music Publishing, and co-founder of LaFace Records.
Veeram refers to two Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action movie directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays refers to two distinct films: a 1972 American made-for-television horror movie directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 feature film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster in which eight men and eight women compete for the chance to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan (born July 15, 1973) is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label operating as a division of Universal Music Group.
Sikkim is a state located in the northeastern region of India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius “Ron” Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, distributed by Columbia Pictures, and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

In 2016, Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society and completed the Showtime revival of Twin Peaks (2017) reprising her role as Laura Palmer, while Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway.
Matteo Renzi, born on 11 January 1975, is an Italian politician who served as Italy’s Prime Minister from February 2014 until December 2016.
The passage names The Road to El Dorado and lists its principal cast members: Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

“Same Old Love” is a track by American singer Selena Gomez from her second studio album, Revival (2015), which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200; its first three singles—“Good for You,” “Same Old Love” and “Hands to Myself”—each reached the top of the U.S. Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a variety show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United Kingdom and the United States, and by the late 1970s the new wave of British heavy metal scene—exemplified by bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon—continued its development.
Ashton Kutcher went on to star in a string of romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008) and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is a men’s clothing retailer that operates as part of the Arcadia Group—which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans and Dorothy Perkins—and maintains a network of high-street stores across the United Kingdom as well as outlets in six Irish towns and cities.

At the start of the Industrial Revolution, Wales shifted from an agricultural society to an industrial nation as mining and metallurgical development—especially the rapid exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield—drove a swift population expansion.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, toured internationally, and released albums that have topped charts in multiple countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website based in San Bruno, California, and is ranked the world’s second most popular site by Alexa Internet.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television and film.

Conrad Dunn launched his screen career in 1981 playing Francis “Psycho” Soyer in the film Stripes, which also marked the first significant film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl and Judge Reinhold.
Raees is a film starring Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation together with Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of approximately 1.5 million Armenians—mostly Ottoman citizens—during the late Ottoman Empire and early Republic of Turkey, and similar campaigns against Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks (known respectively as the Assyrian genocide and the Greek genocide) are considered by some historians to form part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster and voice-over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton (born August 19, 1946) is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001, with his first inauguration held on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle (born 20 October 1956) is an English director, producer, screenwriter and theatre director known for films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours and Steve Jobs; The Beach, released in 2000, is an adventure drama he directed, based on Alex Garland’s 1996 novel and adapted for the screen by John Hodge.
In the first week after the image’s release, it generated over 10 million tweets featuring hashtags like #thedress, #whiteandgold and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar (22 January 1917 – 11 June 2006) served as an officer in the British Army.
Advertising is a sponsored, nonpersonal form of marketing communication that uses audio or visual messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas.

The 2001 film The Others earned eight Goya Awards—including Best Film and Best Director—becoming the first English-language picture to win Spain’s top prize without any Spanish dialogue, and garnered six Saturn Award nominations (for Best Director and Best Writing for Amenábar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann), winning three: Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman) and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).
Ralph Fults (January 23, 1911 – March 16, 1993) was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who operated with Raymond Hamilton and was linked to Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, born Lhamo Thondup on 6 July 1935 in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet (then administered as part of Qinghai province, Republic of China), was given the religious name Tenzin Gyatso (short for Jetsun Jamphel Ngawang Lobsang Yeshe Tenzin Gyatso), identified in 1937 as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama and formally recognized in 1939 at a public declaration near Bumchen; following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he remains a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna follows four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who, stranded in German-occupied Tuscany during World War II, find refuge in a small village and forge deep bonds with its residents, the tale unfolding as a flashback narrated by one survivor in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy (born November 27, 1957) is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

Home for the Holidays is a 1995 film featuring an ensemble cast that includes Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, then relocated first to Texas and later to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, raised in Anaheim, California, and as a child developed both a fascination with the ocean and an interest in art.

Mendicant lifestyles are embraced by various religious traditions—Catholicism, Hinduism, Sufi Islam, Jainism and Buddhism—where practitioners rely on alms and ascetic discipline. A monk (from Greek monachos, “solitary,” and Latin monachus) is someone who adopts monastic living, alone or in community, dedicating life either to serving all beings or to withdrawing from society into prayer and contemplation.
The Mod Squad was an American crime drama series broadcast on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American film that blends science fantasy, western, action, and horror elements, and is directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is a southwestern U.S. state, the sixth largest and 14th most populous of the 50 states, admitted as the 48th and last of the contiguous states on February 14, 1912. Approximately one-quarter of its land is designated Indian reservations, home to 27 federally recognized tribes—including the Navajo Nation, the largest tribe in both Arizona and the United States with over 300,000 citizens—and the state is noted for its high population of Native Americans.
Smriti Mandhana, born on 18 July 1996, is an Indian cricketer who represents the Indian women’s cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson (born 15 April 1990) is a French-British actress, model and activist who was born in Paris, raised in Oxfordshire, attended the Dragon School and trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s after earning a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University and a Master of Fine Arts degree from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA’s highest award, conferred by the President in Congress’s name upon recommendation of the NASA Administrator, and is presented to astronauts who achieve extraordinary accomplishments during space flight under NASA’s authority; among its recipients is Frank Frederick Borman II (born March 14, 1928), a retired U.S. Air Force colonel.
The Saw film franchise’s installments have collectively grossed over $873 million at the worldwide box office.
Down with Love is a romantic comedy film released in 2003.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for portraying Joe Wicks in BBC’s EastEnders and DS Sam Casey in ITV’s Law & Order: UK.
Colombiana is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was a member of the main cast of Netflix’s original series Marco Polo until it was cancelled on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal production, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco farming, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Boyhood, filmed over 12 years (2002–2013), follows Mason Evans Jr.’s growth from age six to eighteen as he navigates childhood and adolescence in Texas with divorced parents.
Hush is a 2016 film produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and by Jason Blum under his Blumhouse Productions banner.
The Penibaetic System, also called Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain ranges that make up the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a men’s apparel brand offering a full range of suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear and accessories, while Topman, part of the Arcadia Group (which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans and Dorothy Perkins), operates a chain of high-street men’s clothing stores across the United Kingdom and in six main-street locations in Ireland.
“Roar” is a song by American singer Katy Perry from her fourth studio album, Prism, released as the album’s lead single on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, also known as Saturn LLC, is a subsidiary of General Motors established as a registered trademark on January 7, 1985.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, refers to the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of approximately 1.5 million Armenians—mostly Ottoman citizens—beginning in 1915 under the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey, which today rejects the term “genocide” to describe these mass killings.

Muslims believe the Quran was revealed verbally by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over about 23 years, starting on 22 December 609 CE, when Muhammad was 40, and ending in 632 CE, the year of his death.

The human brain, together with the spinal cord, forms the central nervous system and is divided into the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum; the cerebrum is the largest region. Beneath its cerebral cortex lie several key structures—including the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and subthalamus—alongside limbic system components (the amygdala and hippocampus), the claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and the three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy-drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is a U.S. family-oriented television network that offers a diverse lineup of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to shows, hunting and fishing content, children’s shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001) was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman ever; even after retiring from Test cricket over 50 years earlier he remained a national icon whose advice was sought despite his reclusiveness, and in 2001 Prime Minister John Howard called him “the greatest living Australian.”

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher (13 October 1925 – 8 April 2013), was a British stateswoman who served as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990—becoming the first woman to lead a major UK political party after defeating Edward Heath in the 1975 leadership contest—and as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990, making her the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold that office.

Randy Mario Poffo (November 15, 1952 – May 20, 2011), better known as “Macho Man” Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator best known for his tenures in the World Wrestling Federation (now WWE) and later World Championship Wrestling.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor whose career has spanned more than fifty years.

EA Black Box, originally Black Box Games, was a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees and later acquired by Electronic Arts.

Baiae was an ancient mineral springs and coastal resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples in Italy; nearby, the Roman town of Herculaneum, buried by Vesuvius’s 79 AD pyroclastic flows, lies today in the commune of Ercolano, Campania. Around Naples one also finds the Palace of Caserta and the ruins of Pompeii, and globally there exist famous archaeological sites from ancient China, the Indus Valley, Judea, Greece, Egypt, Rome, Zimbabwe, the Inca and the Maya.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in the 1980 West Texas desert, starring Tommy Lee Jones as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell alongside Javier Bardem and Josh Brolin, and follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran caught up in a deadly pursuit.

Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, in the San Francisco Bay Area; its name—derived from the Spanish words palo (“stick” or colloquially “tree”) and alto (“tall”)—means “tall tree.”

Albert Lawrence Brooks (born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22, 1947) is an American actor, filmmaker, author and comedian. The film Finding Dory was directed by Andrew Stanton with Angus MacLane as co-director, and its screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text as a series of on-off tones, lights or clicks understandable by a skilled listener without special equipment, with shorter signals assigned to more common English characters to speed communication; it remains more robust than voice in poor signal conditions, is still used (e.g., by amateur radio repeaters), and can be improvised in emergencies, making it a simple, versatile telecommunications method.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born on March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 UTC with a magnitude of 6.5; the quake occurred in the Hindu Kush, an 800 km mountain range spanning from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan (near the Afghan–Pakistan border) that features numerous snow-capped peaks and whose highest point is Tirich Mir (7,708 m) in Pakistan’s Chitral District.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had a student body of about 840 in 2015, with most students residing on campus.

Fox Sports is the brand name for various sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming and other media worldwide that are wholly or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch’s family. Murdoch served as Chairman and CEO of the global media holding company News Corporation—now the world’s second-largest media conglomerate—and, following its 28 June 2013 split, its successors News Corp and 21st Century Fox. Both companies remain owned by Murdoch and his family through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US‐based women’s apparel company specializing in tomboy‐style clothing.
Bessie Smith (April 15, 1894–September 26, 1937) was an American blues singer.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that draws on linguistics, computer science and electrical engineering to develop methods and technologies for converting spoken language into text.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and deceased on 1 December 1947, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist and mountaineer.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that debuted on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, released on 20 October 1995, stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol and was filmed in India, London and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth (born 14 May 1961) is an English actor and director, while Tim Roth (born 6 December 1975) is the guitarist, backing vocalist and sole remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O’Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn made his film debut in Taps (1981) and appeared in diverse 1980s roles such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982) before earning critical notice in crime dramas At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). He emerged as a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), which brought him his first Academy Award nomination and the Berlin Film Festival’s Best Actor Award. He earned further Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001) and went on to win Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008). His fourth directorial feature, Into the Wild (2007), received critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

Volcanic outgassing likely produced Earth’s original atmosphere—largely oxygen-free and inhospitable to modern life—and its early oceans; as the planet cooled, a solid crust formed and liquid water persisted at the surface. Since then, plate tectonics has continually reshaped continents, oceans and the species they support, while more recent human-driven changes in the biosphere have significantly affected atmospheric composition (ozone layer integrity and greenhouse gas levels) as well as soil health, air quality and water purity. Today, water covers 71 % of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk, also known by its Danish name Godthåb, is the capital and largest city of both Greenland and the Sermersooq municipality.

How to Train Your Dragon 2 is written and directed by Dean DeBlois and features returning voice actors Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, with new additions Cate Blanchett as Valka, Djimon Hounsou as Drago, and Kit Harington.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson and David Hyde Pierce; it pastiches the late-1950s and early-1960s sex comedies exemplified by Doris Day and Rock Hudson’s Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961) and Send Me No Flowers (1964). A separate Taiwanese TV series titled Down with Love aired on free-to-air China Television (CTV) from 31 January to 23 May 2010 (Sundays 22:00–23:30) and on cable Gala Television (GTV) Variety Show/CH 28 from 2 February to 30 May 2010 (Sundays 20:00–21:30).
The album Paris by Paris Hilton incorporates elements of reggae, soul and pop rock in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy, and featuring early film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, Judge Reinhold, Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint Wondaland Arts Society and to Atlantic Records.

Jewell is an American singer best known for her song “Love or Lust,” which was featured in Bill Duke’s film Deep Cover, and for performing choruses on classic West Coast rap tracks such as Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi enrolls about 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent of its total student body from Mississippi, has a minority representation of 23 percent, and hosts international students from 90 countries.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy played Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014, co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime dark comedy-drama Unreal in 2015, and currently stars as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren (December 5, 1782–July 24, 1862) was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States (1837–1841). A leading figure in the Democratic Party, he held senior roles under Andrew Jackson as tenth Secretary of State (1829–1831) and eighth Vice President (1833–1837). Van Buren organized and supported Jackson’s successful 1828 campaign, briefly served as Governor of New York to boost Jackson’s popularity, then resigned to become Secretary of State. After aiding Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair, he received a recess appointment as American minister to Britain in 1831.
Camden, New Jersey, is home to Rutgers University–Camden, originally established as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and to the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a Great Lakes and Midwestern U.S. state that ranks tenth in population and 11th in total area (the largest east of the Mississippi River). It uniquely comprises two peninsulas, making it a top destination for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionised 1930s publishing by offering high-quality fiction and non-fiction in inexpensive sixpence paperbacks sold through Woolworths and other high-street stores, thereby bringing affordable literature to the mass market.
The 2008 film Australia was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist who helped popularize country music globally. Excuse My French is both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his own experiences at a public middle school after returning from Saudi Arabia; the film’s script was deemed too sensitive by Egypt’s censorship board, forcing Salama to revise it while retaining its focus on religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 South Korean–American independent dance film Make Your Move, which was inspired by Romeo and Juliet.

“Bad Romance” is a song by American singer Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster; after its demo was leaked, she debuted the finished track at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show that October and released its cover art soon after. The single topped charts worldwide and sold 12 million copies, making it one of the best-selling singles ever. Separately, Bad Romance (French title Les Mauvais Romans) is the title of a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including the Shrek franchise and its Puss in Boots prequel-spinoff, the Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon and Trolls series, as well as standalone hits like Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013) and Home (2015). Additionally, Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks (born 8 August 1966), known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Christopher Livingstone “Chris” Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989), is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016, and as of May 2017 is ranked fifth best super-middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist best known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and, following News Corporation’s split on June 28, 2013, continued to hold full control as chairman and CEO of its successors—News Corp and 21st Century Fox—making it the world’s second-largest media conglomerate; his younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch (born December 13, 1972), is an Australian-British-American businessman serving as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was Israel’s second highest-earning actress/model behind Bar Refaeli—surpassing Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka—with most of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, commonly known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are bony growths on the heel that are typically identified through radiographic examination, commonly known as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield is a vast area in south Wales, notably the South Wales Valleys, characterized by abundant coal deposits.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental club football competition organized by CONCACAF for top teams from North America, Central America, and the Caribbean; it began in 1962 under the name CONCACAF Champions’ Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 upon King George V’s death and her son Edward’s accession, only to witness Edward’s abdication that same year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son, Albert, who reigned as George VI until his death in 1952. Mary herself died in 1953 during the early reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
Poseidon is a film that had a production budget of $160 million and earned $181,674,817 at the worldwide box office.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was introduced in 1996, and Omar Epps and Joe Morton share the record for the most wins, each having won three times.

Human trafficking involves trading people—primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery or commercial sexual exploitation—and in 2014 forced labor alone generated about $150 billion in profits; of the 20.9 million victims worldwide, 14.2 million (68 %) endured labor exploitation, 4.5 million (22 %) were sexually exploited and 2.2 million (10 %) were subjected to state-imposed forced labor.
The animated film Rio premiered in 2011, and its sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I refers here to two rulers: Franz Stefan (1708–1765), Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany whose wife effectively held real power, and François I (1494–1547), the first French king from the Angoulême branch of Valois who reigned from 1515 until his death. The latter, nicknamed “Francis of the Large Nose,” the Grand Colas and the Roi-Chevalier, personally waged war against his rival Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, and—after failing to defeat him outright—sealed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent; he also fought Charles V in the Italian War of 1536–1538.

Peking University (PKU), colloquially Běidà (北大), is a major research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Taixue (Guozijian or Imperial Academy), it initially served as China’s highest educational administration (ministry of education). Today, PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was renowned for his friendly mutton chop sideburns, his gravelly voice, and his distinctive style of bass playing.
Global warming poses significant risks to humans by reducing crop yields, which threatens food security, and by causing sea levels to rise, which can force populations to abandon affected areas.
Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British epic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick (born June 26, 1980) is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide range of oral traditions and practices, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore and superstitions, as well as traditional food‐making and craft‐making.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films noted for being both informative and entertaining, and it also created instructional films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones, the author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel From Here to Eternity, which was swiftly adapted into a major film and later a television series; James Jones, the basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior to earn Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors, has won three NBA championships (two with the Miami Heat, one with the Cleveland Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals seven straight years alongside LeBron James by 2017, finished third in the league in three-point percentage in 2007–08, and won the 2011 Three-Point Contest.
In 1999, the American Film Institute named Humphrey Bogart the greatest male star of classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the technique for producing animated images, and Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy TV series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced in 2009 that he would resign from WWE, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981—the longest tenure of any actor in that role—and for narrating the comedy series Little Britain; beyond on-screen work, he has also lent his voice to commercials, video games, audiobooks and other television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site not only undergoes a major cleanup project but also hosts the Columbia Generating Station commercial nuclear power plant and key research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed and removable at the president’s pleasure who serves as the executive branch’s spokesperson—particularly on the president, senior leaders, and policy—and, despite not requiring Senate confirmation, holds a high-profile non-Cabinet role due to frequent media briefings.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” for the fertile pastures of bluegrass, features the central Bluegrass Region home to Louisville and Lexington and is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds and Kelly Preston, who also appeared in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert (born March 1, 1987), formerly stylized as Ke $ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two new versions of “Despacito” were released: an electronic rendition produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance and later World Championship Wrestling, initially airing on closed-circuit television and, beginning in 1987, becoming the first NWA event broadcast via pay-per-view after the WWF’s Survivor Series secured Thanksgiving exclusivity; in 2014 the WWE Network added the 1983–1986 closed-circuit Starrcades to its PPV library and rated them TV-MA for violence, notably the “I Quit” match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A., and Starrcade 1997 marked the fifteenth annual PPV edition.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director working in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created specifically for that service and marks the first new Star Trek show since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers and Washington Redskins, and also competed in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana; Excuse My French is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, inspired by his own experiences at a public middle school after returning from Saudi Arabia; and Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (born 22 October 1983), known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director and producer.
A floppy disk is a disk storage medium consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a rectangular plastic shell lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala endured chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, then from 1960 to 1996 suffered a bloody civil war between a US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres of the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects; outside of medical contexts, they are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, following its sixth season as cable’s highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the fictional protagonist of Lost, an American drama series that aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with its first season averaging about 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who, since 2011, has focused on dramatic roles in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees and Free State of Jones; the 2012 film Mud also stars Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer renowned for his book Deep Blues, his music journalism in The New York Times and Rolling Stone, his production of blues recordings and the Deep Blues film soundtrack, and his clarinet performances with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author and engineer who is best known for taking over leadership of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial project in March 1941, following the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, who had designed the sculpture and overseen its execution from 1927 to 1941 with Lincoln’s assistance.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams; it stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series about a group of nine teenagers—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy and Wells Jaha—sent from their space habitat, the Ark, back to Earth after a devastating nuclear apocalypse; it also follows Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke’s mother), Marcus Kane (an Ark council member) and Thelonious Jaha (the Ark’s Chancellor and Wells’s father).

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite facing financial difficulties due to its groundbreaking scope, became a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid event that generated significant awareness and funds and offered valuable lessons and inspiration for later projects such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is an influential Indian filmmaker credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and reshaping the profile of Indian cinema.

Stephen A. Douglas’s Freeport Doctrine, asserting that territories could effectively exclude slavery through local legislation, was presented at the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates—seven in all—pitted Republican Abraham Lincoln against Democratic incumbent Stephen Douglas in their contest for the U.S. Senate seat from Illinois. The gatherings in Freeport, Quincy and Alton attracted particularly large, multistate audiences due to the national significance of the slavery issue.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and featuring an ensemble cast that includes Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O’Brien on October 4, 1941) is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She launched her writing career in California with the 1976 publication of Interview with the Vampire and followed it with sequels throughout the 1980s. Although her early work received mixed reviews, she gained critical acclaim and a growing readership during that decade. Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 Census population of 77,344, making it the state’s 12th most populous municipality; at the start of the twentieth century, its residents were predominantly European immigrants, and a city is defined as a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the original screenplay for the critically derided 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, known as the Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven public debates in Illinois between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for U.S. Senate, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas.

Homer is the name the ancient Greeks gave to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two foundational epic poems of ancient Greek literature, and The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American writer Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece rock band formed by Soundgarden’s lead singer and rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell alongside Rage Against the Machine’s Tom Morello on lead guitar, Tim Commerford on bass and backing vocals, and Brad Wilk on drums. Brad Wilk, who began drumming for Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991, played in Rage from 1991–2000 and 2007–2011, joined Audioslave from 2001–2007, and by 2016 was drumming in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine itself, formed in 1991, comprised vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist and backing vocalist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records; in 2010 she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid—a concept-album sequel to her debut EP—through Bad Boy Records.
Winter’s Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. The University of Mississippi enrolls about 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of its total student body from Mississippi, with 23% of students identifying as minorities and international students representing 90 countries.
Flaked was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served two terms in the New York State Assembly (1784–85, 1798–99), was New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791, represented New York as a U.S. Senator from 1791 to 1797, and reached the apex of his career as Vice President.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet human spaceflight program. Originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar effort, it succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was first launched with eight unmanned test flights before carrying out the first 19 crewed missions. Commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft, the program—named after the Russian word for “Union” as in Soviet Union—remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded in 2000 after vocalist Zack de la Rocha quit due to creative tensions; the remaining members then joined Chris Cornell to form Audioslave, which released three albums before splitting in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited at Coachella after a seven-year hiatus. Their fourth studio album, Renegades, had been released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float, market-weighted index tracking 30 well-established, financially sound companies on the Bombay Stock Exchange; among its constituents is Tata Motors, which is listed on the BSE, the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with about 92.7 million people, making it the world’s 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous in Asia. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has sustained one of the world’s highest economic growth rates and in 2011 topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. It is one of only four remaining one-party socialist states officially committed to communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film marking John Gatins’s directorial debut, which he both wrote and directed.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic acts of violence against the British in India and subsequent execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became even more popular after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film Dangal, directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) became King of Scotland as James VI in July 1567 and, upon the union of the Scottish and English crowns in March 1603, King of England and Ireland as James I, ruling the three kingdoms in a personal union while each remained a separate sovereign state with its own parliament, judiciary and laws; he strongly supported creating a single parliament for England and Scotland but encountered significant conflicts with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress best known for originating a core role on the soap opera Shortland Street and for her television roles as the Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her film work includes the 2009 movie Separation City and the Australian series Rake, and she gained widespread acclaim for portraying Bea Smith on the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, a role she held for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer renowned for his extensive collaborations with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade has starred or co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups and Grown Ups 2; Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales—Lady Gaga’s second consecutive US number-one—and selling 757,000 copies in that period; it ended 2013 as the ninth best-selling album worldwide with 2.3 million copies sold.

John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006 and remained the last to feature him before he confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and introduced a set of economic and political policies known collectively as Thatcherism; her tenure remains controversial, with supporters hailing her as one of Britain’s most influential leaders while debates over the merits and impacts of Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who, beyond his musical career, has written weekly columns on diverse topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, beyond his acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous Valencian Community in Spain and, with about 800,000 residents in its city proper and between 1.7 and 2.5 million in its metropolitan area, ranks as the country’s third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film adaptation and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It concluded with its third and final season after an April 26, 2012 announcement, and its series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics combining linguistics, computer science and electrical engineering to enable computers to convert spoken language into text. Its applications range from voice user interfaces—such as voice dialing, call routing, home automation control and direct voice input for aircraft—to search, data entry, structured‐document preparation and speech‐to‐text processing in word processors or emails. Recent advances are marked by a surge in academic research and the widespread adoption of deep learning methods by industry leaders—Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek and CDAC—which attribute their core speech recognition technologies to deep learning.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 — January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970—later known as the San Diego Comic–Con International—alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and served as its chairman beginning that year.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France’s Matthieu Dubuisson shot a 67 to join South Africa’s George Coetzee van Zyl atop the leaderboard at 16 under par, while Rory McIlroy carded his third straight 67 to move to 15 under alongside Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy’s round featured an eagle at the 12th and came after he’d dropped shots at the third and 10th holes, the latter causing him to fling his putter in frustration. The world number three, who suffered a left ankle ligament rupture in July, returned to competition in August and is now chasing his first title since May as well as a third Race to Dubai crown, leading Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events left. England’s Chris Wood (–13) and Richard Bland (–12), tied for second overnight, sit in fifth and seventh place, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman argues that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and to appoint a clear interlocutor for the royal family, pointing to reformist Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa in contrast with hardliners led by the long-serving Prime Minister. He and six opposition societies have agreed to talks which he insists are both welcome and necessary, despite widespread youth disillusionment and a history—most notably a seven-point reform plan scrapped when Gulf troops intervened in March 2011—that has undermined trust. He calls on the United States under Secretary of State John Kerry to press more forcefully for human rights and democracy, and on the UK government to publicly demand an end to violence, rather than continue private appeals. Al-Wefaq will persist in peaceful demonstrations despite a ban on public gatherings, and Salman demands the release of 13 opposition leaders jailed on torture-tainted evidence, warning that their exclusion will doom any dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, founder and long-time director of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), died in Cambridge after a months-long illness; his private funeral will be followed by a public memorial. A leading figure in the early-music movement, he led the AAM for some 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 period-instrument recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle—and acclaimed versions such as the 1980 Handel’s Messiah. Trained in keyboard at Cambridge and under masters like Gustav Leonhardt, he began with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and co-founded the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director for the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel & Haydn Society, tutored at Harvard, held professorships at Cambridge and Cornell, and was praised by colleagues and artists—among them Emma Kirkby and Richard Egarr—for his generosity, scholarship and dedication to historically informed performance.

In the year to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicides—the lowest annual total since 1976 and half the number seen nine years earlier—with only one case unresolved, down from 62 after revisions to 2014-15 figures; sharp instruments, almost always knives, accounted for 51% of killings, and 31% of accused individuals were reported under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the long-term decline but stressed the need for continued education, enforcement and cross-sector support to curb violent crime and alcohol misuse, while Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned that past figures have been revised upward and noted rising sexual offenses and a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth suffered a 2-1 defeat at Sunderland—the Black Cats’ first Premier League win at home this season—despite Dan Gosling’s opener, their first goal in three matches. Manager Eddie Howe lamented his side’s profligacy in front of goal, pointing out that they had created enough chances to win multiple games but failed to capitalize even after Sunderland went down to ten men following Steven Pienaar’s red card. Sunderland’s victory was sealed by goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, leaving Howe to emphasize the importance of bouncing back.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended Australia’s policy of detaining and offshore-processing boat-borne migrants—“stop the boats”—as the only way to prevent deaths at sea, a stance the New York Times called “brutal,” “inhumane” and legally questionable in an editorial warning Europeans against adopting similar measures. While Abbott described the image of drowned Syrian toddler Alan Kurdi as “very sad,” he reiterated that halting illegal boats had ended drownings. Separately, Abbott sparked ire from Australian Jewish groups by asserting that IS’s shameless boasting of atrocities made it worse than the Nazis; the Executive Council of Australian Jewry rebuked the comparison as injudicious and noted the Holocaust’s systematic, state-implemented genocide, but Abbott stood by his remarks while disclaiming any intent to “rank evil.”

Washington has suspended its participation in bilateral ceasefire talks with Russia, blaming Moscow and the Syrian regime for renewed heavy bombardment of Aleppo—Syria’s largest northern city—since the truce collapsed two weeks ago, including strikes on the main trauma hospital in rebel-held eastern districts and a deadly attack on a humanitarian aid convoy. State Department spokesman John Kirby said Russia breached its own commitments and failed to ensure Assad’s forces respected the cessation of hostilities or allowed aid to reach civilians, with some 250,000 people trapped in the city. Russia, which denies conducting the aid‐convoy strike, expressed regret at the US decision, accused Washington of not fulfilling its humanitarian obligations around Aleppo, and criticized American efforts to distinguish moderate opposition from jihadists. Though the US withdrew personnel meant for a joint implementation center in Geneva, both sides agreed to continue coordination on counter-terrorism to prevent clashes.

The Policy Exchange report endorsed by Downing Street proposes selling vacant high-value social homes—defined as those worth more than the regional average and accounting for 21.8% (816,000) of the UK’s 3.78 million social dwellings—to raise up to £5.5 billion annually (net £4.5 billion after debt servicing), which it claims could fund the construction of 80,000–170,000 new social homes—potentially the largest such programme since the 1970s—and reduce the 1.8 million-strong housing waiting list by about 500,000. The government says councils already have this power and should use it to invest in more social housing, while critics—including Labour and the National Housing Federation—warn that forcing sales would break up mixed communities, push low-income families into new ghettos and worsen segregation. Shadow ministers instead advocate funding affordable homes via a bank bonus tax, and Housing Minister Grant Shapps highlights a £19.5 billion affordable housing programme and new fixed-term tenancies to target those in greatest need.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his Swansea home amid a measles outbreak that has reached 942 cases, though an examination could not confirm measles as the primary cause and an inquest has been opened and adjourned pending further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams, recently treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital, developed a full-body rash (excluding his arms) a few days after discharge, saw an out-of-hours GP on April 17, and was found dead the next morning. Public Health Wales confirmed measles in laboratory tests but is awaiting further results to establish the cause of death, and the family—whose three-year-old daughter is vaccinated—do not know how he contracted the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16 reported to have occurred in 2001; he is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court later.

Neil Aspin’s Gateshead, winless in nine National League matches, drew 1-1 at home with Adam Lockwood’s Guiseley, who arrived unbeaten in five, after Jake Lawlor gave the visitors the lead on 15 minutes following a James Hurst throw-in. Gateshead defender Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston’s follow-up and keeper Jonny Maxted saved Wesley York’s effort before half-time. Early in the second half Gateshead levelled on 62 minutes when a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah allowed York to curl into the top corner. Simon Walton and Gus Mafuta were booked, and the game saw Guiseley substitutions Michael Rankine for Jordan Preston, Derek Asamoah for Kevan Hurst and Adam Boyes for Jake Cassidy, plus Gateshead’s Luke Hannant replacing Mafuta.

Bristol Sport Ltd, led by majority shareholder Steve Lansdown, plans to replace two stands at its existing football ground—instead of moving to a stalled Ashton Vale site—to boost capacity; following Bristol City Council’s November approval, the club will sign a Section 106 agreement imminently, observe a six-week judicial review window, and, if unchallenged by March, commence redevelopment in May.

Cuadrilla has paused its Lancashire fracking operations after a magnitude-1.5 tremor struck near Poulton-le-Fylde—the second seismic event in two months—and will review British Geological Survey (BGS) data before deciding whether to resume. The BGS, which also monitors fracking activity, noted the April 1 tremor shared a “similar location and mechanism” with a magnitude-2.3 quake earlier in the month and occurred about 2 km from the Preese Hall drill site at roughly 2 km depth. Cuadrilla’s chief executive, Mark Miller, said the halt allows time to share information with authorities and experts, a process expected to take weeks. Fracking—where high-pressure fluids or small explosions fracture underground shale to release gas—has drawn US environmental criticism over potential groundwater contamination, but a recent Commons energy select committee report urged UK ministers to back shale gas under strict regulation and industry best practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting donations; he was cleared of two other counts. Carpenter, who typically performs in full regalia and has piped for the charity before, insisted on this occasion he was merely busking and that the banner—a design approved by campaign chairman Kenneth Derbyshire featuring the eternal flame and the word “justice”—was intended solely as a tribute to the victims, not a fundraising tool. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3–0 at Portman Road as Grant Ward opened the scoring with a close-range finish before Luke Varney capitalized on a miscleared clearance by QPR keeper Alex Smithies and Tom Lawrence sealed the win with a composed long-range strike; Ipswich, who had failed to score in seven of their previous ten Championship games, dominated proceedings with several other chances saved or missed, while QPR rarely threatened despite a late Sandro header hitting the post. The victory lifted Mick McCarthy’s side to 14th place—above Ian Holloway’s Rangers, who slipped to 15th—and prompted McCarthy to praise his team’s grit and Varney’s influence, whereas Holloway lamented defensive lapses and called for greater mental toughness.

Sam Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66 in last season’s T20 Blast, and he believes his club is heading in the right direction under coaches who have fostered an elite-performance environment that players are eager to join.

The Reds, sitting fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor for their second consecutive win, with front-row leaders Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams making more than 70 tackles to spark the effort; despite the emotionally dogged performance, coach Churcher stressed it wasn’t complete and urged the squad to build on it as they prepare to face seven teams below them and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight fixtures.

The police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul—also called Nazu and believed to be a Bangladeshi citizen—raped a 74-year-old nun during a March 14 attack on a convent in Ranaghat, in which money was stolen and the building ransacked. Outrage over the crime sparked street protests across India. After five previously arrested suspects identified Nazrul as the rapist, he was traced—via CCTV footage and a tip-off—to a Kolkata railway station and taken into custody, marking the sixth arrest in a case that has eight named suspects, two of whom remain untraced.

An interactive video presented by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, examines how innovations like the domestic freezer, washing powder and cheaper imports have reshaped UK consumer purchases, and also investigates shifts in ownership and rankings of Britain’s major brands; a non-interactive version and related resources—including information on Chinese brand ownership, freezing food tips, the BBC Good Food survey of the UK’s top 20 consumer brands and the Museum of Brands’ own materials—are provided via links below.

A 71-year-old Sandyhills woman and, a week later, a Stranraer woman were each defrauded by callers falsely claiming to be BT technical support, gaining remote access to their computers and stealing substantial sums of money; police warn against accepting unsolicited tech-support calls or disclosing banking details over the phone, stressing that legitimate banks and businesses never request such information.

Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to sign a one-year contract as head coach of third-placed Championship side Featherstone, where the Scotland assistant coach will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the Super 8 Qualifiers; chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s work at Swinton under difficult circumstances, while former assistant Stuart Littler has succeeded him there, and Duffy’s own playing career spanned 16 years with Leigh, Widnes and Salford.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday, where they found an unconscious rider with head injuries and hypothermia from lying on wet sand; after treatment on scene she was airlifted to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

Representatives from over 160 countries at the UN’s World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva agreed to allocate a radio frequency for satellite-based automatic dependent surveillance–broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions to enable real-time global flight tracking, addressing gaps that left about 70% of airspace unmonitored. This decision, driven by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in March 2014, will allow satellites to receive data previously limited to ground stations and other aircraft. The ITU’s Radiocommunication Bureau head, François Rancy, and Secretary-General Houlin Zhao praised the swift response to global concerns, while the International Civil Aviation Organization has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring position reports at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who vanished at age five and reappeared at 18 living with his father in Cleveland, was identified after a tip to the FBI on 30 October during his college application process; authorities, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed his identity and notified his mother. His father, 53-year-old Bobby Hernandez, was arrested in Ohio, charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012, and is held on $250,000 bail at Cuyahoga County Jail. Authorities had long suspected him in his son’s 2002 disappearance after he claimed to be taking Julian to preschool and then fled.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (whose site was managed by Asset and Land Group) from accepting waste and has revoked its environmental permit effective 7 August—pending any appeal—after joint visits with Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which found the operators “broadly compliant” with fire safety legislation despite earlier concerns about risks to residents, transport and the environment. The company must still remove all waste, and the cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has introduced two bills in the Duma tied to the Ukraine crisis: one would allow Russia to incorporate foreign territory when local leaders or referendums express the wish to join, bypassing the current treaty requirement, and the other would fast-track Russian citizenship for Ukrainians—eliminating state fees, residency, financial-means or citizenship-renunciation requirements and shortening the naturalization period from a year to two months—with its preamble invoking protection of Russian-speaking Ukrainians against a revived “brown threat.” A Just Russia leaders and allied MPs, joined by celebrities, have promoted these measures in Crimea, where many already hold Russian passports, especially in Sevastopol, home to Russia’s Black Sea Fleet.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most successful teams with 182 Grand Prix victories, 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ championships—including a near-perfect 1988 with Senna and Prost—has slipped into a deep slump since 2013 when chassis design faltered and its renewed Honda engine under-performed. After eras of dominance under Ron Dennis with Honda in the late ’80s and Mercedes in the late ’90s, McLaren endured high-profile scandals in 2007 (spying) and 2009 (“lie-gate”) and last won a constructors’ crown in 1998. Despite signing two-time champion Fernando Alonso in 2015 and improvements to the chassis, Honda’s power unit remains the weak link. Dennis insists the team is on the brink of recovery and will soon challenge Mercedes for titles again.

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool’s Old Swan on 27 January and later died in hospital. Merseyside Police believe the shooters waited about an hour for him to leave the gym, then sped off in a silver VW Polo that was tracked along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one 32, are in custody for questioning, and detectives are urging several people seen on nearby CCTV to come forward with any information.

The passage highlights five digital ways to celebrate a more spiritual Christmas: Everyday Church Online, launched in the UK, streams weekly virtual services—complete with chat-room “foyers,” Star Wars–themed sermons like “The Hope Awakens,” and global prayer requests—from attendees in 61 countries; Guardians of Ancora, a free fantasy game by Scripture Union for 8–11-year-olds, whose players recover Bible stories to restore light to the fictional world, now featuring two Christmas quests about Jesus’s birth; innovative nativity videos such as Viral.de’s 2010 “Digital Story of Nativity” told entirely through social-media updates (nearly six million views) and the Churches Advertising Network’s era-shifting “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” (about 250,000 views but barred from cinemas for being “too religious”); Next Manga’s Manga Messiah app and e-book offering Bible stories in Japanese cartoon form in 33 languages—with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to refugees; and widespread church use of Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to share brief spiritual reflections, reflecting a belief that “Jesus would definitely be on Twitter.”

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to use 250 hectares of common land, with supporters—including Blaenau Gwent council—offering roughly 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts disagree on whether building on the common would harm habitats and plants, and Natural Resources Wales has questioned the equivalence of the replacement land without opposing the project. Developers’ ecology reports claim a net biodiversity gain through habitat enhancements, a view challenged by Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation before Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a Novaya Gazeta report on 1 April alleging that more than 100 men had been detained, tortured and at least three killed in an anti-gay purge in Chechnya, calling it an insult and vowing “retribution” against those they deemed responsible; the paper, supported by the Russian LGBT Network’s confirmation of electric-shock and beatings near Grozny, defended its investigation and urged dialogue, while leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied any gay people existed in Chechnya, and the LGBT Network, alleging official inaction, says it is helping victims flee and may bring the case to the International Criminal Court.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency founded in 2002 by Samir Patel, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity he set up in 2010, have for two years been housing single homeless men over 35 by placing several unrelated tenants in one house and claiming housing benefit per person—often far exceeding the landlord’s rent—passing “the bulk” to private landlords and pocketing the difference, making the venture highly profitable (for example, claiming £2,114 a month for two tenants while the landlord received £1,150). Operating across seven London boroughs (with nearly half its funds from Wandsworth Council), the scheme exploits benefit rules that allow over-35s private rather than shared accommodation, charging up to £260 per week per room. Tenants like Nigel McCann report squalid conditions—no heating or hot water, rats, damp and heaps of rubbish—prompting criticism from homeless charities, while Patel insists Fresh Start is independent with its own trustees, that most rent goes to landlords, and expresses concern at specific allegations. A government spokeswoman says local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers’ money in private sector housing.

Great Britain’s basketball team, coached by Joe Prunty, led through much of their final warm-up match before Eurobasket qualifying but were overtaken by the Netherlands in the fourth quarter and lost despite a late rally. London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA veteran Ben Gordon added 13, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter, while Worthy De Jong led the Dutch with 18 points. Prunty praised Gordon’s contribution and stressed the need for consistent effort on both ends as GB prepare to begin their six-game qualifying campaign in Hungary.

The Nevada Athletic Commission received Conor McGregor’s waiver request hours before Wednesday’s deadline to allow 8oz gloves instead of the mandated 10oz for his August 26 boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather at 154 lbs, a move requiring public debate on August 16 under NAC rules designed to prioritize fighter safety. Mayweather had announced his intent to wear 8oz gloves on Instagram but only McGregor filed the necessary paperwork in time; NAC executive director Bob Bennett, after consulting experts and reviewing footage of McGregor’s sparring and Nate Diaz’s sessions, recommended approval based on McGregor’s punching power, durability, youth and stature, noting Mayweather’s long absence from knockout wins. Bennett also advised McGregor to hire a boxing referee, leading to the appointment of Joe Cortez, despite sparring tensions that saw Paulie Malignaggi depart McGregor’s camp amid disputes over training images.
