Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Dundee-based Sunday Post are the last journalists to leave Fleet Street, once the heart of Britain’s national newspapers since the Daily Courant launched there in 1702, and famously nicknamed the “Street of Shame.” In its heyday it was crowded with printing presses, smoke-filled newsrooms, typewriters, lively bars and a sense of journalistic camaraderie—complete with editors’ hidden drinks cabinets and all-male newsrooms broken only by a handful of women in places like the Piranha Pool. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch relocated his titles to Wapping, triggering a bitter dispute and accelerating the shift to cheaper computerized printing, after which buildings were repurposed—Mirror Group’s site becoming Sainsbury’s headquarters and Stab in the Back turning into a Pizza Express. Smith, Smith and former editor Robin Esser reflect on Fleet Street’s pivotal role when newspapers delivered 85 percent of the public’s information, and as they move on—to freelancing, memoir writing and beyond—they mark the end of an era that reshaped journalism and London alike.

J.K. Rowling said recent kind messages on Twitter have reminded her how many decent people there are, after she’d faced abusive comments—including being called “a traitor”—for donating £1 million to the Scottish independence “No” campaign (and the same amount to Labour in 2008). She wrote that her “personal line” had been crossed and that it isn’t always fun being a famous woman on Twitter, but she believes in standing up to bullies and refused to protect any party’s image. Rowling has blocked some abusive users she thought were SNP supporters, yet also engaged with other polite SNP followers with whom she shares political views, and even joked about bringing marshmallows after someone suggested her books be burned. Meanwhile, the SNP won 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats in the recent election, becoming the UK’s third-largest party.

University of Edinburgh researchers tracking 4,300 young people since 1998 found that poverty strongly increases both youth offending and victimization, with disadvantaged children twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as their wealthier peers and about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision; a prior police record was the strongest predictor of being outside education, employment or training by 18. Household poverty remained a significant risk factor for violence and crime even after accounting for truancy, substance abuse and poor parental supervision, and boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violence. Additional findings published in Scottish Justice Matters revealed that recent overall crime reductions in Scotland have not benefited the most deprived communities, where crime, unemployment and chronic health problems remain highly concentrated. Scottish government statements highlight record lows in overall crime and ongoing anti-poverty initiatives.

Mr Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee shortly after 1:00 a.m. on Sunday after an alleged confrontation involving Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, and at least two other men who had called at houses searching for Mr Haugh. During the fight, knives and golf clubs were used, and Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back; he was later pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 6:00 a.m. Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August, while two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge and files are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Phil Flanagan tweeted that Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, “harassed and shot” people during his ten-year service, but the High Court heard Elliott has a clear MoD record; Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour, agreed in court to post an apology acknowledging it was “untrue and wholly without foundation,” and judgment on compensation has been reserved, while an insurer has refused to cover Flanagan’s costs— a decision he is challenging—and Elliott, describing himself as “totally vindicated,” expressed disappointment at the delay in resolving the matter.

Hawick Knitwear, founded in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has raised its weekly sweater output from about 7,500 to 9,500 to meet strong demand for both its newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range (introduced in January) and its established private‐label business. Acquired last November by managing director Benny Hartop, the company supplies markets across Europe—including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain—as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan. Hartop attributes the surge in orders to dedicated staff at all levels and expresses confidence that the company’s success will continue.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady of 20 years’ service, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston when Brian Wright, 55, drove his VW Golf through a red light while blinded by the setting sun and struck her as she escorted a mother and child across the road; now in residential care, Mrs. Blackburn’s case is being tried at Luton Crown Court, where Wright has admitted hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, expressing remorse and attributing his actions to sun glare as the trial continues.

Nato’s “Dynamic Mongoose” exercise pits a German U-boat, U33, against ten allied warships led by the USS Vicksburg to rehearse anti-submarine warfare in response to increased Russian undersea activity, which has exposed gaps in Britain’s defences—most notably its lack of maritime patrol aircraft since retiring the Nimrod. Participating forces include frigates, helicopters, a French Atlantique patrol plane and, for the first time, underwater drones Harpo and Groucho from Nato’s research vessel, whose persistent, cost-effective surveillance complements ship- and air-borne sonar teams. Russia’s expanding, technologically advanced submarine fleet—around 60 vessels, including its newly launched “quietest submarine in the world”—poses a growing threat, capable of long, undetected patrols and of potentially monitoring the UK’s nuclear deterrent from Scottish waters. The exercise underlines the importance of allied cooperation and signals that Britain must address its maritime patrol shortfall in the upcoming defence review.

Since violence erupted in Juba in July and spread into the southern Equatoria states of South Sudan, an average of 2,500 people a day—340,000 in total—have fled ethnic killings, rapes and the targeting of civilians by Dinka soldiers against Equatorians and Nuer, crossing into Uganda via informal border points like Busia. Refugees describe men being hacked or shot, women raped, children beaten or killed; families walk for days through the bush to reach reception centres, where Uganda and aid agencies allocate each household 30 m² of land and basic shelter within 36 hours, allowing them to plant crops. Settlements such as Bidi Bidi have swelled from a village of a few hundred to over 250 km² housing more than 250,000 people, while Uganda’s generous policy is straining resources—particularly water supply—and compelling schools to expand rapidly to educate a refugee population half of whom are children. UNHCR officials warn the world to press South Sudan’s leaders to halt what they call a massacre of civilians.

McKenzie, 38, who gave up football in 2011 and turned professional in 2013, holds an 8-0-1 record in nine bouts and will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title; he is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition has allocated part of its £330 million NHS facilities fund to build a new Bridgwater Community Hospital at a cost of £33 million, with the remainder covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust; the facility will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery‐led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray and mobile scanner space, and is planned for Bowers Lane pending planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014. The existing 1813 building is cramped, outdated and costly to maintain, prompting staff such as Matron Sue Taylor to praise the new design’s positive impact on patient well‐being. Over the past five years, three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and work has begun on Musgrove Park Hospital’s Jubilee Building. GP Dr Donal Hynes says the new hospital will enhance integrated one-stop care delivered by GPs, nurses and therapists.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, around 13:35 GMT while in or beside the black Mercedes he had been driving; armed officers sealed off the area and he was taken to Northern General hospital, where he died. Neighbours said he belonged to a family holding a celebration nearby and that relatives rushed out to assist after hearing the shot. Although Sheffield has seen several shootings in recent weeks, those incidents occurred in northern districts—Shiregreen (where a 25-year-old was seriously injured on Monday), Southey Green (where shots were fired through an elderly couple’s window in what police suspect was mistaken identity) and High Green (where houses were shot at twice in January).

Three main independent hacktivist groups—Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut and Anonymous International—have waged a digital campaign around the Ukraine–Russia conflict. Led by Yevhen Dokukin, the Ukrainian Cyber Troops have used DDoS attacks, hijacked CCTV cameras and network printers, and exfiltrated data from Russian interior ministry servers to reveal evidence of wounded soldiers evacuated to Russia. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western outfit, has defaced Ukrainian government sites, disrupted electronic vote counts, leaked defence-ministry data, hacked billboards with anti-Ukrainian propaganda and claimed to have exposed confidential documents from US and Ukrainian officials. Anonymous International (aka b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay) leaks Kremlin and rebel-related communications—some from Russia’s FSB—though its hacking methods remain unclear.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears by veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil’s powerful farewell speech, in which he urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster on accountability, scrutiny and opposition, and warned of the consequences if it failed to do so. She was again emotional after Alex Salmond—first minister from 2007 to 2014—delivered his valedictory address, reiterating his belief that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” celebrating the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill while lamenting unfulfilled unionist pledges, and quipping about competing with the UK budget and Cheltenham’s champion chase before bidding “goodbye… for now.” Salmond, McNeil and former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie—who joked she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “huge outbursts of faux indignation”—are all standing down ahead of the 5 May election.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering firsthand accounts from pensioners, their families and care staff to inform her review of residential care in Wales, aiming to develop recommendations for providers and public bodies that highlight both best practice and the harms of substandard care. Having travelled across Wales and received growing correspondence about inconsistent quality of life in care homes, she will assess residents’ physical and psychological health, social relationships and environment, and consult care providers, social care staff and public bodies to ensure accountability and drive improvements. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but has criticised the absence of any care-home practitioners or former residents on the advisory panel, warning that this omission undermines full partnership with the sector.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group reported a pre-tax profit rise of £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016 despite turnover dipping by £1 million to just over £100 million; international sales grew in Europe and new markets, while its Turriff operations supply feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry farmers and run 19 Country Store shops across Scotland offering fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. The company warned that agriculture remains hard to predict, cited challenging conditions over the past 12–18 months and noted that although the impact of Brexit is not yet clear, it believes it is well positioned to meet forthcoming business challenges.

The body of a man in his 70s was found on Saturday afternoon at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and another man in his 80s was taken to hospital; detectives from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire major crime unit are treating the death as murder and urgently want to speak to 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), described as a white male about 6 ft tall with greying collar-length hair, average build, and last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt; the public are urged not to approach him but to contact police or Crimestoppers, and additional patrols have been deployed in the area.

David Lipton, the IMF’s deputy managing director, warned that the fund’s most recent assessment shows the global economy weakening and that we are at a “delicate juncture,” citing a 25% year-on-year drop in Chinese exports and signaling a likely downgrade from its 3.4% global growth forecast when it updates projections in April, a slowdown with significant implications for businesses relying on China’s expansion.

Council leader Dave Stewart announced that crossings at Cowes will be free until July 2 to acknowledge ongoing issues with the new chain ferry and gather feedback, while an independent audit review has been ordered. Since its late-May launch, the ferry has suffered breakdowns, groundings and a suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and several cars were damaged boarding or disembarking. East Cowes shopkeeper Angie Booth warned local businesses have lost nearly six months of trade and asked about compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward confirmed is under discussion. Ward described the vessel as a prototype still facing teething problems—now resolved electrical faults, newly authorised ramp extensions to prevent scraping and corrected seamanship procedures to avoid groundings.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred around 07:30 GMT on Thursday on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an agency branding itself as “an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” has come under fire for job adverts specifying physical attributes—such as a personal assistant with “a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup” and a “sexy female driver” for a high-paying role—deemed unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the ads “appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women,” prompting a formal request for clarification of the agency’s hiring practices, while campaigners and lawyers warn that terms like “beautiful and attractive” covertly discriminate against older women and may invite sex-discrimination claims with unlimited compensation. Founder Nathalie Jansen defends clients’ demands—citing a polo-playing businessman’s Dior-designed “Jackie O” outfit and other examples—arguing looks matter for first impressions, even as the law prohibits discriminatory criteria based on age, sex, disability or other protected characteristics unless strictly job-relevant.

A shooting at the Pragati Residential School hostel in Bangalore saw office assistant Mahesh allegedly enter 18-year-old Gautami’s room on Tuesday evening and fatally shoot her in the head before wounding another student, Sirisha, who is now expected to survive; Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until April 12. School gun violence is extremely rare in India, which has strict firearms laws despite widespread use of guns in settling disputes, and the last campus shooting occurred in 2007 near Delhi, when two students killed a 14-year-old classmate.

Glaad’s “Where We Are on TV” report, covering scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series from June 2016 to May 2017, found 278 regular or recurring LGBT characters, including a rise in transgender representation from seven to 16, but noted that over 25 lesbian and bisexual women—including Poussey Washington in Orange Is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth—were killed off; it also recorded a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder, and while Glaad president Sarah Kate Ellis called the progress “heartening,” she cautioned that “numbers are only part of the story.”

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South since 2015, has withdrawn his candidacy ahead of a local party meeting where he faced deselection over his role in a controversial £10.25 million borough council loan to Northampton Town FC—made while he was council leader to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop adjacent land—that is now missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities; the stadium stand remains half built, Mackintosh denies any wrongdoing, and he says it is the right time for constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former Balch Springs police officer, was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon after firing a rifle into a car of teenagers leaving a house party in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; footage showed the vehicle was driving away, contradicting initial police claims that it had reversed aggressively. Oliver was dismissed for policy violations days after the shooting, remains free on bail, and faces 5 to 99 years if convicted—potentially becoming the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. No trial date has been set, and Dallas County District Attorney Faith Johnson affirmed that justice is proceeding, while Edwards family lawyer Lee Merritt noted the rarity of such convictions in Texas history.

The passage discusses Melania Trump’s decision to keep her son Barron in New York to finish the school year rather than immediately move into the White House—an arrangement that has drawn criticism on social media but is historically uncommon only twice (Martha Washington and Anna Harrison) and reflects prior concerns over children’s schooling under presidents Cleveland, Tyler and Madison. It notes that recent presidents’ families—Cleveland’s Franny, the Clintons’ Chelsea and the Obamas’ Malia and Sasha—either divided their residences or moved early to avoid midterm school changes, while emphasizing that the first lady’s role, though officially ceremonial, has grown to include public causes and shapes the president’s symbolic image. Mrs. Trump, who has long prioritized Barron’s well-being, is expected to take a less active public role than her predecessor but has hinted at focusing on cyber-bullying, and it remains possible that Ivanka Trump or other family members could assume traditional first-lady duties if needed.

A 72-year-old man died in a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October, prompting the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to instruct the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner to examine Police Scotland’s initial response to his call; Police Scotland says it is fully engaging with the investigation, and PIRC’s report will be submitted to COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning has been issued for the west of the mountains, where easterly gusts of up to 75 mph (120 km/h) could occur, increasing the winds’ impact and likely causing disruption to road and sea travel. The alert covers Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight gusts felled a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, blocking Telford Road—a key access route expected to remain closed through most of Monday for cleanup.

Player-coach Derrick Walser gave the Giants an early lead before Jeff Dimmen pulled the Panthers level; in the second period Mike Forney’s power-play breakaway made it 2–1 until Andy Bohmbach equalised, after which Mike Radja scored from an acute angle and James Desmarais added a fourth for the Panthers before Nottingham’s David Ling replied; the teams meet again Saturday, with Nottingham topping the league on 28 points, Sheffield Steelers second on 27 and Belfast third on 25.

Nico Rosberg won the Chinese Grand Prix after Daniel Ricciardo suffered an early puncture, while Lewis Hamilton started last, damaged his car in a first-lap collision and made five pit stops but could only climb to seventh, leaving him 36 points behind Rosberg with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel recovered from a collision with his Ferrari team-mate Kimi Räikkönen on lap one to finish second, Räikkönen fighting back to fifth behind Red Bull’s Daniil Kvyat and Ricciardo. The opening-lap chaos brought out a safety car, leading to strategic tyre changes—Ferrari’s switch to softs on the final stint helped Räikkönen overtake Hamilton—but Mercedes enjoyed clear air up front once Rosberg inherited the lead under the safety car restart on lap 9. Vettel and Kvyat traded words post-race over their own first-corner clash, while Hamilton lamented aero and suspension damage that hampered his comeback.

Thomas Hitzlsperger’s public revelation of his homosexuality—motivated by a desire to spark discussion in a football culture that has long ignored the issue—was hailed as both courageous and groundbreaking by teammates such as Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, by German Football Association figures like Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball, and by international voices including Gary Lineker, Joey Barton and John Amaechi. Bayern Munich and political leaders from Chancellor Merkel’s office to openly gay MP Volker Beck also praised the move. Seen as a watershed moment in confronting homophobia in German football, his announcement follows earlier controversy over Philipp Lahm’s advice to keep gay players closeted and builds on the 2007 coming-out of Marcus Urban, offering hope that greater openness will soon become the norm.

Craig Sidwell, 34, has featured in 32 Championship matches this season, helping Brighton earn promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at season’s end, the midfielder—who previously spent 19 games on loan at Brighton in 2015–16 before signing permanently in June 2016 and has Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke—hopes to secure a new deal, confident he can contribute to Brighton’s survival in the top flight. Sidwell, praised by manager Chris Hughton and instrumental in Brighton’s recent win over Wigan that sealed promotion, believes he’s outperformed expectations and looks forward to negotiating terms this summer.

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1-1 draw in a game in which Nathan Delfouneso’s 12th-minute chip set up Jamille Matt’s close-range finish for the Seasiders, only for Kurtis Guthrie to bundle in from a corner soon after. Both sides had gilt-edged chances—Sam Slocombe denied Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Tom Aldred headed wide from a late corner—but neither could find a winner, and Colchester were reduced to ten men when substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a late tackle on Jim McAlister.

The 29-year-old defender, who featured 37 times for the Sky Blues last season as they dropped out of League One and has previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, is set to make his U’s debut in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa; Colchester began their campaign with a 3-1 loss at Accrington on Saturday.

An attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March that killed PC Keith Palmer has accelerated plans by the UK Police Memorial Trust to build a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, bearing the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty. The £4 million project—of which the government has committed £1 million and the trust is seeking a further £1.5 million—will feature a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts presented to bereaved families as personal memorials. Chair Sir Hugh Orde and Home Secretary Amber Rudd emphasize the importance of providing a lasting national tribute honoring 250 years of police courage and sacrifice, with completion due in 2019.

Manchester United extended their lead atop the Premier League to 15 points with a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, marking their 25th win in 30 matches and 50 of a possible 54 points from their last 18 games. Sir Alex Ferguson said the team is focused solely on upcoming fixtures—starting with Sunday’s derby against Manchester City—while also aiming to surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record, with eight league games remaining. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson and goalkeeper David de Gea in the Sunderland match prompt changes for Monday’s FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, where rested players including Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez could return, pending Wayne Rooney’s recovery from fatigue.

Mr Schmidt told the BBC that Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011—exactly the legal requirement—and insisted that if the British government changed its tax laws, Google would comply by paying more or less accordingly. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new body to oversee major firms’ tax arrangements in private hearings to prevent companies hiding behind confidentiality. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, has faced criticism for minimising its UK tax bill. Last week EU leaders agreed to implement automatic information exchange between tax authorities to curb avoidance. Mr Schmidt has argued that corporate taxes should be levied where a company conducts economic activity and takes risks rather than where products are consumed, and called for politicians to engage in international tax reform to create clearer, simpler rules that reward companies abiding by the law.

NHS Improvement has reported that last year’s £3.6 billion agency staffing bill needs to be cut by £1 billion this financial year; an October cap limiting agency pay to no more than 55% above normal shift rates (excluding senior managers) has already saved £600 million but trusts remain 10% behind target. Agency staff cost more due to agency fees and employer contributions, and it is unclear whether savings on agency pay have been offset by higher spending on other pay categories or overtime. The regulator will publish performance “league tables” and data on the 20 highest-earning agency workers per trust amid evidence of excessively high quotes—up to £130 an hour for a surgeon versus the £76 cap and £70 for a junior doctor against a £35 cap—and NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey warns more action is needed.

Longford Town Centre, built during the Celtic Tiger era beside a fast‐flowing stream, fell silent after Ireland’s economic crash but is now showing signs of revival: family‐run menswear retailer Matt O’Brien reports a 30% post‐boom drop in sales that has recently begun to recover thanks to diversification into childrenswear and dress hire. Meanwhile Fianna Fáil’s local TD Robert Troy accuses the Fine Gael–Labour government and the IDA of neglect—pointing to a half‐billion-euro water-meter investment and four years without new industrial clients—while the government highlights Center Parcs’ planned €200 m tourism development in Ballymahon, which could employ about 1,000 people when it opens in 2019, as evidence of support. Fine Gael TD James Bannon champions the region’s waterways and scenery for tourism growth, though traders like O’Brien argue that policies such as on-street parking charges still hamper local business and call for further measures to sustain the nascent recovery.

The tournament features eight teams playing each other twice in a single stadium, concluding with a final on 29 May after two qualifiers and an eliminator to determine the four sides advancing to the play-offs; leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267) and De Villiers (249), with most sixes by Warner and De Villiers (12 each) and Kohli (8), highest individual innings of 108 by De Kock, and 90 not out by Warner and Gambhir, and top wicket-takers McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8) and Rahman (7); four England internationals—Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils) and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)—participate, and the full round-robin fixture list runs from 25 April to 22 May, with all matches at 15:30 BST unless otherwise noted.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reports that plastic carrier bag use in England has risen by 200 million since 2013, creating environmental problems as many bags cannot be recycled and end up in landfills or waterways. From October, a mandatory 5p charge for plastic bags will be introduced in England—following similar schemes in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland that have successfully reduced bag use—with the aim of encouraging reuse and cutting down on discarded bags.

Part of a school roof at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon was torn off and hundreds of homes in Wales lost power as gusty winds, under a yellow warning in force until midnight, caused train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges and cancellations of six Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, with passengers rerouted to cruise vessels. Arriva Trains Wales imposed speed restrictions and possible delays between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, and restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge were later lifted. Winds eased by Friday evening but blustery conditions prompted the postponement of Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan has signed on for Black Panther, reuniting with Creed director Ryan Coogler and expressing excitement about working alongside Lupita Nyong’o and Chadwick Boseman; Jordan—fresh from his Human Torch turn in last year’s Fantastic Four reboot—didn’t reveal his role, while Nyong’o, an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave, returns to the big screen after portraying Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther hits theaters in February 2018.

The 1875-built theatre, long unused but still featuring original decor and stage machinery, and the adjoining BBC studios will be repaired and refurbished as part of a £26.6 million east-wing restoration at Alexandra Palace to create a new cultural destination hosting theatre, cinema, comedy, live music and exhibitions in a glazed east court; funding comprises an £18.8 million Heritage Lottery Fund grant, £6.8 million from Haringey Council and a £1 million pledge from Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, with the theatre’s planned reopening in 2018.

Former Manchester City midfielder James Milner, 30, won 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, featuring in two World Cups and two European Championships—though he played just three minutes at Euro 2016—and has announced his departure from the squad as “a decision about common sense,” wishing Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success; he also holds the record for England Under-21 appearances with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith’s home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fast-spreading fire started when rubbish she’d burned in the wood stove ignited out of control; her son David, who was on FaceTime with his father and saw the flames first, woke the family in time for everyone to escape in their pajamas, though their dog and cats perished. The fire alarm failed to sound, and Mrs. Smith believes David’s quick actions saved her and her daughter. The community has since donated clothing, shoes and a bike for David, whom his mother praises as a hero she will thank for the rest of his life.

Reports indicated an energy drinks company was weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United, which co-owners David Sullivan and David Gold bought in 2010 for £105 million and now control over 85 percent of. Since the club’s move to London Stadium in August, Qatari and Chinese investors have also been linked with potential takeovers. Last year Sullivan suggested selling a minority stake to reduce debt but emphasized that he and Gold plan to hand ownership down to their children.

The red‐carpet event in Los Angeles, jokingly dubbed “definitely not the Oscars” by Jillian Bell, blended fan‐voted awards (such as best kiss and best shirtless performance) with promotional sneak peeks at summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars swept the night, winning best movie, best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss for Shailene Woodley, who dedicated her speech to author John Green. Bradley Cooper earned best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep was named best villain for Into the Woods; Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne also picked up awards. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award alongside his children, while Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award amid an Avengers tribute. The show closed with teasers for Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck and Marvel’s Ultron.

Smith, 21, a Scotland Under-21 international who made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and scored four goals in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side, was loaned by the Dons to Dundee United in July and has netted five times this season; St Mirren boss Jack Ross described him as a “very good, mature” player who adds attacking options, and his new club, bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has deployed its Jetpatcher machines to repair about 145 potholes daily over the next four months now that temperatures have risen, while additional crews will fix rain-damaged drainage systems and clear gutter debris.

Last December on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors led by rigging supervisor Steve Innes were exposed for hours to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while performing shutdown work on pipe equipment without proper PPE; although EnQuest reported the exposure—below 1% of the reportable threshold—to the HSE at the time and has since added precautionary measures, Innes says the company failed its duty of care and he now faces ongoing cancer concerns and difficulty finding work. EnQuest and Wood Group both emphasize their commitment to safety, noting medical assessments, joint investigations, and reinforced procedures, while Unite calls for greater transparency and the HSE, having deemed the incident non-reportable under RIDDOR, carried out no further inquiry.

The Asian Civilisation Museum purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later confessed to trafficking stolen Indian antiquities. Believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, the piece’s return was prompted by a May request from India’s Archaeological Survey of India and discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and the ASI. Although there is no definitive proof the sculpture was temple-stolen, ACM acknowledged the dealer’s admission of dealing in looted Indian artifacts and criminal possession of 150 stolen objects. The museum acquired 30 items from that dealer—only this bronze is flagged as stolen—and plans to seek legal compensation for the purchase fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) at a depth of 15.5 km, 35 km north of Lucca in Garfagnana, Italy, and was felt as far away as Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena; several lower-magnitude aftershocks followed, phone and power outages occurred locally, and schools were evacuated as a precaution, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy, prone to quakes—including a deadly magnitude-6 event in the same area last May and the 2009 L’Aquila disaster that killed nearly 300—has an active National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV), whose Alessandro Amato described the latest tremor as “medium-strong” and “fairly shallow.” Six scientists and a former official were convicted in 2012 for underestimating the risk of the 2009 quake, which led many residents to stay indoors and perish.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield who had doubted whether South Yorkshire’s climate could support the crop, finally saw fruit successfully grow—still unripe and attached to the plant—and was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has pushed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March in order to allow extra testing and polish, assuring fans the delay will be worthwhile. Meanwhile, eagerly awaited online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch, and new PC screenshots showcase Los Santos and Blaine County running at 1080p/60fps with support for up to 4K resolution and triple-monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications have also been published, and it’s noted that GTA V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever upon its original 17 September 2013 release, earning $1 billion in just three days.

At 76, the painter Jenny Simpson has won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery with her work Squint (19), having been shortlisted once and longlisted three other times before; the 7-ft-tall painting—part of a series depicting medieval church “leper squints,” small holes through which outcasts could view services—was praised by judge Ansel Krut as “quite extraordinary” and likened to a “tone poem” for its subtle, minimal language and sympathetic subject, and Simpson says she will spend the prize money on high-quality stretches, canvas and paints. Established in 1957 as one of Britain’s oldest biennial art awards, the John Moores Painting Prize counts David Hockney and Peter Doig among its past winners and is now patronized by Sir Peter Blake.

Masked assailants attacked the offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit early Thursday, shattering windows with gunfire and causing a fire at the Yeni Safak building that firefighters swiftly extinguished; no casualties were reported, police cordoned off both scenes—located 20 km apart—found numerous spent bullet casings, and are hunting the attackers, none of whom have claimed responsibility.

The 24-year-old, previously contracted to the Stags and on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer effective 1 January as Bignot’s first signing.

Arsène Wenger, whose Arsenal contract runs until summer, has been linked to the England manager’s role now held by Gareth Southgate, whom Wenger praises for gaining experience and making sound decisions in recent matches (a 2-0 win over Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia). Southgate, 46, must secure a win over Scotland in a World Cup qualifier on November 11 and perform well in a friendly against Spain four days later to earn the permanent position. Wenger emphasizes competency over big names and focuses on his own duties, stating he plans to extend right-back Héctor Bellerín’s contract amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, and confirms midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A man employed by Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday, and Lincolnshire Police, alongside the Health and Safety Executive, is conducting a joint investigation with full cooperation from the company.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that from next month Serco Northlink will resume operation of the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay under a new charter arrangement designed to end a dispute in which the RMT union claimed some crew were paid under £4 an hour. Seatruck, the current operator contracted by Serco Northlink, had argued the UK national minimum wage did not apply to many non-UK resident seafarers, while Serco Northlink said it had repeatedly offered to backdate and bridge the pay gap—a proposal Seatruck declined. Subject to final financial and regulatory details, the new charter will guarantee all crew at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which holds a six-year £243 million contract awarded in 2012, operates three ferries and two cargo boats on the heavily subsidised Northern Isles route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an altercation at Rockley Park in Poole involving him, his partner Samantha Mitchell and her son Jamie Mitchell. Jamie, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother on 7 May after drinking heavily at the holiday park bar, and pleaded guilty to common assault. Both he and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about who started the confrontation, later claiming Jamie had tried to separate them, resulting in what he called a “tragic accident.” They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter behind hits such as Michael Jackson’s “Off the Wall,” “Rock With You,” “Thriller” and Heatwave’s “Boogie Nights,” died in London at 66 following a brief aggressive battle with cancer. Nicknamed “The Invisible Man” for his low profile, Temperton rose from a refrigerated-food factory in Grimsby to join disco band Heatwave in the 1970s, penning “Boogie Nights,” “Always & Forever” and “Groove Line” before Quincy Jones recruited him for Jackson’s Off the Wall and Thriller albums—projects that helped make Thriller the best-selling U.S. LP of all time. His songs have been recorded by Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin and others; he won a 1990 Grammy for Quincy Jones’s Back on the Block and earned two Oscar nominations for The Color Purple soundtrack. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan and BBC presenter Gilles Peterson, while Warner/Chappell confirmed his family’s request for privacy after his private funeral.

A team including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, along with researchers from Exeter, Reading and Brazilian universities, has uncovered over 450 large geometrical earthworks—geoglyphs up to 2,000 years old—in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon. Hidden beneath bamboo forests until recent deforestation, these ditched enclosures yielded few artifacts, suggesting they were not villages or fortifications but sporadic ritual gathering sites. Dr Loader’s analyses of phytoliths, charcoal and carbon isotopes indicate the geoglyphs were built under tall vegetation, unlike Maya pyramids, raising questions about their visibility and purpose. The findings also overturn the idea of a pristine pre-European Amazon, showing humans over 6,000 years spread diverse plant species and managed forests by promoting economically valuable trees—a “prehistoric supermarket”—whose legacy may endure in today’s biodiversity.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian ranked a career-high 12th and fresh off winning the Japan Open, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round; despite his victory, Kyrgios admitted he felt tired and less vocal than usual due to travel fatigue, poor sleep and a challenging commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium, noting that his recent success and schedule had taken their toll.

Scientists and charities are calling on the Welsh government to extend its successful girls-only HPV vaccination programme—which has reached 85% coverage since its 2008 rollout—to boys, arguing that HPV drives a rising number of head and neck cancers predominantly affecting younger, non-smoking men around age 55; they plan to deliver a letter urging action ahead of awaiting guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

Jak Trueman was a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil battling a rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, whose fight—shared by his mother Allison, sister Aimie and girlfriend Hannah Boyd on a Facebook page called Jak’s Journey—garnered over 28,000 Likes as he documented hospital stays, visits from Rangers, Celtic and Hibs players, Edinburgh Rugby and the cast of Wicked, and personal moments like playing his tuba. After learning on 23 January that his cancer had spread and that no further treatment would be pursued, Jak continued to make the most of his time—visiting the Kelpies, enjoying a supercar ride, attending a prom in his honour (where he collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy), and meeting former Rangers stars Barry Ferguson, Neil Alexander and Nacho Novo—while raising funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His mother announced his death on Facebook, writing: “Devastated and heartbroken to say my beautiful boy’s gone to Heaven.”

Egypt edged Uganda 1-0 in Port-Gentil courtesy of Abdallah El Said’s 89th-minute finish, set up by Mohamed Salah, after Uganda had a first-half effort correctly ruled out for offside. Despite dominating possession and creating a handful of chances—including Salah being denied by Denis Onyango’s header and several saved efforts by Essam El Hadary—Egypt struggled for long periods on a poor pitch against a resolute Cranes defence. The victory keeps Egypt’s hopes of topping Group D alive ahead of their clash with Ghana, who earlier beat Mali 1-0, while Uganda, playing their first tournament since 1978, are eliminated and will face Mali in their final fixture needing a win and a favourable Ghana-Egypt scoreline to advance.

Lancashire County Council has designated land at the former Glenburn Sports College and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College as the preferred site for a new railway station after Network Rail compared these and a site near the Concourse shopping centre; Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956. In partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, the plan would deliver two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, and the chosen location offers room for future expansion, good highway access and connectivity. The council, which owns the Glenburn site, will now begin acquiring the land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in October 1961, remains one of the largest towns in northwest England without its own railway station.
Police officers searching a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning discovered plants in an elaborate grow house and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

Police in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, say a 28-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin was found late Sunday lying on a pavement with serious injuries after having been dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Münder later handed himself in and is now in custody. Prosecutors say the motive remains unclear, and police have secured the area and are calling for witnesses.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers from the 2013–14 workplace relations survey, conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, found that women ask for pay rises just as often as men but are 25% less likely to receive one once they do, even after comparing full-time with full-time and part-time with part-time workers and controlling for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications. The research found no support for the idea that women are more reluctant than men to negotiate pay or afraid of defying stereotypes, and noted that men may simply be less likely to acknowledge failed requests. Differences by age showed parity in negotiation and success rates for both sexes under 40, suggesting younger women’s growing confidence may help close the gender pay gap.

Oxford City Council has spent most of its budget on ground investigations for new burial sites but has been unable to find suitable land—council-owned parcels have been ruled out due to size, ground conditions, high water tables or restrictive covenants. Only two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, remain with space, expected to fill by 2018 and 2021. Once they are full, only reopened family plots, a few reserved plots and ashes interments will be possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932, and the council says it is still exploring options.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, running from 19 to 22 July, can now access augmented reality content—videos, band interviews and real-time updates—via an app that scans signs and posters on site. This feature, introduced by HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan, aims both to enhance the on-site experience and to allow people worldwide to interact with the festival atmosphere, buy tickets and receive up-to-date information at any time.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; although he had previously shown post-race ataxia symptoms and a tendency to overheat, he exhibited no health issues on the day, and the British Horseracing Authority notes such rare bleeding episodes can occur in otherwise healthy sport horses and is investigating their causes and prevention.

In autumn 2004 a 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage and later accused her of raping her while two friends slept; Ayrton, now 34 and legally known as Davina since a name change in 2012, denied the charge at Portsmouth Crown Court. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her to custody—likely in a male prison in Winchester—citing risks to her safety and court attendance, and she will be sentenced on 4 March. The court heard Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, had protocols in place for her detention and insisted during the trial that she had made no physical changes to her body or taken medication. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of Foster’s, clearly recalled shouting at Ayrton to stop, and Ayrton later disclosed the attack to a care-home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, in 2014.

The Serbian doubles team fell 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, coming just a day after world number one Novak Djokovic was ousted from the singles by Argentina’s Juan Martín del Potro; Djokovic, 29, had also suffered an unexpected third-round Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey in July but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympics.

More than 20 chainsaw carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US will compete in Saturday’s event in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms, where only chainsaws are permitted to carve logs into animal and human figures; last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Josh Webb hasn’t played since a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up against Italy in September but is now “back up and running” and in a pre-season phase, aiming to shave a couple of weeks off a planned early-February return so he can regain fitness ahead of Wales’s Six Nations opener against Ireland on 7 February. Capped 16 times, the 27-year-old has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union—turning down other offers to stay with the region he debuted for in 2007—in order to keep himself in prime position for international selection.

US border agents south of Sumas, Washington, intercepted two men carrying backpacks containing 26 kg (58 lb) of MDMA on Tuesday morning; when ordered to stop, one man dropped his pack, fired at agents and fled (later identified as Canadian Nathan Hall), while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately. A California driver’s license bearing William Nickerson’s name but Hall’s photo was found in one pack. Investigators then arrested Bellingham resident Kali Henifin—who had planned to pick up the pair after monitoring police radio—and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who expected $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco. All three now face federal conspiracy, possession and distribution charges; the smuggling route, a wooded area east of a highway crossing, is known for drug and firearm trafficking.

The NSPCC’s Childline reported a sharp rise in online abuse counseling, helping over 4,500 children last year compared with about 2,400 in 2011–12, with many more cases thought unreported and some victims as young as seven. Childline warned that cyber-bullying, driven by online trolls, can follow children beyond school and become relentless persecution. President Dame Esther Rantzen urged parents, teachers and schools to intervene early, noting that bullying only worsens if ignored and children must feel able to seek help. The findings coincide with the launch of Anti-Bullying Week, led by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is partnering with families and schools to tackle the issue, while testimonies from young callers underline the emotional toll of online harassment.

Ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Israel’s government—reportedly at Prime Minister Netanyahu’s request—postponed a Jerusalem planning committee vote on 492 new homes in Ramat Shlomo and Ramot to avoid further US tensions after America abstained on a UN Security Council resolution condemning West Bank and East Jerusalem settlements. The resolution, backed by 14 members, declared settlements “flagrant violations” of international law and obstacles to a two-state solution, infuriating Netanyahu, who accused the White House of drafting the text—a claim Washington denied. In response, Israel summoned foreign envoys, recalled its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal and cancelled Ukraine’s prime minister’s visit. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution as groundwork for a January Middle East peace conference in France.

On the eve of the Queen’s 90th birthday, Prince William praised his grandmother’s duty, service and tolerance as “a guiding example” in a BBC interview, acknowledging media criticism of his own royal commitments but insisting he’ll assume greater duties in due course. To mark her milestone, the Queen toured Windsor’s Royal Mail delivery office—coinciding with the postal service’s 500th anniversary—opened a new bandstand at Alexandra Gardens, and unveiled ten commemorative stamps featuring four generations of the royal family. On her actual birthday she will inaugurate The Queen’s Walkway and ignite a beacon to launch over 900 celebratory beacons worldwide, before hosting President and Mrs. Obama at Windsor Castle, while republican critics accused the BBC of unbalanced coverage.

West Ham United defeated League Two Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup after Diafra Sakho opened his account for the season from Sam Byram’s pass and Andre Ayew doubled the lead before half-time. Despite a promising start and chances through Harry Pell and Jordon Forster, Cheltenham were unable to breach Adrian’s goal, while West Ham, making seven changes after recent Premier League defeats, dominated possession and had several opportunities to extend their lead. A late Cheltenham substitute, Dan Holman, narrowly missed a low cross, and Robins captain Kyle Storer even cleared Angelo Ogbonna’s header off the line, but Cheltenham bowed out without seriously testing the visitors’ keeper, leaving League Two without representation in the competition ahead of Thursday’s third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, was killed when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig turned his VW Transporter right on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion without seeing the motorcyclist. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, received a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. Prosecutor Sarah Marsh said the victim’s family, staying near Bala, accepted it was a momentary lapse and did not seek imprisonment, while defense counsel Craig Hutchinson noted Werner’s remorse and inability to explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British fighter known as Abu Daigham al-Britani, traveled to Syria in January last year to join the Islamic State–affiliated Rayat al Tawheed, where he posted propaganda videos, solicited donations and even appeared holding a severed head. Tracked by MI5, he faked his own death online and enlisted his cousin Tahir Bhatti’s help to return to the UK via Bulgaria, but was arrested on arrival at Dover. Now held at Belmarsh and facing life imprisonment, Khawaja has admitted four offences related to terrorism while Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender; the more serious charge of soliciting to murder remains on file.

Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances as Wrexham finished eighth last season, has become Barnsley’s third signing ahead of their League One play-off final; caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson’s pace and attacking style after the player declined a new contract offer from Wrexham.

National Trust volunteers have been removing sealed bottles of Vanish washing up at Poldhu Cove and nearby beaches—including Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion—after storms allegedly caused a container to fall from a ship near Land’s End in May. Although the Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirms the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of the detergent, it says there’s only circumstantial evidence linking those bottles to the Cornish shore. Some bottles are reported to have leaked, raising concerns among Cornwall Wildlife Trust and National Trust staff about detergent entering sensitive marine habitats. Cornwall Council, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency and Natural England are monitoring the situation, advising the public to keep children and dogs away and not to attempt bottle recovery.

The passage reports that a crash occurred at about 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, resulting in several minor injuries, closure of the road with diversions via the A897 between Helmsdale and Melvich, and ongoing Police Scotland inquiries.

Dervite, 28, played 14 times last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and earn promotion, bringing his total appearances for the club (which he joined from Charlton in 2014) to 83 in all competitions; praised by manager Phil Parkinson as “a bit of a forgotten man” who made an excellent late contribution, he has now signed a new contract alongside David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan ahead of the Championship campaign.

Lib Dem Lord Oates and Labour’s Baroness Smith traded accusations after their joint efforts to secure EU citizens’ rights and require parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal fell apart when MPs rejected the amendments: the Lib Dems vowed to keep pushing for those protections, while Labour chose to defer to the Commons, prompting Lib Dems to accuse Labour of colluding with the government on a hard Brexit and Labour to dismiss Lib Dem tactics as “grandstanding” that offered “false hope.” Despite having cooperated on other issues such as higher education and housing, tensions now loom over future alliances, although both sides say they will work together where they still agree.

Defence barely registers with voters despite growing global instability, and all major UK parties devote scant manifesto space to it, avoiding the hard choices ahead. British forces have already shrunk—regular Army from 102,000 to 82,000, a 19-ship navy and just seven front-line fast-jet RAF squadrons—and capability gaps like the lack of Maritime Patrol Aircraft force reliance on NATO allies. Defence spending, once fourth globally, has fallen to sixth and is set to drop below NATO’s 2 percent GDP benchmark (to 1.7 percent or even 1.5 percent by 2020) with no party pledging to protect the budget, making further cuts likely. Committing £20 billion to four replacement Trident submarines and completing two carriers strains already stretched manpower and equipment plans, and while Conservatives promise no further troop reductions and a 1 percent annual equipment uplift, a new government faces pressure to balance fiscal targets with military readiness.

Barcelona has paid £48.6 m to sign 22-year-old Neymar from Santos, with his parents receiving £34 m, and including the transfer fee, signing-on bonus, five years’ wages, agents’ fees and a recent tax settlement, the total cost to the club has reached £106.8 m. Last month president Sandro Rosell resigned amid allegations of misappropriation of funds and a Spanish judge has ruled there is enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Although Barcelona insists it committed no tax offence and that its original payment fulfilled all fiscal obligations, it has filed an additional “complimentary” tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover any divergent interpretations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 La Liga games and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham and new father, was killed on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, when Albert Kenneth Newman, a retired motorist driving north in the southbound carriageway, collided head-on with the Ford Transit van in which Luciw was a passenger; Luciw’s family and the van’s driver, Andy Harrington, who was seriously injured, urged mandatory medical and driving tests for older drivers to prevent such tragedies, while Age UK emphasized the importance of enabling safe driving among the elderly. Currently in the UK, drivers over 70 must renew their licence every three years via self-assessment without medical or practical testing, and the DVLA says it has no plans to impose age-based restrictions, relying instead on licence renewals and reports of medical conditions to remove unsafe drivers from the road.

Independent review of transvaginal mesh implants for pelvic organ prolapse in Scotland, prompted by patients’ debilitating side effects, has been criticized for its final report, which two patient members and a consultant quit over, alleging content was watered down. Professor Alison Britton will assess the review’s methodology and draw lessons for future processes, while the report itself advises against routine use of these procedures, urges offering patients alternative treatments with full information, and calls for mandatory adverse-event reporting. Despite campaigners’ demands for a ban, the Scottish government says only the UK’s Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency can prohibit them. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants in the past two decades; more than 400 are currently pursuing legal action.

Laura Muir, 23, shattered Yvonne McColgan’s 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena with a time of 14:49.12. McColgan welcomed the milestone but expressed initial uncertainty over whether the mixed 3K event—where Muir was the sole 5K finisher—met UK Athletics’ “genuine race” and doping-control requirements; British Athletics has since indicated the mark will be ratified. McColgan praised Muir’s world-class potential, suggesting she could lower her best to around 14:30, and drew parallels between Muir’s solo pacing—lapping other runners—and her own similar record run that also involved lapping Paula Radcliffe. Muir, who previously broke the British 1,500m record in Paris and reached the Rio Olympic 1,500m final, thus adds another national record to her achievements.

Michael Jung claimed gold riding Sam, a late substitute after Fischertakinou fell ill, with France’s Astier Nicolas taking silver and America’s Phillip Dutton bronze, while Great Britain’s William Fox-Pitt, competing ten months after a coma-inducing fall, delivered a faultless final show-jumping round on Chilli Morning but could only finish 12th overall after cross-country time penalties following his dressage lead; Ireland’s Jonty Evans was ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. Fans are invited to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics, and can access a special guide on getting into equestrian via the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray defeated 30-year-old Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours 39 minutes on Centre Court, rallying from two set points against him in the fourth to reach the Wimbledon last 16 for the 11th time. Murray sealed victory at 20:57 BST as fading light threatened a roof closure and will next face Benoît Paire. Earlier, Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. Despite an up-and-down performance and some movement issues, Murray praised his resilience, noting he can improve before Monday’s match.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 and police found patrons still inside, with till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. At Limavady Magistrates Court, licensee Colleen O’Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours; a defence solicitor admitted the premises had not been properly run and stayed open into the morning. The judge, noting O’Neill’s “appalling record” and lamenting his inability to impose custody, ordered the bar closed for three months and fined O’Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt opened the Ulster Unionist manifesto launch with the slogan “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” aiming to frame the election as a verdict on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, but his remark about preferring to work with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin drew attention and prompted a public sidestep by colleague Danny Kennedy. Nesbitt, unrepentant, quipped that Kennedy’s distancing was “reaffirming” and insisted voters should back the UUP first, then any local candidate they trust, while stressing his own campaign success in unionist areas and contrasting his party’s vision with what he called “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption” at Stormont. The UUP’s ‘Real Partnership’ manifesto pledges to tackle health‐care waiting lists, boost PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritise the York Street interchange, defend LGBT rights and ensure no group is disadvantaged by Brexit, alongside a commitment to “clean up Stormont.”

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to introduce a legislative consent motion in the Northern Ireland Assembly to enact provisions mirroring England and Wales’ recently announced “Turing’s Law,” which grants posthumous pardons to men convicted of abolished sexual offences and allows living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, with the aim of correcting past injustices and ensuring equal treatment as soon as possible.

Laura Muir, the 23-year-old from Kinross, ran 4:19.12 to finish second behind Faith Kipyegon and set a new Scottish 1500 m record, beating Yvonne Murray’s 1994 mark and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Already holder of the Scottish mile record and fifth at last year’s World Championships, Muir began her season with an 800 m win in Montbéliard and will next race the 1500 m in Stockholm, all while completing her fourth year of veterinary studies, and she aims to secure Great Britain’s Olympic spot at the British trials in Birmingham from 24–26 June.
The passage presents a selection of user-submitted photographs from the 26 beaches in Scotland that have been officially rated as “most excellent” for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko in 2006 and that the use of polonium-210 in his tea pointed to sponsorship by the Russian state, which had ample reasons—such as his defection and public attacks on President Putin—to wish him dead, though this did not implicate Putin directly. Litvinenko died in hospital almost three weeks after the poisoning. Horwell noted two separate poisoning attempts, a “trail of polonium” linking the suspects, and unknown long-term risks to Londoners. Extradition efforts have failed, the men remain in Russia, and the public inquiry has been adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia’s permanent one-day captain and will also lead the Twenty20 side in Aaron Finch’s absence, with 28-year-old David Warner named vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and suitability for the role as Michael Clarke, 34, retires following England’s Ashes win at Trent Bridge. Smith has already captained in three Tests during Clarke’s injury layoff and boasts 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66 in 32 Tests. Despite past disciplinary issues, Warner is viewed as a maturing senior figure ready for leadership. The new leadership duo will guide Australia through the limited-overs fixtures after the final Ashes Test at the Oval beginning 20 August.

Tim Farron has consistently declined to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead emphasizing that “we are all sinners,” while insisting he is “a liberal” who is “absolutely” committed to LGBT-plus equality. On the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show he pledged to defend equal-marriage rights and to extend them to transgender people by removing the “spousal veto,” which currently requires a spouse’s consent for a gender-transitioning partner’s marriage to continue. He explained that in 2007 he backed a Lib Dem amendment to the Equality Bill out of concerns for “protection of individual liberties” and then voted against the bill after that amendment was defeated, even as he affirmed his support for equal legal access for all sexualities.

Accord Healthcare will reopen Sanofi’s former Fawdon drug manufacturing plant, closed in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs, and aims to rehire many ex-Sanofi employees; the company expects its investment to benefit the local area, while Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes praised the move as boosting the region’s science and healthcare reputation and economy. Accord Healthcare, which develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries, is positioned as a global industry player.

Richard Ellis, the council’s former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, will leave at the end of his contract on Friday, while Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive’s office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement; SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn said these departures illustrate the council’s struggle to retain senior staff and predicted more to come, and council chief executive Angela Scott thanked all three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants stormed Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital at 09:00 local time after detonating explosives at the gate and opened fire on staff and patients, wounding more than 50, before four attackers were killed several hours later by commandos who landed on the roof; the Islamic State claimed responsibility—marking its first direct clash with security forces in the capital—while the Taliban denied involvement. President Ashraf Ghani condemned the assault as a violation of “all human values,” and officials warned it signals IS’s growing resources and training that could bring further high-profile attacks. Since declaring its “Khorasan Province” in 2015, IS has carried out deadly bombings across Afghanistan, including at Kabul rallies, mosques and the Supreme Court, but has struggled to establish a broader foothold beyond eastern border regions, where security forces claim to have dismantled some of its bases but not dislodged militants from mountainous areas. Afghanistan’s leadership, including de-facto deputy leader Abdullah Abdullah, condemned the hospital attack and vowed to avenge the victims.

English rider Martin suffered a crash at this year’s TT and his Fireblade bike has been beset by mechanical issues; although he initially announced he was quitting road racing, he later clarified on Facebook that he hasn’t given up on racing but simply has no plans to do further road racing on Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will also miss next month’s Ulster Grand Prix, a decision the team made without informing him. Martin described the TT as “a bloody disaster” and felt reduced to a test rider; after recent testing at Cadwell Park convinced him the bike wouldn’t be competitive at Ulster, he accepted the withdrawal. He says he has no unfinished business in road racing and plans to focus on classics and unusual events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of 28 governorships in Saturday’s elections, marking the Peoples Democratic Party’s (PDP) worst defeat since military rule ended in 1999 and reinforcing its loss of last month’s presidential poll to Muhammadu Buhari, who is to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP, long dominant, was ousted in key northern states—including Katsina and Kaduna—and in Adamawa, but held eight governorships mainly in the south-east and retained oil-rich Rivers State; elections in Taraba and Imo remain unresolved, and seven states did not vote. The APC now controls most northern states and Lagos, though it fell short in all five oil-producing states—a concern given potential militant disruption—and recorded higher violence at polling stations than in the presidential election. Despite this, the overall election was more peaceful than previous cycles, suggesting democratic maturation, while the PDP faces a period of introspection and leadership renewal after defections, corruption allegations and failure to curb the Boko Haram insurgency.

Environmental lobby group Mighty alleges that Singapore-based commodities trader Olam, 99% of whose palm oil is sourced from third-party suppliers and accounts for under 1% of the global market, may be inadvertently fueling the slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia that cause regional haze and that its majority owner, state investment fund Temasek, has turned a blind eye to these unsustainable methods. Mighty’s report claims Olam created a “secretive market for rogue palm oil companies” and that Temasek’s stake implicates Singapore in financing haze-causing palm oil, which both Olam and Temasek deny. Olam CEO Sunny Verghese insists the firm enforces a “no burn-no peat-no deforestation” policy, has only just disclosed its 14 supplier names, and will expel any noncompliant producers after a multi-year vetting process. Temasek, while affirming support for no-burn land-clearance policies, says it does not intervene in Olam’s operations. The report also criticizes Olam’s Gabon ventures for rainforest clearance, a charge Olam rebuts by asserting its public–private partnerships there are responsible and transparent.
On 27 August 2016 (last updated at 12:34 BST), a restaurant began offering “puppy platters” after a new law permitted dogs to dine at eateries—provided they remained outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri remains doubtful after featuring only as a substitute in the last two matches due to a knee issue; striker David Nugent, sidelined with a groin problem, could return following his absence in Monday’s draw with Huddersfield; and midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who came off the bench to score a late equaliser against the Terriers, is pushing for a starting spot.

Pakistan’s telecom regulator lifted its 2012 Supreme Court–imposed YouTube ban after Google rolled out a Pakistan-specific version, with the PTA ordering ISPs to restore access. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists have called for transparency on the deal’s terms. The IT ministry explained that Google now provides an online process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material locally, but YouTube says it evaluates removal requests against its community guidelines and records government takedown requests in its Transparency Report. The original ban followed protests and deadly violence over the amateur film Innocence of Muslims, deemed blasphemous under Pakistan law.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, has been urged by Liberian FA president Musa Bility to withdraw by Thursday or face a challenge at the Court of Arbitration for Sport, on the grounds that Article 7.4 bars committee members with nationality ties to candidates. Scala and Claudio Sulser voluntarily stepped aside in 2015 when incumbent Sepp Blatter, a Swiss national, ran, but Scala’s spokesman Andreas Bantel argues that with five candidates and no incumbent, there is no conflict now. Bility, whose own candidacy was ruled ineligible last November, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali of Jordan and insists on fairness after FIFA’s recent turmoil. The February 26 presidential election in Zurich, decided by FIFA’s 209 members, will feature Gianni Infantino, Prince Ali, Jérôme Champagne, Sheikh Salman and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in the paint-spraying area of Harford Attachments in Spar Road; their bodies were removed the following afternoon. A forensic search at the digger-bucket manufacturer has been completed, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reports “significant progress” in forensic inquiries and witness statements. Preliminary evidence indicates a flashover explosion—caused by a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition—resulted in a fireball effect, and the Health and Safety Executive has deployed inspectors and electrical safety experts to gather further evidence.
