Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to CAF for contesting a controversial late penalty and subsequent quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament, while Morocco re-entered the 2017 qualifiers when the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned CAF’s ban and cut its fine from $1 million to $50,000 after Morocco refused to host the 2015 finals over Ebola fears; both federations have since patched up relations with CAF, and in last week’s draw Tunisia were placed in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F.

Manchester City’s Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho have been charged following a late on-pitch brawl in the 95th minute of their 3-1 defeat by Chelsea at the Etihad Stadium; Aguero, sent off for a high challenge on David Luiz, received a four-match ban—the club’s second violent-conduct dismissal this season—and Fernandinho, involved in the ensuing scuffle with Cesc Fabregas, was given a three-match ban, while Fabregas faces no further action and Guardiola has apologized. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on December 8 to respond.

Wedi canfod bod cyfraddau goresgyn canser yn isel yng Nghymru, lansiwyd cynllun peilot yn Cwm Cynon a Castell-nedd lle gall hyd at 40 meddyg teulu gyfeirio cleifion y maent yn eu pryderu – er nad oes arwyddion clir – at ganolfan ddiagnostig Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg o fewn saith diwrnod, gyda’r nod o weld tua chwech o gleifion yr wythnos a chynnal pob prawf ar yr un diwrnod; dim ond 35% o gleifion â symptomau pryderus sy’n cael diagnosis yn ardal Cwm Taf ar hyn o bryd a’r bwriad yw cyrraedd y mwyafrif sydd heb symptomau amlwg yn gynt. Dechreuwyd y syniad ar ôl ymweliad arbenigwyr â Denmarc, lle gwelwyd gwella sylweddol mewn canser oherwydd canolfannau tebyg, ac yn ôl Dr Gareth Davies a meddyg teulu Gareth Jordan bydd y cynllun yn tawelu meddwl cleifion, yn lleihau oedi rhwng cyfeiriad a diagnosis ac yn hybu canfod cynnar. Os bydd y tri mis cyntaf o’r tri mis cyntaf o’r peilot chwe-mis yn llwyddiannus, bwriedir estyn y gwasanaeth ledled Bwrdd Iechyd Abertawe Bro Morgannwg.

England wrapped up a comprehensive victory at Old Trafford with a day to spare, levelling the series after scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to secure their second–biggest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root, promoted to No. 3, was named man of the match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76*; coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s hard work and self-analysis after two early dismissals in the first Test. Pakistan offered little resistance on a benign pitch, lasting just 63 and 70 overs in their two innings, and have only two batsmen—Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq—past fifty in the series so far. England pundits hailed the hosts’ batting discipline and bowling quality, predicting continued dominance, while Misbah bemoaned his side’s lack of confidence and poor shot selection. Pakistan now head to a two-day match against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Head coach Warren Gatland has named interim coach Rob Howley and handed forwards coach Robin McBryde head‐coaching responsibilities for the third time—after Wales tours in 2009 and 2013—for the British and Irish Lions’ tour of New Zealand. McBryde described it as an honour and an exciting opportunity, while the Welsh Rugby Union says it will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour and hopes to confirm its full management team next week. WRU chairman Gareth Davies added that involving Welsh coaches on the Lions tour will benefit Welsh rugby by developing coaches in new environments and mentally stimulating both coaches and players.

Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty put Southampton ahead and Hull City lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to injury before half-time, but Robert Snodgrass—introduced after Keane’s withdrawal—revived the Tigers with a well-taken 61st-minute strike and a pinpoint free-kick that Michael Dawson headed home moments later. David Marshall made several crucial saves and Sam Clucas blocked a last-gasp shot off the line as Hull secured their first league win since August 20, ending a six-game losing run, though they remain in the bottom three ahead of the international break.

A local motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa; the tractor driver was uninjured, Lincolnshire Police have released no further details but have appealed for witnesses, and the B1191 was closed both ways between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov abruptly halted a probe into alleged abuses of power exposed by covert recordings ahead of June’s early elections, claiming he acted to “defend national interests” and “cut a knot,” a decision denounced by opposition leader Zoran Zaev—who called it illegal and mobilized protests in Skopje—and by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardizes Macedonia’s EU ambitions. The 2015 crisis stems from recordings released by Zaev purporting to show ministers plotting vote-rigging, wiretapping some 20,000 individuals, mismanaging funds, prosecuting opponents on dubious grounds, and covering up a murder; the government denies the allegations and accuses Zaev of seeking to destabilize the country.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Saturday’s match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s sacking, while Swansea aim to appoint ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as permanent boss to steer them clear of relegation. Curtis warned that dropping into the Championship—now stronger and harder to return from despite examples like Norwich, Burnley and Newcastle—would be tough for a club unable to retain top players. Swansea, promoted in 2011 after narrowly avoiding bankruptcy, thrived under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup but have since “lost their way” amid constant managerial changes and insufficient player replacements. Curtis believes the current squad can survive and ensures all new signings understand the club’s rise from near collapse and the importance of Premier League status for the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who had reached League One in 2010 and the Football League for the first time in 2007 under John Still, were relegated back to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona overturning Jay Simpson’s early brace; Armand Gnanduillet’s late strike sealed Orient’s win, leaving them two points shy of the play-off spots. Dagenham’s League Two campaign has been marred by the division’s worst goal difference—conceding 20 more goals than at the same point last season—and an attack short of former returns, with 40-year-old Cureton on nine goals compared to 20 in 2014–15. Still, now in his third spell, admitted his side lacked organisation and discipline for long periods, while Orient interim boss Andy Hessenthaler acknowledged nervy moments but stressed the need for wins to maintain their play-off push following Kevin Nolan’s recent dismissal.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach—his first role since retiring in November after a 19-year playing career that began with his Liverpool debut in 1998, included multiple domestic and European trophies, and ended at LA Galaxy. Manager Jürgen Klopp welcomed the appointment, noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and his readiness to learn, and praised his combination of experience and character. Gerrard had been linked with MK Dons but deemed it premature, and he is currently working toward his UEFA A coaching licence required for Premier League management.

Morton took an early lead when McManus scored on the quarter-hour, and Ross Forbes’s deflected shot made it 2–0 before Alloa’s Kyle McAusland pulled one back just before half-time; McManus then scored again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to secure a comfortable home victory.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in unhygienic, unsafe conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham—among 18 unregulated centres, mostly in Muslim communities, inspected in recent months—that have now closed and whose proprietors face investigation for running illegal schools punishable by up to 51 weeks in jail. Any institution teaching children more than 20 hours per week must register as a school, yet some “part-time” or “flexi” centres exploit home‐education rules to operate unlawfully, prompting Sir Michael Wilshaw to warn these cases are likely the “tip of the iceberg” and risk child abuse or radicalisation. He criticized government officials for giving confusing advice to proprietors about registration, and ministers have funded a six‐inspector team to pursue further illegal providers across all religious groups. The education secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases and is consulting on tighter regulation of settings teaching over six to eight hours weekly, with responses due by mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, housed in a cowshed at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the UK’s smallest-scale gin distillery, aiming to usher in a revival of Borders distilling alongside several proposed whisky ventures. Led by Kate Macinnes, it draws on abundant wild botanicals from the Teviot valley to express local “terroir,” complementing the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery and aligning with the centre’s ethos of using regional ingredients. Named after Lilliard, a legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, the distillery reflects both the surrounding landscape and its strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam was killed at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013 when 51-year-old Gary Green, over twice the legal alcohol limit after consuming the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, reversed a tractor into him while walking in a closed-off area; Green, prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the incident occurred on private land, admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and received a 16-month, two-week prison sentence. His mother, Pam Whitlam, who worked at the farm’s café, said the family had been “changed forever,” lamenting that Harry’s memory was now confined to the day of the accident and calling for accountability for anyone driving drunk, whether on public roads or private property. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the case as “extremely tragic” and Green’s behaviour as “reckless.”

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) has upheld FIFA’s record nine‐match ban on Luis Suárez for biting Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup but ruled that the Uruguay striker may now train with Barcelona’s first team, play in friendlies and take part in promotional activities while serving the remaining eight competitive-match suspension. Barcelona confirmed Suárez will join team training on Friday and be officially presented at Camp Nou on Monday, though it is unclear if he will feature in the friendly against Club León. His competitive debut is expected in El Clásico against Real Madrid on 26 October, and he will be available for Uruguay’s friendly fixtures. Suárez’s legal team maintained that FIFA’s blanket prohibition on football-related activity was disproportionate, a stance echoed by players’ union FIFPro, which remains disappointed that the bans themselves were not reduced in exchange for mandated treatment.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying race on 18 March 2014, beating Lithuania’s Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa after training on a local athletics track. The 380-metre course featured haystack hurdles, a steep slope and water pistols, and allowed any gender pairing. Rich and Anna will advance to the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond reassured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that scrapping paper car tax discs in October 2014 and moving to an electronic monthly direct-debit system may alter DVLA job roles and reduce refund-processing tasks, but any staffing reductions will be handled by redeploying employees to growth areas rather than redundancies—a response Hedges said would comfort concerned DVLA staff despite fewer local job opportunities.

Hungary’s foreign minister told Reuters the EU should not interfere in what he called “domestic issues” and said Poland has pledged to veto any attempt to strip Hungary of its voting rights over its asylum controls, higher education law and proposed NGO legislation. The EU objects to Hungary’s tight asylum measures—which include forcibly housing asylum seekers in secured shipping containers—and to a higher education law that could close the Central European University founded by George Soros, as well as draft rules labeling NGOs “foreign-backed.” Despite thousands of protestors and warnings from EU Commissioner Frans Timmermans, Hungary’s Fidesz government under Viktor Orbán has refused to backtrack, and any sanctions would require unanimous EU approval, which Poland has signaled it will block.

Oscar-winner Emma Watson stars as Belle in Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice and the star of the 1991 animated film voicing Mrs. Potts; filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May and the film opens in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a celebrated Sunday Times columnist since 1993, died suddenly after publicly battling a “full English” array of cancers, having undergone chemotherapy and written a final column on coming to terms with his diagnosis. Praised by editor Martin Ivens as the paper’s “heart and soul” and by peers like Jay Rayner and Tim Shipman for his wit and fearless writing, Gill was admired for overcoming dyslexia and dictating copy by phone. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, educated at St Christopher’s, Central Saint Martins and the Slade, he began as an art reviewer before moving to Tatler and then the Sunday Times. Known for provocative pieces—ranging from shooting a baboon in Tanzania to insulting the Welsh and Isle of Man residents—he also once described Clare Balding in homophobic terms and was thrown out of Gordon Ramsay’s restaurant. Gill married three times—first to Cressida Connolly, then Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children, and was engaged to long-term partner Nicola Formby, with whom he also had twins—describing his upcoming marriage as an unexpected source of excitement.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa and lead singer of Mongolian band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked onstage in Ulan Bator—struck over the head with a bottle, repeatedly kicked in the face, and left in a coma for about ten days—after performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Nazi Germany. His father and lawyer denied that Amraa shouted “Heil Hitler” during the show and emphasized the swastika’s cultural significance. The Russian embassy called local reports of the assault “distorted” and said it was investigating, while Mongolian police and Amraa’s lawyer insist the Russian diplomatic officer suspected of the assault must face investigation under Mongolian law despite claims about his immunity.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest on Monday at 03:30 BST on Heathrow’s northern runway to oppose the airport’s expansion, and have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area; they are due in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police said it will review airport security.

Nick Selman anchored Glamorgan’s innings with a patient 101 off 144 balls—the Brisbane-born opener’s second first-class century—despite being dropped early, while Aneurin Donald chipped in with 36. Seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles exploited the cloudy conditions to take regular wickets, constraining Gloucestershire, who struggled as their batsmen fought for survival into the evening. Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten later secured a consolation bonus point for Glamorgan. Michael Hogan captained in Jacques Rudolph’s absence, and in post-match comments Selman acknowledged his return to form after a string of low scores, while Taylor praised the helpful seam conditions and expressed satisfaction at transitioning from white-ball to red-ball success.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after contacting Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre and admitting he intended to file a false crime report so officers dispatched to the Dee Estuary could be ambushed and shot; he made these threats twice late at night while intoxicated. At Mold Crown Court on Friday he pleaded guilty to two charges and was remanded in custody pending sentencing next week, with Judge Niclas Parry noting Hughes’s 2009 firearms conviction. During an earlier hearing, his defense said he never intended to carry out the plot or to kill himself, and police had been especially alarmed because he was on bail for firearms offences (later cleared) when the threats were made.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7 thanks largely to a 130-run stand between Ollie Davies and Ben Foakes (90), while Yorkshire’s chase faltered after Stuart Meaker took three wickets in nine balls, including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance, leaving them all out for 236 despite a late 68 from Tim Bresnan. Surrey’s Matthew Waite also picked up 3-48 and dropped two chances before finally breaking the Davies–Foakes partnership, and although Yorkshire’s Bresnan and Waite (38) tried to rally, needing 27 off the last three overs proved too steep. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised his team’s collective effort, while Yorkshire skipper Alex Lees rued their failure to capitalize on a “reachable target” despite strong bowling.

A 56 ft converted trawler foundered six miles west of South Stack after its onboard pump failed to handle incoming water; the crew alerted Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST, and an RNLI lifeboat crew fitted a replacement pump and towed the vessel back to Holyhead.

Jemma Muir, the 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner who placed fourth in the 1,500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will miss next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine final-year exams in May clash with the event. Returning to university immediately after a brief break, she prioritizes completing her degree but remains optimistic about her athletics future, targeting the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March and believing she has the potential for two or three more Olympics. Fresh from setting an outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 while finishing behind Hellen Obiri, Almaz Ayana and Sifan Hassan in a tough 5,000m race, Muir says she’s pleased with her form and excited about what lies ahead.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are a long way off challenging for the Premier League title again because they’ve lost the attacking firepower of Luis Suarez and the largely injured Daniel Sturridge, while replacements Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert and Fabio Borini lack both goal threat and the intensity that powered last season’s high pressing. Their set-piece potency has vanished, their defence remains unsettled despite heavy spending on Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren, and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet provides shot-stopping but not leadership at the back. Savage expects Brendan Rodgers to field a midfield-heavy XI with Borini leading the line against Chelsea but still foresees a home defeat, as José Mourinho’s side are on “another planet.” He also highlights Steven Gerrard’s ongoing struggle to secure a long-term future at Liverpool, praising his professionalism and fitness at 34 while acknowledging the physical and mental challenges aging brings.

A £45 million campus is to be built on Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, and East Ayrshire Council plans to seek the McIlvanney family’s permission to name it after William McIlvanney. Born and educated in Kilmarnock, McIlvanney taught English after graduating from Glasgow University before becoming a full-time writer in 1975; his debut novel Remedy Is None and subsequent works—including the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty and The Big Man—earned him the title “Godfather of Tartan Noir.” He was also a poet, journalist and broadcaster who influenced Scotland’s political and sporting discourse through columns and television, and he died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

Residents near Gourock’s swimming pool area were evacuated for much of the morning and early afternoon and those within 500 m were advised to stay indoors with windows open and avoid walls, while a half-mile exclusion zone on the river and sea kept small craft away as experts made safe a 1940s–1950s British sea mine spotted Monday. Three streets were cleared, ferry sailings from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted, and police commander Ch Insp Elliot Brown emphasized the precautionary nature of the operation and lack of immediate danger. Royal Navy Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis explained that the mine’s deterioration made its explosive charge uncertain, so it was moved to a safer location for disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and evacuation.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million—£2 million less than for Rio—to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, setting medal targets of 51–85 for the Olympics and 115–162 for the Paralympics. Cycling’s funding was cut by over £4 million to £25.98 million, and archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby lost theirs entirely. Badminton, despite earning bronze in Rio, saw its entire £5.74 million withdrawn, prompting objections from Badminton England and GB Badminton officials, while judo received a slight increase. Government and National Lottery funding remains confirmed, but UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl stresses tough prioritisation to safeguard medal potential. Basketball, handball and volleyball, long unfunded, criticised UK Sport’s reluctance to support team sports. Funding for returning sports—baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton—will be decided pending medal-potential reviews, with £9 million still unallocated.

Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—are set for demolition at East Cliff in Bournemouth to make way for a six-storey, four-star, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living blocks (nine and seven storeys, totaling 122 apartments), a plan by East Cliff Project LLP that councillors approved by seven to three votes despite English Heritage’s and the Ancient Monuments Society’s warnings of “severe harm” to the conservation area; supporters (246 letters) cited tourism benefits, while 49 residents objected, and planning board chair David Kelsey argued the old buildings are no longer functional and must give way to improved tourism and senior living.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment training in Brecon, was found unconscious and later died after being punched and beaten outside The Cellar bar on 8 May by 24-year-old Jake Vallely, who boasted earlier that night of being the “hardest man in Brecon” and dragged Boyd’s body away before fleeing; Vallely faces sentencing on 8 December and his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement after jurors heard he left before the attack. Det Supt David Guiney called the assault “a despicable act” that shocked the community, and Boyd’s family paid tribute to him as a loving, loyal “all-rounder” with a promising career, lamenting the void created by his loss and praising the support and strength shown by Brecon residents.

Andrew Travers departed Barnet Council by “mutual agreement” following a polling-list error that left voters initially turned away from all 155 borough polling stations, prompting an independent investigation and an internal review due to conclude by the end of May. Travers, who served three and a half years as chief executive, said he was proud of ongoing growth and transformation initiatives. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will act as interim chief executive while permanent arrangements are made. On election day, one station reported only three of the first 30 voters were on the register, and the council later apologised, offered emergency proxy votes and blamed electoral registration lists for the disruption. The forthcoming review will assess the suitability of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June, with findings to be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2–1 thanks to Josh Gillies’s early free-kick and Ryan Bowman’s second-half header, after Wrexham had drawn level through Sean Newton’s set-piece. Gateshead boss Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s improved second-half passing and the quality of Bowman’s winner, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills rued his team’s drop in performance after the break despite creating chances.

On 1 October 2014 the Global AgeWatch Index 2014 was published, ranking the social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries; Norway ranked first, while Afghanistan ranked last, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb plans to deploy a broadband constellation of at least 600—and ultimately over 2,000—small, low-cost satellites to deliver global internet (with every school connected), manufacturing them on new high-volume, assembly-line systems in Toulouse (and soon Florida) at under $1 million apiece and at rates of three per shift. Launches using more than 20 Soyuz rockets will put clusters of 32–36 satellites into 1,200 km orbits, yielding roughly 300 satellites on station by early 2021, over 600 by 2022 and 800+ by mid-decade. While rivals such as SpaceX and Boeing seek similar “mega-constellations,” OneWeb—backed by $1.7 billion in equity and pursuing UK licensing and financing—claims a first-mover edge. To address debris concerns, each satellite is designed to deorbit within two years and includes an adapter for potential retrieval by a chase vehicle. Airbus and OneWeb also hope to apply their mass-production techniques to other satellite customers, though bespoke “gold-plated” platforms will still be needed for specialized missions.

John Swinney warned that successive UK government spending reviews since 2010, including the latest one, have imposed “unprecedented” real-terms cuts on Scotland—projected to reduce its discretionary budget by 12.5% between 2010-11 and 2019-20, with a further 4.2% squeeze to come and over £1 billion still to hit by decade’s end—and pledged to protect key services such as schools, hospitals and police amid tough choices. He contrasted these austerity measures with Scotland’s record of more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university and a record health budget. A Scotland Office spokesman retorted that the Scottish government will actually have almost £30 billion in its block grant next year—£390 million more, or £750 million including underspend—and argued this is better than the independence alternative. Labour’s Jackie Baillie meanwhile called on Swinney to move beyond “anti-austerity posturing” and set out a long-term budget with different tax choices than the Tories or the SNP.

Many people with severe disabilities who require hoists or two carers find standard accessible toilets inadequate, leaving them isolated and stressed when out in public. Campaigners—including mothers Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers, and disability groups like Mencap—are calling for compulsory installation of larger, fully equipped Changing Places toilets (12 m² with benches, hoists and washing facilities) in new large buildings such as shopping centres, cinemas and stadiums. Although guidelines (BS 8300:2009) recommend these facilities, they are not mandatory, so many venues cite space and cost barriers. Families describe the indignity and logistical struggles of changing loved ones on dirty floors or in cars, while successful installations—like at Cardiff’s Principality Stadium and Arsenal FC—demonstrate positive public response and the feasibility of retrofitting existing sites when requirements are clear.

Italian consumers’ groups have filed an antitrust complaint with the European Commission, alleging that McDonald’s forces its franchisees into excessively high rents, fees and long-term contracts that prevent them from switching to competitors and result in higher prices and less choice for consumers. Supported by the SEIU and European unions, the complaint argues that McDonald’s dominant market position harms franchisees, workers and customers. McDonald’s insists it shares risks and rewards with its licensees and provides ongoing support, while franchisees operate 73% of its European restaurants. The Commission is now reviewing the complaint and may launch a formal investigation if it finds the claims credible.

A social media campaign featuring the hashtag #prayforjosh has gone viral in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, after he was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when surgeons at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital found and removed a large primary tumour and five smaller growths instead of performing an appendectomy. Launched by Bangor Elim Church—where Josh’s father serves on the pastoral staff—with Facebook and Instagram posts that have reached over 79,000 people and been shared 948 times, the movement recently gained a surprise boost when an anonymous donor funded a giant “#prayforjosh” billboard near Holywood. As classmates, church members and strangers worldwide continue to send their support and prayers, the campaign’s senior pastor, Gary Beattie, remains amazed at its global impact.

The Ministry of Defence has announced the closure of Brecon Barracks—home to troops since 1805—and the wider reorganisation of military sites in Wales, which includes creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, shutting Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies condemned the decision as a “blatant lack of respect” for the barracks’ history and warned of its impact on a region with high unemployment and a thriving military tourism sector, launching a petition against it. The barracks employs about 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, whose jobs are currently not thought to be at risk, and nearby training facilities at Sennybridge and Dering Lines are unaffected. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need to restructure but cautioned that base closures would create “gnawing uncertainty” for local livelihoods.

The House of Lords European Union Committee warns that although Britain’s fishing communities, which strongly backed Brexit, hope to regain control of UK waters and become major exporters, the industry—worth only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000—risks being sidelined in Brexit talks; shared stocks with other EU states, high export dependence on the EU market and imports of fish for domestic consumption mean continued market access is vital but may require granting EU vessels fishing rights, and any deal must balance trade-offs over tariffs and quotas. The report urges retaining Common Fisheries Policy elements—scientific total allowable catches, international cooperation—and cautions that leaving the EU could fragment fisheries management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland, even as recent CFP quota increases for key species and industry optimism suggest Brexit could herald fuller control over a 200-mile exclusive economic zone and fairer, sustainable management.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical contractor, revealed that the NSA conducts mass surveillance on individuals’ communications—including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers and social networking activity—by collecting millions of Verizon phone records (call duration, location, numbers) and using “backdoor” access via the Prism program to nine major tech companies’ servers (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple). While U.S. intelligence officials defend these operations as vital to counterterrorism, the exact mechanisms remain secret, companies deny direct involvement, and experts debate whether access is broad or limited to named targets under court orders. National and international data-protection laws generally regulate corporate data handling rather than government surveillance, and U.S. statutes like the Patriot Act and FISA enable authorities to reach data stored abroad—raising concerns among EU officials and privacy advocates. British and U.S. leaders insist law-abiding citizens need not fear monitoring, but critics warn that the scope of Prism and related programs threatens individual privacy worldwide.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services, is a nonprofit AI research venture committed to advancing digital intelligence for “positive human impact” without profit motives. While Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that unrestrained AI could become humanity’s “biggest existential threat” by self-improving faster than biological evolution, other experts view such risks as remote. OpenAI’s mission is to develop AI that benefits everyone, distributed widely and aligned with individual human wills, and it plans to spend only a small portion of its $1 billion pledge in the coming years.

Lieutenant Ben Parkinson, seriously injured by a bomb in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June in Doncaster—walking for half an hour with crutches and an assistant to support his arm—after reclaiming his speech and personality following a brain injury. Since then he’s received over 5,000 Facebook friend requests (the site limit for personal profiles), thousands of visits and messages via the Pilgrim Bandits charity he patrons, and hundreds of torch-relay appearance invitations. He spends 12 hours daily on gym work and rehabilitation while raising funds for military charities. Facebook suggests he create a public page or enable subscribers for his updates.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held steady at 15%, or 46.2 million people, after three years of rises, while real median household income fell by 1.5%; the average poverty threshold for a family of four stood at $23,021. That year saw a 1.6% rise in the Gini index—the first annual increase since 1993—indicating growing income inequality, and the uninsured rate dipped from 16.3% to 15.7%. In 2010, poverty had reached a record high of 15.1%.

The 25-year-old wicketkeeper-batsman Jos Buttler joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new contract running until 2019; a short-format specialist, he holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries—including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan—and was instrumental in Lancashire’s T20 Blast triumph at Edgbaston last year, earning praise from cricket director Ashley Giles for both his talent and dressing-room presence; currently with Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for Friday’s home T20 Blast fixture against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour pending bids to register by 23 January, with viewings in late February and March and a final decision expected in spring. No preservation proposals have been received; the Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to assess domestic capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports recycling but hopes one frigate can become an artificial reef and tourist dive attraction. Originally anti-submarine specialists, the Type 22s later gained robust anti-surface and anti-aircraft systems, flagship command facilities and a crew of about 280.

Since 1987 Fiji has suffered recurring political upheaval driven by tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, beginning with a coup that year and followed by a convoluted constitution, a 2000 coup that saw the Indo-Fijian prime minister held hostage, and a 2006 bloodless military takeover—events that crippled tourism, damaged Fiji’s international standing and led to its 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth. After the government pledged in 2012 to hold free elections in 2014, Australia and New Zealand restored full diplomatic ties and the Commonwealth readmitted Fiji. Its population—once evenly split between indigenous Fijians and descendants of Indian indentured laborers—now has a slight indigenous majority due to Indo-Fijian emigration, with deep social segregation and small Chinese and Rotuman minorities. Although Fiji’s economy benefits from sugar, tourism, mining (gold, silver, limestone), services and light manufacturing, chronic trade and budget deficits make it one of the highest per-capita recipients of foreign aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is striving to meet its OPCW- and UN-mandated timetable to destroy its roughly 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over the full stockpile and alleged attacks by “terrorist groups” on shipments from Damascus to Latakia; to date only about 30 tonnes (4%) have left the country, prompting US and Russian concerns over delays. Mekdad also defended the government’s use of barrel bombs in Aleppo—where the UK-based Syrian Observatory reports hundreds killed—and denied shelling civilians or losing control of Aleppo’s central prison, dismissing US criticism as “absolutely unacceptable” and accusing America of continuing to back terrorists. He maintained Syria remains committed to its disarmament obligations despite ongoing security challenges.

The 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, the first open to all English-language authors, features six contenders: debut favorite Mukherjee’s The Lives of Others (5/2), Howard Jacobson’s futuristic love story J (former winner, next at 3/1), Ali Smith’s How To Be Both, Joshua Ferris’s To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, Karen Joy Fowler’s best-selling We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, and Richard Flanagan’s wartime romance The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Since the shortlist announcement on September 9 sales spiked—Fowler’s title topping 55,000 copies—and judges chaired by AC Grayling will name the winner at London’s Guildhall on Tuesday, with each shortlisted author receiving £2,500 and a specially bound edition. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

PJS is challenging a Court of Appeal decision that lifted his England‐and‐Wales media anonymity order, and the UK Supreme Court has agreed to consider whether to grant his appeal, keeping an interim injunction in place until that hearing concludes. The dispute centers on The Sun on Sunday’s wish to publish alleged extra‐marital sexual encounters beginning in 2009 involving PJS, “AB” and “CD,” which first surfaced in a December 2011 text about a three‐way and were offered to the paper in January; a High Court judge initially refused PJS’s bid to block publication, but two appeal judges later granted him interim anonymity and barred identifying him in England and Wales until 13:00 BST on Wednesday, pending his Supreme Court application. News Group Newspapers then asked the appeal court to remove the ban, noting widespread publication abroad and online, and the judges ruled confidentiality has likely been lost and a permanent injunction is now “hopeless,” even though PJS’s solicitors have actively sought to remove breaching content.

Fosse Park, a retail site near M1 junction 21 opened in 1989 and acquired in August for £345.5 million, is set for improvements to its parking, traffic flow and unit façades. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White noted discussions with the new owners on planning issues, emphasizing the site’s role as the city’s gateway and the need to replace the “backs of sheds” view. Crown Estates investment director Paul Clarke added that addressing parking, congestion and the quality of common areas and facilities is essential to revitalizing the tired park.

Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast was cleared by Malaysia’s Censorship Board with a P13 rating after a “minor edit” to remove a brief gay subplot involving LeFou’s feelings for Gaston, but its release has been delayed pending a content review by Disney. Although homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, the board’s chairman said approval means the film can screen, while cinema chains offer refunds to ticket holders until a release date is set. The decision has drawn criticism online, with some calling the review “ridiculous” given the country’s own film output.

Landlords in Southampton letting properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation licence—which can cost around £1,000—or face fines up to £20,000, yet the council estimates some 1,500 HMOs remain unlicensed. Tenants, according to Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan, often fear eviction and endure poorly maintained homes amid a shortage of affordable housing, prompting about five or six related calls daily. National HMO licensing applies to three-storey houses occupied by five or more unrelated people; locally, Designation 1 areas (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling) have been covered since 2013 and Designation 2 areas (Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett) since 2015. While most landlords comply, the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are negotiating to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil offering to facilitate a minority government without endorsing its programme. Their main dispute centers on water charges: Fianna Fáil demands their immediate removal while Fine Gael insists they retain a role, and a commission on the future of Irish Water is under consideration. After the election nearly two months ago, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour seven, but no party has secured a majority or elected a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck about 27 km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon; the blaze intensified so rapidly that its captain, who initially hoped to contain it, ordered a full evacuation. Passengers and crew boarded lifeboats and life rafts before being rescued by several vessels—including the ferry Puglia—and taken aboard that ship. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and were airlifted to hospital. Spanish officials reported that the rescued group was being returned to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists awaited to offer counseling. The cause of the fire remains unknown, and the Balearic Islands port authority warned that the Sorrento, owned by Italy’s Atlantica di Navigazione, may sink where it lies.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had noted people, including students, claiming to have voted twice in the 8 June election—a record turnout with 46.8 million registered and 68.7% voting. Although nearly 4.9 million registration applications were submitted online between December and May, only a net 1.4 million new entries appeared on local registers, implying 30–70% were duplicates. With 381 unconnected local registers and no way for individuals to check their status online, officials face significant administrative and financial burdens. The commission urged better integration of databases, clearer registration guidance, and a verification tool, while warning that double voting in a general election is a criminal offence. Labour cautioned against measures that might deter young or mobile voters.

Lawrence Phillips, a former University of Nebraska star and NFL running back for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, died by suicide at age 40 while awaiting trial for the alleged killing of his cellmate, Damion Soward. After his pro career was derailed by repeated off-field incidents, Phillips was imprisoned for assaulting a former girlfriend and for driving into a group of teenagers. He was serving a sentence of more than 30 years, had been isolated in his cell following the murder accusation, and leaves behind a legacy of talent overshadowed by anger issues that even his college coach, Tom Osborne, acknowledged.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially enlisted as a soldier with his own army number, pay for rations and holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester marking the Mercian Regiment’s eight-year anniversary. He is the 30th mascot ram in an unbroken line dating back to Private Derby’s acquisition in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot, which later became the Mercian Regiment in 2007. Since joining in February 2014, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has earned his promotion for “good behaviour” and has taken part in public duties such as switching on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at the 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool produced a stirring last-minute 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-final second leg at Anfield, overturning a 2-0 first-half deficit with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren, inspired by Jurgen Klopp’s passionate touchline leadership and the Kop’s relentless support. Dortmund’s early dominance through Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang threatened to derail Liverpool’s campaign, but Klopp invoked the spirit of Istanbul 2005, instilling belief that propelled a dramatic turnaround. The night combined colour, atmosphere and emotion—highlighted by an extended “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and a minute’s silence for Hillsborough—before Liverpool’s force of will broke Dortmund’s resolve. Klopp’s six-month tenure has already reshaped the team’s identity and rejuvenated supporters, even as defensive frailties remain. With Sevilla, Villarreal and Shakhtar Donetsk still in the draw, Liverpool now move into the semi-finals, edging closer to European silverware and a Champions League return.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Brexit Secretary David Davis proposed monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to share analysis and ensure a two-way information flow as the UK prepares its negotiating strategy with Brussels, describing the inaugural session as constructive despite differing viewpoints. Scottish government minister Michael Russell welcomed the involvement but criticized the UK government’s lack of clarity—more than four months after the referendum—on whether it intends to stay in the single market or customs union, insisting that single-market membership is vital for Scotland’s economy. Meanwhile, the UK government anticipates that the High Court’s ruling on triggering Article 50 will be overturned by the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government plans to oppose that appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking permission to participate.

Veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr and Professor Kevin Sinclair are conducting detailed health assessments on a flock of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham—among them four “Dollies” cloned from the same ewe as the original Dolly—to determine whether cloned animals age or develop age-related diseases prematurely. Through hands-on joint examinations, X-rays, fMRI scans and regular monitoring of osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease and diabetes, the team aims to discover if any “age memory” from adult donor cells accelerates cellular senescence or disease onset. Though the first Dolly died at six-and-a-half with arthritis and a viral lung infection, the current clones—now nearing nine and ten years old—appear in robust health, and the study’s full results will be published next week.

Shutter Speed extended her unbeaten run as the 4-7 favourite, winning by a length and three-quarters over Vintage Folly on very soft ground, and trainer John Gosden plans to target the Oaks at Chantilly rather than Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are favoured. Frankie Dettori, riding Shutter Speed, praised her class and predicted improvement on better ground, while BBC’s Cornelius Lysaght noted she handled the soggy conditions well. In other action, Tasleet (14-1) delivered a comfortable victory in the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas, Jim Crowley aboard. Gosden remains cautious about running his colt Cracksman in Thursday’s Dante Stakes because of the ground and the quick 16-day turnaround to the Derby trial.

The pound initially fell against the dollar, euro and yen amid worries that Remain’s chances were slipping—down 0.2% to $1.4226, 0.6% to €1.2605 and 1% to ¥151—before a brief mid-afternoon recovery and further losses, driving sterling volatility to levels not seen since 2008. With ten days until the referendum, two weekend polls and Betfair odds saw Remain’s probability drop to 68.5% from nearly 80%, prompting analysts to warn of heightened currency swings if the race remains tight. Hedge funds have increased short-selling bets on sterling, and markets are on “full Brexit alert,” with sterling off more than 2% in two sessions. Asian stock markets tumbled—Japan’s Nikkei fell 3.5%, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng 2.5%—while London’s FTSE 100 ended down 1.1% at 6,044.9, led by a 4.2% drop in Lloyds shares. Leave campaigners counter that sterling and the FTSE are unchanged since March and argue a weaker pound benefits exporters, a point underscored by April’s narrowing UK trade deficit driven by higher exports.

Braintree Town sit sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off places, after losing to Barrow—who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games—despite a spirited effort following a six- to seven-hour journey and conceding an early goal. Manager Craig Cowley praised his team’s performance, called their campaign “nothing short of remarkable” so far, acknowledged the difficulty of competing as a part-time side, and vowed to embrace and enjoy the challenge ahead.

From April 2015 responsibility for most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will transfer from the Stormont Planning Service to local councils, meaning elected politicians rather than officials will approve or reject developments. Michael Corr of PLACE welcomes this as an opportunity for councils to create community-led development plans, provided voters elect politicians with urban-planning expertise. However, memories of 1960s housing discrimination and Friends of the Earth’s concerns about uneven treatment of communities, close ties between developers and parties, and potential conflicts of interest mean a strict code of conduct and full transparency over party donations—currently capped at £7,500 for reporting—are regarded as essential, with the Northern Ireland Secretary set to decide when to expand political-donation disclosures.

One-year-old Teenie was found in Winchburgh on 14 March having been shot twice in the shoulder and once through her left hind leg, which vets were forced to amputate; her owner and the Scottish SPCA describe the three shots in a housing estate as “callous” and are urging anyone with information to come forward. Scottish SPCA chief superintendent Mike Flynn said the case underlines the need for urgent airgun licensing so only those with lawful reasons can possess such weapons and police can trace irresponsible users. Last year’s Scottish government consultation on airgun licensing saw 87 percent of respondents—many calling the proposal “draconian” or “heavy-handed”—reject the plan, though a few argued it did not go far enough.

Liverpool have bolstered their attack by triggering the £32.5m release clause in Christian Benteke’s contract, making him their second-most expensive signing on a long-term deal after selling Raheem Sterling for £49m and Luis Suarez for £75m; the 24-year-old Belgium striker, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa since arriving from Genk in 2012 and netted 15 last season following an Achilles injury, joins amid concerns over Liverpool’s meagre eight-goal haul from new forwards Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert. Manager Brendan Rodgers, who has also brought in Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and seen Divock Origi return from loan, aims to revive a misfiring attack, a view shared by former Villa boss Paul Lambert—who calls Benteke a “brilliant number nine”—and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge, who praises his pace, strength and aerial presence.

A recent study of 671 state and independent schools found that while tablet use has surged—68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools now employ them, 9% issue one per pupil and numbers are set to rise from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 by 2016—there is no clear evidence that tablets alone improve academic attainment. Researchers note they cannot isolate technology as the cause of any performance gains, though head teachers report positive impacts on pupil motivation, family involvement and engagement among disengaged students. A separate National Literacy Trust and Pearson report highlights touch-screens’ benefits for boys and children from poorer households in reading. Within fully tablet-equipped schools, a quarter of secondary pupils self-identify as internet “addicts,” and about two-thirds take internet-connected devices to bed. Advocates like Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School, argue tablets empower pupils, reflect real-world technology use and foster a trusting school ethos, even if their benefits can’t easily be quantified in exam league tables.

The Museum of Liverpool’s Growing Up in the City exhibition features 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s that chart changing childhood experiences and Liverpool’s social history, from an 1887 portrait of the Rollo children dressed for a mayoral fancy-dress ball to a circa-1900 image of a young maid at work; curator Kay Jones selected these images from hundreds of postcards, photographs and glass-plate negatives to illustrate both the joys of street play and the hardships of child labor, and the show runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals, having previously featured for Aldershot, Exeter and clubs in Italy, and could face his former side on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, whose past clubs include Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, arrives pending international clearance after a recommendation from ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson describes Anderson as a “leader-type” despite limited game time and Keating as “raw but incredibly hungry,” as his side sit four points above the relegation zone with just one win in their last six matches.

Bolivia’s newly approved law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, imposes up to 30 years’ imprisonment for child homicide and toughens penalties for violence against children, and was championed by Vice-President Álvaro García Linera as a necessary response to one of South America’s poorest nations. Congress passed the measure, signed in President Evo Morales’s absence, to address the reality that over 500,000 Bolivian children already work—often in shoe-cleaning, food vending, mining or agriculture—to support their families. While the International Labour Organisation recommends a minimum working age of 15 (or 14 in developing countries) and is reviewing Bolivia’s law for potential breaches of global child-labor standards, García Linera argues that stricter but realistic legislation will better enforce children’s rights and help eradicate extreme poverty.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, describes how she fell ill at home—experiencing sudden nausea, aches and chest pain—after helping a woman from her car in Nyack, New York, and, having searched online for “women’s heart attack symptoms,” took aspirin instead of calling 911. The next day a cardiologist found a 99 percent blocked artery and inserted a stent, diagnosing a “widow maker” heart attack. In a blog post titled “my heart attack,” she urged women to recognize symptoms and call emergency services, noting she felt “lucky to be here.” O’Donnell, known for roles in Drop Dead Diva, Will & Grace and Nip/Tuck, recently hosted The Rosie Show on OWN until its cancellation in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed to death in an alleyway off Belvedere Way, Kenton, at about 00:30 GMT after attending a party where an earlier group fight had occurred; he was pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed at the same time and is in stable condition in a north London hospital. Police believe Che, who had been invited to what appeared to be a well-run event with appropriate adult supervision, was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. Detective Chief Inspector Chris Jones has appealed for witnesses present between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate when the attack occurred. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder (the minors bailed until mid-December), and a 14-year-old is held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Danish health authorities, prompted by “quite alarming” cancer survival statistics over 15 years ago and long diagnostic waiting times, introduced a three-route model in 2007 to speed up detection of both obvious and hard-to-diagnose cancers without increasing overall referrals: fast-track pathways with strict time targets for “alarm” symptoms and a legal requirement that any referred patient be investigated within 30 days; diagnostic centres at hospitals and clinics offering rapid tests and scans for cases GPs cannot diagnose, eliminating referral “ping-pong”; and “yes-no” centres for patients with minor symptoms to receive simple tests or scans within hours. Evaluations by Prof. Frede Olesen and others show this reorganised approach has improved survival rates, accelerated Denmark’s progress compared to Norway, Sweden and Finland, and offers organisational lessons for similarly structured systems like Wales.

The UK government has replaced the Office of Fair Trading’s oversight of estate agents by awarding Powys County Council a £170,000-a-year contract to handle breaches of the Estate Agents Act, including issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest agents. Although consumers will continue to lodge complaints with their local authority trading standards, cases involving alleged statutory violations will be referred to Powys, whose new team will be led by James Munro, who hopes the arrangement will demonstrate the council’s ability to secure and manage similar external contracts in future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, based on a Nuffield Trust review, to expand the roles of its 1.3 million-strong workforce—examples include nurses covering for hospital doctors and pharmacists assisting GPs—to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and rising GP demand. The report argues that shifting more responsibilities to non-doctor staff aligns with the growing focus on managing long-term conditions, though it warns additional funding is needed for training. While supporters highlight potential benefits for patient care and staff satisfaction, union leaders caution against viewing workforce reshaping as a low-cost shortcut that could undermine doctor training and fail to resolve chronic staffing shortages.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT, leading to an A36 road closure until 14:00 GMT that disrupted commuters and bus services; investigations into the collision are ongoing, and First’s managing director James Freeman said some services have resumed but full recovery will take a few hours, aiming for a complete service by the evening commute, while thanking the public and staff for their support.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) has estimated that the proposed £1.3 billion Swansea tidal lagoon could cause annual mortality rates of 21% for salmon and 25% for sea trout during migration, figures Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) challenges as “unrealistic and grossly misleading” and based on undisclosed “what if” scenarios. TLP’s own expert computer modelling predicts a worst-case fish mortality of 2%. NRW insists its numbers derive from the best available evidence, shared methodology and data assessed by independent and in-house experts. The Swansea lagoon, seen by TLP as a pilot for larger coastal projects, is under UK government review, and while Wales’s Environment Secretary supports the scheme, she urges clarity on its future.

Stormont’s Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced that Northern Ireland’s Agri-Food Strategy Board will develop a new industry-led agri-food marketing body—modeled on Scotland Food and Drink—to provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing efforts across government and private sectors in a region that employs nearly 100,000 people in farming, fishing, retail and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as a positive step toward export-led growth and improved coordination, while noting the plans may affect other organizations, including her own department, and expressing her intention to discuss these implications with the board.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant 40,000 native UK trees this Saturday at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley as part of a four-year, four-site project planting “millions” of trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. At Brackfield Wood—dedicated to the roughly 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives—the trust aims to create a thriving wildlife habitat with carpets of wildflowers and iconic poppies. Director Patrick Cregg encouraged locals and visitors to “roll their sleeves up” and contribute hands-on by planting saplings provided by the charity, wearing stout footwear, with limited parking available seven miles outside Derry city off the Glenshane Road.

Hilary’s thriller Someone Else’s Skin, the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackling domestic violence and honour crime, won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at Harrogate’s crime writing festival, praised by judges for its emotional power, tight prose and evocative atmosphere. Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham called it “emotionally exhausting and powerful,” while festival chair Ann Cleeves highlighted its strong plotting. US author Sara Paretsky, creator of detective VI Warshawski and founder of Sisters In Crime, received an outstanding contribution honour for revolutionizing the portrayal of female protagonists in crime fiction over her 23-year career.

Santner, 24, who broke his finger in only his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, missed the remainder of the season at a time when director of cricket Steve Rhodes felt his continued presence could have bolstered the county’s qualification hopes; having made his Test debut in 2015 as a left-arm batsman and spinner, Santner will return to the Rapids after June’s ICC Trophy in England, hoping to make up for lost time, and Worcestershire have meanwhile signed Australian paceman John Hastings as their main overseas player for all formats in 2017.

Barry Pring, 47, was fatally struck by a speeding car with stolen plates while trying to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway in 2008; his wife, 19 years his junior Ganna “Anna” Ziuzina, had gone back for a missing glove and later tried to claim his assets, selling his Range Rover and moving funds from his account. At an Exeter inquest, coroner Dr. Elizabeth Earland returned a verdict of unlawful killing, finding overwhelming circumstantial evidence and noting witness reports that the car did not brake and the incident was deliberate. Pring’s family and close friend are convinced Ziuzina staged the hit-and-run to inherit his estate—she was entitled to the first £200,000—and evidence emerged of her affair with a Ukrainian man and past work as a lap dancer. Despite three statements to Ukrainian police, Ziuzina declined to attend the inquest, and although Ukrainian authorities reopened the inquiry as a murder case in 2011, it remains technically active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Merseyside who has battled illness since age three and suffered a third relapse in April, urgently needs further experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children’s Hospital after a previous transplant failed and no UK treatment options remain. An anonymous donor has now paid for his treatment in full, a development his parents describe as “completely overwhelming,” and Charlie has received financial clearance to begin therapy as soon as a date is set next week.

Apple has responded to reports that third-party “forensic” tools were used to steal celebrities’ private photos from iCloud by extending its two-step verification to include backups—a measure that is currently opt-in but which experts say should be enabled by default. After signing in on a new device, users must enter their password plus a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone or via the Find My iPhone app; without it, they cannot access iCloud or make iTunes, iBooks or App Store purchases. A 14-character recovery key can restore access if a trusted device is lost, though critics warn it risks being forgotten or stolen. Previously, even with two-step authentication enabled, tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker could download full backups; its developer now admits Apple’s changes block that method and trigger email notifications when backups begin. While some security specialists welcome the improvement, they urge Apple—and other firms—to make two-factor authentication the default and increase user awareness.

Dan Groves has indicated that the “finer points” of a deal which could see 30-year-old Wright acquire a 20% stake in Billericay Town and become a club director are yet to be disclosed. Currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off the play-offs, the club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has committed to investing £10,000 a week. Wright, known for finishing runner-up on I’m a Celebrity…Get Me Out of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds, while Billericay also bolstered their squad in early March by signing former England international Paul Konchesky, 35.

Mr Ashley has been asked by the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to give evidence on the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage following a BBC investigation into Sports Direct’s Derbyshire warehouse practices. In a letter giving him until 21 March to respond, Mr Wright notes that although Mr Ashley invited the committee to meet at the company’s Shirebrook base, the committee will hold its session in public at Westminster and has offered several dates which Mr Ashley has neither accepted nor declined; failure to agree to a date could result in further action, including a contempt complaint to the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented, and the company has previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley’s oversight.

A Russian-language report titled Putin. War, initiated by the late opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin, compiles evidence—much of it previously reported in Russian and international media—showing that President Vladimir Putin has directed regular Russian troops and equipment to secure major victories for pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine since 2014. The dossier features admissions from Russian soldiers and veterans that they were ordered by Russian generals, documents unit names and weapon photographs, and estimates Russia’s conflict spending at 53 billion roubles. Originally spurred by relatives of fallen soldiers who never received promised compensation, the report faces distribution challenges in Russia, where many publishers fear repercussions and public opinion remains divided over Moscow’s role in Ukraine.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearne in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday and died of head injuries, and a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman have been arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones has criticised the UK government for publishing its Article 50 letter without consulting Wales’s devolved administration or letting him see it beforehand, describing the process as “unacceptable” and disrespectful, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the UK government has engaged with Wales for months and must act in the interests of the whole UK. In her letter to Donald Tusk, Prime Minister Theresa May pledged to consult on which repatriated powers should sit at Westminster or with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, and said she expects each devolved administration’s decision-making authority to increase. However, key details—such as which specific powers will be devolved, whether corresponding funding will follow beyond 2020, and how regional aid commitments will be maintained—remain unclear ahead of a forthcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged during an incident on Nursery Drive and Parkhead in Newry on Friday night, prompting Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin to condemn what he called “mindless attacks” on PSNI officers and the local community. A PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post said officers were “carrying out duties” when they were attacked and urged parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr Charney, founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted last year following employee complaints and alleged misuse of company funds, and the board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return. The filing, filed in response to Charney’s defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair, presents alleged evidence of illicit emails sent by Charney to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, and asserts that he repeatedly violated the company’s sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board argued that no company would risk hiring him given these facts, and earlier this month was granted a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative press statements about American Apparel or attempting to remove board members.

BBC Sport will stream Britain’s home warm-up match against Greece live on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30 to 19:30 BST at the Copper Box in Stratford. Earlier this month Greece beat GB 92-64 in Patras, but three key Greek players will be absent in London, giving GB a chance for revenge. Guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford local, said the game will be crucial preparation for EuroBasket 2017 and that newcomers will benefit from the Copper Box atmosphere. After facing Greece, coach Joe Prunty’s squad heads to a four-team tournament in Poland before EuroBasket begins in early September with GB in a qualifying group in Istanbul.

The passage recounts how, in January 2007 at the Moscone Centre, Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone—a device not yet available for journalists to handle—prompting the author to secure a brief hands-on from Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, for a BBC news segment. Despite initial skepticism and viewer complaints about overplaying a product launch, the author defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone’s potential impact to that of the Model T Ford. A decade later it’s clear the smartphone has indeed been transformative, putting powerful computers in billions of hands, upending industries and redefining activities such as photography. While earlier phones had cameras and internet access, Jobs’s key innovation was an intuitive interface that made users actually adopt those features. The author reflects gratefully on witnessing the start of the mobile-connected era, noting that today other companies continue innovation—particularly in AI—but the revolutionary shift began on that sunny San Francisco morning.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, tests by the RSPCA confirmed that all cats found near Victor Avenue had ingested a toxic substance—antifreeze—and in the latest incident a seven-month-old cat named Meereen died after showing signs of poisoning; three other cats have died in the past week and another two weeks ago. Meereen’s owner, Adria Pearce, described finding her foaming at the mouth and shivering before vets confirmed antifreeze consumption. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock has appealed to local residents to check for and clean up any antifreeze leaks or spills, warning that it’s unclear whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate.

Greece’s Syriza government is set to accept another €86 billion bailout involving fresh austerity—VAT hikes, pension cuts, reduced farm subsidies, privatisations and market liberalisation—yet there have been no street protests even as tourism surges to a projected 25 million arrivals. Alexis Tsipras, once an opponent of such measures, has become a “TINA” disciple after July’s banking shutdown and economic collapse, and retains popularity despite failing to end fiscal austerity. Meanwhile, limited bank liquidity is choking businesses that rely on September–October credit for Christmas stock, deepening the economic squeeze. For this bailout to foster genuine recovery rather than mere reprieve, creditors—especially Germany—must show restraint and grant substantial debt relief.

Ross Kemp is reprising his role as Grant Mitchell in a brief return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara’s character, Peggy Mitchell, who reappeared to tell her son Phil that her cancer has returned and will die from the disease in spring. Kemp, who originally played Grant from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–2006, says he couldn’t turn down the chance to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for her farewell, while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins describes Grant’s homecoming as a chance to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden facing the loss of their mother in classic EastEnders drama.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles last October; her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, learned of her death when police knocked on their door and immediately feared it was Dhillon. At trial, it emerged that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice, and Hills recounted feeling guilty for having reassured her daughter that the police would handle the situation and for dismissing her sister Emma’s warning. Prof Ruggles admitted that they had underestimated the danger despite warning signs. In Alice’s memory, her parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking risks and celebrate her vibrant, smiling personality. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF’s board has approved financing the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somerset—one‐third funded by Chinese investors—only for Business Secretary Greg Clark to announce a fresh government review before formally backing the project, prompting EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a site visit. Supporters warn that further delay risks higher bills, reliance on dirty power and missed climate targets, while critics—including environmental groups and some EDF insiders who have resigned over financial and environmental risks—say costs may spiral, the deal props up politicians more than business and funds would be better spent on renewables. Hinkley Point C, slated to supply 7 percent of UK electricity, has been decades in planning, with key milestones from its 2006 government proposal to the 2013 strike-price agreement of £92.50/MWh and EDF’s July 2016 investment decision.

The new online divorce form for England and Wales now explicitly asks applicants to name the person with whom their spouse committed adultery—a change family lawyers warn will inject unnecessary conflict and complexity despite Ministry of Justice guidance stating there is no obligation to do so and that naming is “not normally necessary.” Critics such as Resolution vice-chair Margaret Heathcote and Vardags director Georgina Hamblin argue that the prominent adultery box will tempt heartbroken petitioners to name third parties, thereby making them co-respondents in the case, exposing them to paperwork, potential delays and extra costs. Although the previous form allowed optional naming of co-respondents, the new version more bluntly invites it, risking judges’ disapproval of attempts to embroil new partners in proceedings. In 2015 England and Wales saw just over 100,000 divorces, of which 12,148 cited adultery and 46,815 unreasonable behaviour, and petitioners must still choose one ground—such as adultery or unreasonable behaviour—to prove the marriage has irretrievably broken down.

In Wales, where conifer forests have underpinned a £450 million‐a‐year timber industry, commercial growers and the forestry lobby Confor warn that more than 16,000 ha of productive woodland have been lost since 2001 and urgently need replanting to meet market demand—yet ministers and conservationists have focused on environmental goals, favoring native broadleaves and public access over timber production. Half of Welsh woodland is state‐managed and half privately owned, and while rural harvest and transport can spark local conflicts, the Welsh government seeks to balance economic, social and environmental aims through its Woodlands for Wales strategy and the Glastir planting scheme. Confor’s Martin Bishop argues that bureaucratic hurdles mean only 90 ha of new woodland were planted last year against a ministerial target of 20,000 ha, despite strong demand from sawmills that would expand output if sufficient timber were available.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at about 16:40, and was taken by emergency crews to Glasgow’s Queen Elizabeth University Hospital where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Russian Ushakov medals to surviving veterans of the World War II Arctic Convoys—vessels that sailed from Britain to northern Russia under constant threat from German U-boats, aircraft, storms, ice and extreme cold—to repay the Soviet Union for weapons and ammunition that helped beat Germany on the Eastern Front. More than 3,000 seamen died and by May 1945 the route had lost 104 merchant and 16 military ships. The Foreign Office originally blocked the awards—its rules forbade British servicemen from receiving foreign medals for actions more than five years old—until in 2012 it created the Arctic Star for convoy service and, following a campaign, granted an exception. President Vladimir Putin delivered the first Ushakov medals in London on 16 June 2013, recognizing the veterans’ courage in what Winston Churchill called “the worst journey in the world.”
