HM Inspectorate of Probation’s report on community payback’s unpaid-work sentences—ranging from 40 to 300 hours for offences such as shoplifting, theft, drug offences or criminal damage—found systemic delays in getting offenders started, frequent failures to enforce attendance (in one case, just 16 of 200 required hours completed over 17 months), and an overemphasis on punishment rather than rehabilitation. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases, interviewed 86 offenders, and issued 15 recommendations, including reducing unnecessary turn-aways when offenders report on time and tailoring work objectives to individual circumstances. While praising some high-quality work and offenders’ positive attitudes and skill gains, the chief inspector warned that many schemes still lack basic delivery and enforcement. The Ministry of Justice has accepted the recommendations and is taking steps to ensure more effective rehabilitation through timely attendance enforcement and appropriate sanctions.

The article describes how The Sun branded comedian Russell Brand a “hypocrite” for advocating economic and political revolution on behalf of the poor while living in a spacious, upscale London home—a charge he’s faced repeatedly. When asked by a journalist about his own rent while protesting near Downing Street against the displacement of estate residents, Brand rebuffed the question and later responded with the hashtag #TheSunLogic. Although he ignored inquiries about suing the paper, he has publicly acknowledged his wealth, fame and past “daft things” under capitalism, insisted that true change requires both personal and systemic transformation, and argued that dismissing his calls to address widening inequality serves to keep the issue off the agenda.

J. Craig Venter, a brash biologist and entrepreneur, transformed gene mapping into a competitive race, first accelerating genome sequencing by focusing on RNA rather than whole DNA, then founding The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992 after leaving the NIH, where in 1995 he published the first complete genome of a free-living microbe. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years, publishing alongside the publicly funded effort in 2001. With substantial personal wealth from his ventures, he established the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006, pursuing projects from the Sorcerer II ocean-microbe expedition to creating Synthia, the first synthetic life form, which he and his team described in Science and hailed as a potential driver of a new industrial revolution via engineered microbes capable of environmental repair and bio-manufacturing.

A survey of about 1,000 English parents (628 of whom had children eating school lunches) found that 80% of those children tried at least one new food at school and 50% of parents were asked to prepare school-lunch dishes at home; the most popular vegetables served were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least favored. Commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet poll suggested fussy eaters prompted packed lunches, the research echoes Trust chairman Rob Rees’s view that school meals help expand children’s diets and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton’s observation of positive peer pressure and improved menu variety. School lunches must now meet strict nutritional standards, and about 40% of primary and slightly fewer secondary pupils in England—and 46% in Scotland—choose to eat them.

Álvaro Morata, the 23-year-old Spain striker at Euro 2016, moved from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 after rising through Real’s youth ranks and scoring 10 first-team goals; the deal included a buy-back option of up to €30 million. At Juventus he netted 27 goals over two seasons, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, appeared in the 2015 Champions League final (scoring in the 3-1 loss to Barcelona) after featuring as a substitute in Real’s 2014 triumph, and has already scored three times for Spain in France.

Wilson returned to Championship club Nottingham Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5 million, making 51 appearances in his second stint after already spending four seasons at the City Ground before moving to Celtic; the 30-year-old, who has also played for Preston North End and Notts County, was released in May and is currently without a club.

Tesco has agreed to sell its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to private equity firm Yucaipa for an orderly exit from the US market, transferring about 4,000 of the chain’s 5,000 employees and closing roughly 50 of its 200 California, Nevada and Arizona stores. Under the deal Tesco will lend the new business around £80 million, incur a £150 million disposal cost (part of which could be repaid), and retain an option to buy back a stake if Yucaipa—led by billionaire investor Ron Burkle—turns the business profitable. Earlier this year Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.
He overcame early racial abuse, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for an Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

French Alps glaciers have shrunk markedly over the past four decades, declining from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to roughly 275 sq km by the late 2000s—a loss of some 26 percent—according to a new inventory of around 600 glaciers from massifs including Mont Blanc, Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye and Grande Rousse Arves. Produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues at the University of Savoie using historical maps, aerial photos and satellite imagery verified by manual delineation, the survey shows that by 1985–86 area had already fallen to about 340 sq km despite a brief advance in the late 1970s/early 1980s. Retreat has been strongest in southern sectors—Belledonne’s glaciers have nearly vanished and Ecrins is receding over three times faster than Mont Blanc—likely due to lower elevations and drier, sunnier climate, whereas the northern Alps, which receive more precipitation and cloud cover, have seen less loss (La Mer de Glace declined from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km). Similar accelerated retreat has also been reported elsewhere in the Alps.

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five of their Euro qualifying matches and face fellow unbeaten side Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, where a win would all but secure their place at next summer’s finals in the Netherlands; Iceland, ranked 20th to Scotland’s 21st, sit level on points after four victories, and these encounters will likely decide the group winner. Captain Evans—fresh from winning the Frauen-Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and one of 12 squad members playing abroad—stressed the importance of reaching a first major finals after successive play-off defeats and praised the benefits of international experience, noting that with the best six of eight runners-up also qualifying automatically, Scotland are in a strong position.

Stuart Campbell, the Stirling-born, Bath-based blogger and former games reviewer behind the pro-Scottish-independence site Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in western England on Friday following a south London woman’s complaint that he had harassed her via tweets over a two-year period; released on bail until mid-September, he insists the tweets—still publicly visible—were not threatening, criticizes media “innuendo” and says there’s nothing more “sinister or serious” alleged than some harmless tweets.

PETA has proposed replacing Skegness’s century-old Jolly Fisherman mascot—originally commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote seaside train excursions with the slogan “Skegness is so bracing”—with a fish and the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice,” arguing that the current figure “evokes images of cruelty to animals” through practices like netting and impalement. Skegness mayor Carl Macey, however, maintains that the mascot is widely loved by both adults and children, does not convey cruelty, and will remain unless the council decides otherwise, following PETA’s suggestion.

Scotland recovered from an early Georgian try by Vasil Lobzhanidze to dominate possession and territory, running in six tries to Georgia’s two in a one-sided Test at Murrayfield. Tommy Seymour capitalised on Stuart Hogg’s clever kick to score Scotland’s first, Laidlaw added the touchline conversion, and a haul-down of a maul led to a penalty try and sin-binning for Georgia’s lock Kote Mikautadze. Sean Maitland, Hogg (twice), Hamish Watson and a late counter finished by Hogg again extended the margin, with Greig Laidlaw highly accurate off the tee. Georgia grabbed a second Lobzhanidze try from a powerful scrum effort and kicked a couple of penalties, but Scotland substitutes Ali Price, Rory Hughes and Hogg sealed the emphatic win. Head coach Vern Cotter praised his side’s game management, defensive work and continual improvement.

Widnes built a 14-6 half-time lead through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Justin Ah Van and Chris Bridge (Castleford’s lone first-half score coming from loanee Paddy Flynn) and extended it early in the second half with another Flynn reply followed by efforts from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor to lead 38-12. Although Castleford struck back with three tries in four minutes—Larne Patrick (who has just signed a three-year deal from Huddersfield), Luke Gale and Flynn’s hat-trick—the Vikings held on. Mellor’s break from a short kickoff had pushed Widnes’s margin to 26 points and despite Castleford’s late rally they suffered a fourth straight home defeat. Widnes moved into seventh place, leapfrogging Wakefield, while Castleford remained sixth, one point ahead. Referee: J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo since 2002 on suspected al-Qaeda and Taliban ties he denies, was released after a US Periodic Review Board found he no longer posed a significant threat; he challenged his detention in the Supreme Court and left aboard a Kuwaiti government plane, bound for at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center, marking the first release since the Taliban-for-Bergdahl swap in May and reducing Guantanamo’s population to 148.

DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character created by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, released the minute-long song “PPAP (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen),” featuring simple lyrics about combining a pen with an apple and a pineapple, an addictive beat and a basic dance routine. Uploaded to Piko-Taro’s YouTube channel, it quickly went viral on Facebook—his original video surpassed 4 million views while 9GAG’s repost reached over 44 million—prompting both amusement and annoyance among viewers. Despite limited coverage in Japanese media and little domestic social-media buzz, the song has inspired hundreds of tributes and covers worldwide, from Japanese pop duos to heavy-metal and international influencers, earning Piko-Taro comparisons to Psy.

Thousands gathered at Hyde Park Corner for an early morning Anzac Day service, while about 400 people paraded to the Cenotaph for wreath-laying, prayers read by schoolchildren and the playing of the Australian, New Zealand and British national anthems. Anzac Day marks the first major engagement of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War I at Gallipoli, where an eight-month campaign sought to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war and became one of the conflict’s bloodiest. Services in London date back to 1916, when King George V attended Westminster Abbey a year after the Gallipoli landings, and have grown into a key commemoration for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders. At this year’s dawn service, Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer laid a wreath and reflected on the courage and sacrifice of Anzac troops “fighting for God, King and empire, for their mates, for adventure, for a world without war.”

Michael Clarkson, 30, rejoined St Mirren in July for a second spell and could make his debut in Saturday’s Championship fixture against Alloa after scoring nine goals for Dundee last season and featuring mainly as a substitute this term. He has maintained his match fitness by playing with the U20s and insists he is “as fit as I’ve ever been,” ready to slot into the first team. Clarkson, who earned two Scotland caps in 2008—scoring once—and has nearly 400 senior club appearances with former spells at Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers, joins a St Mirren side sitting eighth in the table, seven points clear of bottom club Alloa, with ambitions to build confidence through victories and push up the standings.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, who has guaranteed that all existing pension arrangements—specifically the alternative scheme for members of the closed 2004 final-salary plan—will be honoured; Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed productive talks with Boparan’s team at Great Witchingham, where assurances were also given that Boparan intends to restore profitability through fresh investment, cost savings and by using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

Council leader Dave Stewart announced that crossings at Cowes will be free until 2 July to acknowledge the ferry’s troubled launch—since its 14 May debut the chain ferry has broken down, run aground and been suspended over training concerns, and vehicles have been damaged embarking. The council has commissioned an audit review of the project. Shopkeeper Angie Booth warned that nearly six months of lost trade threaten local businesses and asked about compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said is under discussion. Ward described the vessel as a prototype with expected teething troubles—electrical faults have been fixed, ramp extensions were approved to prevent scraping, and seamanship issues causing groundings have been addressed.

The House of Lords European Union Committee warns that while Britain’s fishing communities supported Brexit to escape the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and reclaim control of UK waters, the sector’s small economic footprint and shared fish stocks with other coastal states mean it could be sidelined in trade talks and may have to concede EU-registered vessels access in exchange for tariff-free market entry. Although Brexit offers the promise of managing a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, the report stresses the need to retain CFP-style scientific quota setting, honor international cooperation, and avoid fragmenting fisheries management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Recent CFP quota gains for the UK have sparked industry optimism, while the government signals its intent to balance single-market access with a revamped, sustainable fisheries regime.

Timothy Geaney admitted that between April 2004 and February 2014 he took or allowed photographs of young boys in partially dressed erotic poses, prompting a community payback order, placement on the sex offenders register and participation in a specialist programme; a General Teaching Council Scotland panel found his actions—characterized by a prolonged pattern of behaviour, lack of remedial steps and high risk of recurrence—“fundamentally incompatible” with teaching standards, ruled him unfit to teach, removed him from the professional register and barred him from re-registration for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site after a 2 March blaze that disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Although Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service—whose officers visited nine times in the past year—found the Asset and Land Group-run site “broadly compliant” with fire safety law, it raised concerns with the Environment Agency in February about risks to residents, transport and the environment. Following joint EA–fire‐service inspections, the EA suspended the facility from accepting waste and announced on appealable notice that its environmental permit will be revoked on 7 August, after which the company must cease operations and remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is striving to meet its UN- and OPCW-backed timetable for destroying some 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its full stockpile—only about 30 tonnes (4 percent) has left the country—and facing attacks on shipments en route to Latakia, which he blamed on “terrorist groups.” He rejected US criticism of government barrel-bomb attacks—condemned by the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which reports dozens of civilian deaths in Aleppo—and denied rebel claims of seizing Aleppo’s central prison, insisting security forces had repelled the assault even as opposition sources say they now control it. While Russia urges Syria to complete transfers by 1 March and destroy all weapons by end-June, US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has warned the plan is falling behind, but Damascus insists it remains committed to its obligations.

England crushed Pakistan by their second-biggest ever margin in runs at Old Trafford to level the series after innings of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared set up victory, restricting Pakistan to 198 and 234. Joe Root, elevated to number three, was named man of the match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls, plus four catches and a wicket, while Alastair Cook made 105 and 76 not out. England’s batting depth and disciplined bowling on a placid pitch earned praise from Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott, who predicted Pakistan’s spirits were broken. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq lamented poor shot selection and confidence issues; only he and Asad Shafiq have passed fifty so far. Before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August, Pakistan face a two-day tour match against Worcestershire.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales by gathering first-hand experiences from residents, their families and friends, care providers, social care staff and public bodies. Having witnessed both high-quality and poor care—and noting unacceptable variations—she aims to issue recommendations that ensure accountability and improve factors such as residents’ physical and psychological health, social relationships and living environments. While Care Forum Wales endorses the review’s objectives, its chair Mario Kreft criticizes the absence of any care-home providers, managers, staff or residents on the main advisory panel, arguing that this omission undermines sector engagement and partnership working.

Former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, who has served as player-manager at Arbroath (the Red Lichties) since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen after a “comprehensive process” led by boss Derek McInnes, with Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser praising Arbroath chairman John Christison’s support of Sheerin’s return; Sheerin, who also featured for several Scottish clubs and Sweden’s Östersunds and earned a Scotland under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division and promotion in 2011 but was relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013-14.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will oversee Saturday’s match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s dismissal as Swansea seek to appoint former Derby manager Paul Clement to steer them clear of relegation. Curtis warned that dropping into the Championship would make an immediate return difficult, noting stronger competition and the challenge of retaining top players. He reflected on Swansea’s rise from near-bankruptcy and League Two relegation to Premier League promotion in 2011, lauding eras under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup as true to the “Swansea Way,” which he feels has since been diluted through frequent managerial changes and insufficient player replacements. Confident the current squad can survive, Curtis also stresses to new signings the importance of preserving the club’s hard-earned status and its impact on the local community, referencing the “Jack to a King” documentary to impart that history.

J. Craig Venter transformed genome research by racing to map the human genome privately after pioneering high-speed sequencing via RNA sampling, a move that shocked and outraged parts of the scientific community but accelerated progress; born in 1946, he turned from a carefree youth and Vietnam naval orderly to a driven researcher, excelling at NIH before founding The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992 and later Celera Genomics, whose 2001 human genome publication rivaled the public project. Unconstrained by traditional funding, Venter went on to establish the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2006, lead the global marine microbial sampling aboard his yacht Sorcerer II, and in 2010 announce Synthia, the first synthetic life form, a breakthrough he predicts could spark a new industrial revolution by enabling microbes to produce useful compounds, reduce oil dependence and capture carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust’s study, carried out by Boston Consulting Group, finds that England’s apprenticeships lag behind those in countries like Germany and Switzerland in quality, duration and uptake: of the 520,000 annual starts in England fewer than 200,000 are at level 3 (A-level equivalent), only one in five employers offer apprenticeships (versus 51% in Germany), and just 61,000 new starts are for young people (compared with 570,000 in Germany, 90% at A-level equivalent). Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level 3 and three-quarters have gone to over-25s, leaving 11 young people competing for each place. England’s system also features 18,000 different vocational qualifications against Germany’s 330, creating a confusing “patchwork” that Sir Peter Lampl warns devalues routes outside university. The report calls for a radical expansion to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually—mostly three-year level 3 courses and some four-year level 4 programmes—capping two-year level 2 schemes at 10%, while preserving industry-respected level 2 qualifications. The Association of Colleges agrees on prioritising level 3 but cautions that creating 300,000 places poses a major challenge, and the Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to last at least a year, include more English and maths, and meet employers’ needs.

Storey won the time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska, and can claim a 17th world title in Saturday’s road race; at 37 she is aiming for more Paralympic success in Rio, is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) in cycling and swimming across six Games, won four golds at London 2012, has 21 world titles, and began her career in the pool—winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics—before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, recently relegated from the Football League, saw their financial troubles deepen after failing to meet successive deadlines to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, leading to their expulsion from the Conference Premier on 10 June despite a last-day survival on the pitch; their supporters’ trust had offered to buy the club for £1 and clear £220,000 of debt, but club chairman David Keyte instead accepted takeover terms from businessman Tommy Agombar, yet the Bulls still owe over £70,000 in taxes, have seen dwindling attendances since 2012, and now lose their place to reformed Chester FC while key players and staff pursue unpaid wages.

The passage outlines that the 30-year-old former Manchester City player earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, was part of two World Cup and two European Championship squads (though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016), and announced his departure citing “common sense” while wishing Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success. He also holds the England Under-21 appearance record with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, who died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, was a pioneering conductor and keyboardist renowned for advancing historically informed performance. In 1973 he founded and led the Academy of Ancient Music for some 30 years, recording over 200 period-instrument CDs—including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle—and producing landmark interpretations such as the 1980 Handel Messiah. Educated at Cambridge under Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, he began his career with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell, and was celebrated by colleagues and soloists for his generosity, intelligence, and commitment to letting music “speak for itself.” A private funeral will be followed by a memorial service.

A boy from Northern Ireland whose family chose to remain anonymous was withdrawn from mainstream school in June because he was struggling, and despite a request for a special school placement the South Eastern Education Board area has been at capacity with no timeline for availability. His mother, who left her job to care for him, says he feels isolated watching his siblings attend school, and although an extra classroom assistant has been added at a nearby special school with hopes he’ll start in the coming weeks, she fears other families will face the same overcrowding. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case for privacy reasons but said it is reviewing special school place needs across Northern Ireland to improve access from 2016 onward.

The Welsh Rugby Union has launched a takeover bid for Rodney Parade tenants Newport Gwent Dragons and plans to vote on it on 9 May, despite Newport County’s existing lease giving them fixture primacy through 2023 and protecting both the football club and the on-site squash club; WRU chair Will Godfrey acknowledges those contracts even as the union signals its intention to install an artificial pitch contrary to Football League regulations. On the field, County—promoted to the Football League in 2013 under a 10-year stadium lease—sit two points clear of League Two relegation with two games to play, having won six of their last ten under caretaker manager Mike Flynn, but face a potentially “devastating” drop back to the National League if they fail to secure survival this weekend and rivals Hartlepool win.

A Sierra Leonean man recounts being abducted at 15 by RUF rebels during the 1991–2002 civil war, forced to commit atrocities under threats and drug influence, branding himself with “RUF” and witnessing horrific violence, before escaping to Freetown, where he was imprisoned for pickpocketing. In jail he met Richard Cole, founder of Lifeline Nehemiah, who encouraged him to resume his education, embrace faith, and help rebuild his country. When Ebola struck Sierra Leone in 2014, he and his team—with local chiefs’ support—launched community education in Temne, Krio and Limba for over 10,000 people, delivered food to 11,000 households and established an Ebola treatment unit, collectively saving many lives amid widespread fear and misconceptions. Now transformed, he regrets his past, champions youth investment for national renewal, and notes the regional toll of 11,314 Ebola deaths (3,955 in Sierra Leone, 4,808 in Liberia, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, plus one in the US and six in Mali).

A planned auction of about 80,000 Wedgwood works—art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs—intended to pay off the pottery firm’s pension debt was averted when a public fundraising campaign launched in September met its target within a month; administrators Begbies Traynor will keep the collection on display at the Barlaston museum, the Art Fund will gift it to the Victoria and Albert Museum, and it will then be loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrator Bob Young praised the collaborative effort that enabled the sale’s cancellation, while Alison Wedgwood and MP Tristram Hunt highlighted the collection’s importance to Staffordshire and Britain’s cultural heritage.

Billericay Town, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points shy of a play-off place under new owner Glenn Tamplin—who invests £10,000 a week—may soon see former non-league player and 2011 I’m A Celebrity runner-up Shaun Wright buy a 20% stake and join the board, though the finer details of the deal have yet to be revealed; the club, taken over by multi-millionaire Tamplin, also signed ex-England international Paul Konchesky in March.

After Brexit, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney surprised observers by opting for a one-year extension to his term—pushing his departure from 2018 to 2019—instead of the originally discussed full eight-year term to 2021. While speculation suggested political pressure or disillusionment with the UK’s economic outlook might have influenced him, Carney revealed that personal reasons—chiefly his daughters’ critical school years and the family’s desire to return to Canada’s education system—were decisive. He emphasized his commitment to devote full attention to the role through 2019, after which a new governor would oversee post-Article 50 economic strategy, and dismissed any tension with government or criticism of pre-referendum forecasts.

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1-1 draw at Bloomfield Road, with Nathan Delfouneso’s chipped cross finding Jamille Matt to open the scoring after 12 minutes before Kurtis Guthrie levelled from close range following a corner scramble. Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe made several crucial saves—denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi among others—while Tom Aldred headed narrowly over late on when unmarked. Colchester finished with ten men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health and piloted in five schools, teaches P6 and P7 pupils how to manage stress and change—particularly the pressures of transfer tests and moving to secondary school—through interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, teach breathing and relaxation exercises, encourage seeking help, and train teachers in basic mental-health support. Launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan, the initiative addresses rising anxiety among children and parents around the transition from a close-knit primary environment to larger secondary settings. With 14,681 pupils sitting unofficial transfer tests this year—a slight increase on 2015—programme chief executive David Babington and Carrick’s pastoral care co-ordinator Helen Hamilton emphasize the value of early coping strategies, while chief inspector Noelle Buick underscores the broader need to strengthen young people’s resilience through enhanced preventative education in Northern Ireland’s pastoral care curriculum.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley oil-fired power station—commissioned in 1971, capable of powering one million homes, and closed in 2013—into a £1 billion “merchant city” centered on its 198 m chimney topped by a petal-shaped glass structure, with a marina, housing, restaurants and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth; outline planning permission is due later this year, and construction could begin in 2018.

Lewis Latham won Britain’s second medal at the Hong Kong championships with a late charge to take bronze behind Poland’s Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany’s Lucass Liss (silver) in the men’s scratch, while the GB men’s team pursuit lost out on bronze to Italy and the women’s quartet of Elinor Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson placed fifth in their heats. Joe Truman failed to advance from the men’s keirin semi-final, and 24-year-old Katy Marchant, 16th in the women’s sprint qualifier, was knocked out in the first round by China’s Lin Junhong but will contest the 500m time-trial and keirin later. Quoting Latham, he “was in a decent position most of the time” and timed his sprint perfectly; Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised his tactics, while Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted the youth and future potential of their squad.

Ross Kemp is set to make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Peggy Mitchell’s final storyline after her surprise reappearance to announce her cancer had returned; Peggy, who first left in 2010, will die from the disease in emotional scenes airing in spring. Kemp, who originally portrayed Grant from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–2006, says reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother “felt right,” while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins describes the storyline as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden (Phil Mitchell) “at their very best” as they face losing their mother.

Sadio Mané’s quick double in 138 seconds consigned Mauricio Pochettino’s Tottenham to a dispiriting Anfield defeat, highlighting the side’s alarming lack of desire and away form—with just two wins since late September and only one victory in 17 top-six away clashes—undermining their Premier League challenge and allowing Chelsea the chance to stretch their lead to 12 points; former midfielder Danny Murphy added that Tottenham’s shift from a successful back three to a back four exposed defensive frailties, a lack of pace and the wrong mindset on the road.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of 28 governorships in Saturday’s elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and coming on the heels of the PDP’s first presidential loss last month to Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP managed only eight governorships, largely in the south-east, with Rivers State its sole hold in the oil hub, while results in Taraba remain outstanding and Imo was declared inconclusive. The APC’s victories extended through most northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna, and the commercial centre Lagos, though it failed to capture any of the five main oil-producing states—a concern given the potential for militant disruption of oil revenues. Despite some violence in southern areas, overall polling was more peaceful than in past elections, suggesting a maturing democracy. The PDP now faces internal reflection and reorganization after 16 years of rule, defections to the APC and corruption and security criticisms eroded its national appeal.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is introducing an augmented-reality app that lets visitors scan signs and posters to access online videos, band interviews and other content on their phones or tablets. Headliners include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan says the app enhances the on-site experience and enables people worldwide to engage with the festival atmosphere, access updated information, buy tickets and view interviews before and during the event.

Ofsted has rated Birmingham’s Park View and Nansen Primary academies as inadequate and the Department for Education has issued notices under their funding agreements, threatening to terminate them unless the Park View Educational Trust and Nansen’s trust respond by 4 July; similar warnings were sent to Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, which must address issues such as discrimination, gender segregation and a narrow curriculum or face de‐funding. These actions follow publication of 21 reports into alleged “Trojan Horse” attempts to impose a hardline Muslim ethos in local schools, with head teachers reporting parental intimidation during inspections and a culture of fear. Park View is also accused of failing to safeguard pupils by hosting extremist speakers at Islamic‐themed assemblies. Birmingham City Council will appoint a temporary governing board at Saltley School, also in special measures, while school leaders and parents—some of whom accuse Ofsted of bias—promise to challenge the findings and work toward improvement.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a 38-year-old British-Iranian charity worker, was arrested at Tehran airport last April and sentenced in September to five years in prison on undisclosed charges of plotting to topple the Iranian government; her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran under her grandparents’ care after her passport was confiscated. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizes the UK government for failing to secure her release and says her appeal, held secretly in Tehran, offers an unpredictable outcome that could see her sentence quashed, reduced or increased. He reports that Nazanin endured solitary confinement—where she attempted a hunger strike and felt suicidal—until being moved out over Christmas, and that Gabriella, whom he watches grow via Skype, has lost her English in favor of Farsi. Amnesty International has declared her a prisoner of conscience and urged her immediate release.

Vincent “Vinnie” Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. At Ipswich Crown Court, the prosecution alleges that optometrist Honey Rose failed to detect and refer his swollen optic discs, a lapse they say allowed a build-up of fluid in his brain that raised skull pressure and caused his death. They argue her conduct fell so far below acceptable professional standards that it amounts to gross negligence manslaughter, a charge Rose denies. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he arranged via an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014, and of sending sexually explicit images to her sister and father on Christmas Day 2014. He was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to the seriousness of his offences. The victim described feeling “blackmailed,” and Sheriff George Way, supported by Lady Wolffe’s remark that the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence, noted Weatherhogg’s moderate risk of reoffending despite his lack of prior convictions.

Opener Stuart Thompson’s 56 propelled Ireland to 165-5 in Greater Noida after Paul Stirling’s first-ball duck, with Gary Wilson (41*), captain William Porterfield (39) and Thompson steadying the innings; Afghanistan chased successfully in 18 overs thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56, Mohammad Shahzad’s 47 and a 51-run opening stand with Najeeb Tarakai, finishing on 171-4, while Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the only bowler with multiple wickets (2-23). Ireland captain Porterfield lamented falling short of the 180 target and a lackluster bowling performance, compounded by paceman Boyd Rankin’s back injury ruling him out of the T20s (he’s expected back for the five ODIs from March 15), and the teams will meet again in the second T20 on Friday at the same venue.

Barcelona has paid a total of £106.8 m to sign Neymar—£48.6 m initial fee to Santos, £34 m to his parents, plus signing-on, wages and agent fees—and insists it committed no tax offence, though it has made an additional €13.55 m tax declaration “to defend the club’s reputation” amid differing interpretations of its fiscal obligations. A Spanish judge recently found sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer, and former president Sandro Rosell, who denies wrongdoing, resigned last month over related accusations. Neymar, 22, has since scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September, and Thai police have charged two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, with conspiracy to murder, rape and robbery, alleging they confessed and that DNA from Witheridge matched the suspects. Metropolitan Police detectives traveled to Thailand to review the investigation, thank the Thai authorities for their cooperation and will now return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims’ families. The UK Foreign Office had previously expressed concerns over DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects, and the visit was agreed after Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha met UK Prime Minister David Cameron in Italy. Post-mortems found Miller died from drowning and a head injury, and Witheridge from fatal head wounds.

Virtual reality is increasingly being used beyond gaming to foster understanding, sell products, train professionals and enrich education. In the UK, the National Autistic Society created a VR film simulating sensory overload for autistic people, touring shopping centres and supplying schools with teaching packs, while Alzheimer’s Research UK released “A Walk Through Dementia” to demonstrate daily challenges of dementia. Retailers such as IKEA and Westfield employ VR headsets to let customers virtually tour kitchens and fashion collections, even adding virtual meatballs when users requested more interactivity. In healthcare, Dr. Shafi Ahmed live-streamed virtual surgery to 5,000 viewers and now offers training via Virtual Surgeon, while studies in the US show VR can help soldiers with PTSD and arachnophobics confront fears. In education, Google Expeditions and startups like Evanescent Studios are using VR to take pupils on virtual field trips—from the Great Barrier Reef to Mars—and to practice languages in immersive settings, though schools face cost and technology barriers before widespread adoption.

The black box of the Russian Su-24 jet shot down on November 24 was opened in Moscow, but investigators led by Nikolai Primak reported that flight information appeared missing; analysis results are due next week and may clarify whether the jet was in Turkish or Syrian airspace when hit by Turkish F-16s. The incident, which killed the pilot (apparently by ground militants) while the navigator was rescued—and also cost the life of a Russian marine and a helicopter—has sparked a diplomatic crisis: Turkey maintains the jet ignored airspace warnings, Russia insists it was over Syria, and President Putin has accused Ankara of subservience to the US and “creeping Islamisation.” In retaliation, Moscow has demanded an apology and imposed sanctions on Turkey, including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions.

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five Euro qualifiers so far and face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with victory likely to seal qualification for next summer’s finals in the Netherlands; after play‐off heartbreak for Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup, forward Julie Fleeting “Evans” stresses how devastating another near miss would be. Ranked 21st to Iceland’s 20th, both sides are unbeaten, and their two fixtures will probably decide group winners, though Scotland could still qualify as one of the top six runners‐up. Evans, who won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich in her first season and formerly starred with Glasgow City and Turbine Potsdam, highlights that 12 of Scotland’s 20‐player squad play abroad—in England, Sweden or the US—bringing high‐level experience and different styles that boost the national side.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform’s review, led by Prof Kenneth Gibb, concludes that the council tax has been flawed from its inception and that no single solution exists to resolve its built-in defects; while property taxes—favored for their stability and market impacts—cause confusion over whether they reflect wealth or service charges and are seen as unfair by those on low incomes, local income taxes are viewed as fairer but produce volatile revenues and limit local rate-setting. Acknowledging reform’s complexity and the legacy of past changes, the commission will hold a public consultation across Scotland before publishing its final report in the autumn, which the Scottish government—considering the current system unjust—eagerly awaits.

Apple has extended its two-step verification to iCloud backups in response to third-party tools—most notably Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker—being used to pilfer celebrities’ private photos, meaning that after entering a username and password on an unrecognized device, users must input a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone or via Find My iPhone (or use a 14-character recovery key), and they now receive email alerts whenever a backup download begins; although this safeguard remains optional and some security specialists urge Apple (and other tech firms) to enable two-factor authentication by default, Apple says it will “more aggressively encourage” users to adopt stronger passwords and two-step verification to bolster account security.

UKIP topped the May election while spending £2,956,737 on its campaign (23 January–22 May), or 68p per vote for its 4,376,635 votes. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), Labour £1,027,339 (26p per vote) and the Liberal Democrats £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote), losing 11 of their 12 MEPs. The Greens spent £534,249 (43p per vote for 1,255,573 votes) and the SNP £267,372. Overall, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087, and all but Labour increased their outlay compared with 2009.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals the Gulls and could face his former club on February 18; the ex-Aldershot and Exeter defender, who has also played in Italy, was signed for his leadership qualities, while 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating—recommended by Micky Adams after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps—is joining pending international clearance; manager Kevin Nicholson says Anderson brings stature and leadership and Keating is hungry to prove himself as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with just one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, collapsed and died of a severe pulmonary hemorrhage after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff treated him on course but he was pronounced dead shortly afterward. The British Horseracing Authority’s acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, noted such hemorrhages are rare and can occur in otherwise healthy sport horses. Although Many Clouds had previously shown post-race ataxia—overheating and wobbling—especially after his Grand National win, he displayed no such symptoms on the day and had never collapsed before. His notable victories included the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014 and the Gold Cup trial in 2015, leading his trainer to call him the “horse of a lifetime.” 2389fdsi2389432ksad

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond delivered their valedictory speeches ahead of the 5 May election, joining Salmond and Annabel Goldie in standing down. McNeil, who has served since 1999, warned that Holyrood must strengthen its committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny, learning lessons from Westminster. Salmond echoed themes from his first parliamentary speech, asserting that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” praising the devolution of powers under the Scotland Bill while arguing it fell short of referendum promises, and closed by calling membership of Holyrood the highest public honour. Goldie quipped about missing exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon and due in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, will feature an unnamed star as Mrs Potts (the teapot once voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury), Oscar winner Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston and Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou; filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service will inform Hillsborough victims’ relatives at an 11:00 BST meeting in Warrington of its charging decisions after 96 football fans were unlawfully killed at the 1989 FA Cup semi-final in Sheffield. Inquests last year ruled the deaths unlawful, and in January evidence files on 23 suspects—15 from Operation Resolve into the disaster’s causes and eight from an IPCC probe into police conduct—were sent to the CPS. Sue Hemming, head of CPS special crime and counter-terrorism, will announce whether charges follow, bringing families, led by Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, closer to long-awaited accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of contraband—particularly mobile phones and synthetic cannabis—being thrown over its walls, according to both the prison and a former inmate who also alleged drones were used to deliver items, though the Ministry of Justice found no evidence of drone deliveries. Residents nearby report seeing packages hurled over the wall multiple times, prompting the prison to host an evening meeting for locals on how to respond. The Ministry of Justice says staff are working hard to intercept contraband and that the Justice Secretary is exploring additional tools to tackle the issue, while a new law allows up to two years’ imprisonment for those caught smuggling items into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old longtime “lollipop lady,” was left with serious head injuries last December after Brian Wright, 55, ran a red light outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston and struck her with his VW Golf. Wright, who says he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall the light’s color, accepts hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies dangerous driving. Now in residential care, Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road when the collision occurred. At Luton Crown Court, Wright expressed remorse for upending her life and that of her family; the trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir has decided to miss next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine exams in May conflict with the team’s preparation, despite having finished fourth in the 1,500m and sixth in the 5,000m at last year’s World Championships. The 24-year-old returns to university immediately to complete her final year but remains committed to representing Scotland when possible. She believes she has two or three more Olympic cycles left and is eyeing the World Indoor Championships in March—potentially in Birmingham—while noting she feels in reasonable shape. Most recently, Muir set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m against tough competition that included gold medalist Hellen Obiri.

In December 2000, 22-year-old Trevor Deely vanished while walking home from a Christmas party; this weekend Gardaí began excavations across three acres of woodland beside Dublin’s R112 near the River Liffey, with searches expected to last weeks. Earlier in the year a six-detective team reexamined his case, enhancing CCTV from the night he disappeared that shows him speaking to a man in black outside his Baggot Street workplace and later being followed by what detectives believe is the same individual on Haddington Road. Released in April, the footage has yet to yield the man’s identity, and Gardaí have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martín del Potro, ranked 165th after over two years out with wrist injuries, beat Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6(2) 6-3 to reach the Wimbledon third round, where he will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young; the 27-year-old former world No. 4, who last reached a Grand Slam semi-final at Wimbledon in 2013, described the win as rejuvenating. In the same half as Andy Murray, Australia’s Nick Kyrgios recovered from two sets to one down, with rain interruptions, to defeat Dustin Brown 6-7(3) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 and set up a third-round tie with Feliciano López—who fought back from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini—while the winner will then face Murray or John Millman. Meanwhile, 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga recorded straight-sets victories over Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco respectively.

Tunisia and Morocco both secured their places in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after clearing disputes with CAF: Tunisia, initially threatened with expulsion for lodging post-match protests over a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final defeat to hosts Equatorial Guinea, formally apologised after meetings with CAF president Issa Hayatou; Morocco, banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola‐related health concerns, had its suspension lifted and a US$1 million fine reduced to US$50 000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Equatorial Guinea ultimately stepped in to stage the 2015 finals on just 64 days’ notice. Tunisian FA vice-president Maher Snoussi and Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa both expressed optimism for the future, and, following last week’s qualifying draw in Cairo, Tunisia will contest Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti and could record a 13th consecutive finals appearance, while Morocco joins Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F.

Once a dominant force with 182 Grand Prix victories, 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ championships—including the unrivalled 1988 season with Senna and Prost—McLaren has cycled through peaks (Fittipaldi in 1974, Hunt in 1976, Hakkinen in 1998–99, Hamilton in 2008) and troughs. After losing its chassis edge in 2013 and reuniting with Honda engines—once the source of its greatest success—it now struggles for mid-grid points despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, at the wheel. Team principal Ron Dennis insists recent chassis gains and forthcoming Honda power-unit improvements will restore McLaren to title contention.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police found several patrons still there, with till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. At Limavady Magistrates Court, licensee Colleen O’Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. A defence solicitor admitted the bar had not adhered to local licensing laws and had been operating into the early morning. The judge, citing O’Neill’s “appalling record,” ordered the premises closed for three months and fined her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry set a new NBA single-season record by making eight 3-pointers (surpassing his previous mark of 272) en route to 45 points and nine assists, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers, with Klay Thompson adding 26 points after they trailed by 13. Portland’s LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds and Damian Lillard scored 20 with eight assists. Meanwhile, Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds and Chicago erased a 19-point halftime deficit with a 39-8 third-quarter run to beat Miami 89-78, as Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 and Derrick Rose chipped in 12, while Miami’s Dwyane Wade managed nine points on 4-of-20 shooting and Hassan Whiteside had 19 and 16 boards.

YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool’s Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Marković at Melwood by posing as a competition-winner fan before showcasing his remarkable dead-ball skills—beating the stand-in keeper and even outshining Balotelli until the striker retaliated with a perfect free kick of his own—and capped off the visit by revealing Balotelli’s infamous slogan T-shirt, all while enjoying the chance to fool and impress his idols.

Women carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations face up to a 70 percent lifetime risk of breast cancer and a heightened threat of ovarian tumors; a Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with these mutations—345 of whom underwent oophorectomy an average of six years after diagnosis—found that removing the ovaries cut breast cancer mortality by 62 percent in BRCA1 carriers (with a 73 percent reduction when done within two years) and reduced overall mortality by 65 percent, benefits that appeared immediately and lasted 15 years. BRCA2 carriers did not show the same breast cancer–specific benefit. Researchers and journal editors recommend considering oophorectomy at diagnosis for early-stage BRCA mutation carriers, especially those with estrogen-receptor–negative tumors, and call for further study of BRCA2 cases. Genetic testing is advised for women with significant family histories or in higher-risk populations such as Ashkenazi Jews.

A married couple, 38-year-old Derek Lowe and 33-year-old Tina Lowe, were struck and killed shortly before 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, by Amtrak’s northbound Carolinian (Train No. 80) en route from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk Southern property; none of the 166 passengers were injured, though one man fell ill during the resulting 2 hour 45 minute delay, and the couple—who may have been living in a homeless camp and were seen pushing a grocery cart—were pronounced dead at the scene.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level Medellín Cartel member who spent 27 years as an unpaid DEA informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s, faces deportation despite being promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his extensive undercover work—helping bring down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega—and despite warnings that returning to Colombia would be a death sentence. Now living illegally after his final temporary visa expired, Toro has declined health-forced retirement assistance, is unable to collect benefits, and remains in limbo while appealing for the green card or passport he was promised; his former DEA handler and colleagues have privately raised funds to cover his medical needs, but the agency itself has refused further help.

The US regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for charging trademark holders—such as Kevin Spacey, who has paid to have his “.sucks” domain removed—and major brands like YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo and Telus Mobility exorbitant fees (about $2,499 a year) to secure or remove these “.sucks” domains. Approved in ICANN’s recent expansion of top-level domains, “.sucks” opened March 30 for trademark holders before public registration; an ICANN advisory panel representing Microsoft, Verizon, eBay and others has deemed the business a “predatory shakedown scheme” and urged regulators in the US and Canada to assess its legality. Vox Populi argues the domains foster customer-company dialogue and comply with ICANN rules, and plans to offer consumer registration at $10 annually starting in September, while ICANN warns it may declare the registry in breach of contract if regulators find unlawful practices.

In 1988 the body of a newborn baby boy was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in Windmill Pit, a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, and was buried anonymously by villagers; after police exhumed his remains in 2015 for a case review, DNA from his leg bone matched a relative in the national database, leading investigators to his mother, who admitted she had secretly delivered the baby stillborn on June 5, 1988, then placed him in the pond; detectives, satisfied there was no third-party involvement or foul play, dropped the infanticide suspicion but the Crown Prosecution Service is considering charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial, while a charity has paid for a new headstone and the boy has been reburied and named Peter at St Peter’s Church.

Kristopher Hicks, then 23, suffered catastrophic brain injuries and post-traumatic epilepsy after jumping from a moving taxi in Bath in November 2010, when driver Michael Young—mistakenly convinced Hicks planned to “do a runner”—refused to stop and tried to return him to the taxi rank, unlawfully imprisoning him. Mr Justice Edis ruled Young’s conduct created a significant risk to life and limb, entitling Hicks to damages (reduced by 50 percent for his choice to jump at speed) plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Hicks, now 27, requires round-the-clock care from his mother; a further hearing will determine the exact compensation, expected to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas Wednesday night as spotters confirmed a twister about six miles northwest of Goddard (15 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast, threatening other communities, while additional reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. The National Weather Service also said a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage, flooding and downed trees were reported and aerial footage showed damaged roofs and flooded streets. Residents in nearby Leadington shared images of ominous clouds, and in Farmington, hail “the size of baseballs” pelted cars. More storms are forecast Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold, riding a three‐fight win streak since his 2013 loss to Vitor Belfort, enters Saturday’s New Jersey middleweight bout against Lyoto Machida determined to “be the bull” by cutting off Machida’s movement, exploiting holes in his defense with takedowns, kicks and punches, and forcing him to fight Rockhold’s fight; despite respecting Machida’s long-time status and unorthodox style, Rockhold vows to dominate. Machida, fresh off a win over CB Dollaway, believes his technique and strategy can neutralize Rockhold, spots potential weaknesses but insists he must “feel the fight” to capitalize, and sees a victory earning him the next title shot.

An Aerostar light twin aircraft landing at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, touched down without its landing gear deployed, skidding along the runway belly-first as its propellers struck the tarmac and wings bounced. The videographer noted the distinct sound of propeller impact and saw the pilot re-engage full throttle to lift off despite damaged propeller tips and high angle of attack. Remarkably, engines remained functional, allowing the 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, accompanied by his dog Buddy, to fly the plane 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and land safely. The FAA is investigating, noting gear-up landings usually result from human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini admitted he has been disappointed by Yaya Touré’s underwhelming performances this season but insisted the Manchester City midfielder – who has two years left on a £220,000-a-week contract – will continue to have his support until the end of the campaign, despite Sportsmail reporting that City will listen to offers for the 31-year-old as they plan to overhaul an ageing squad after a faltering title defense that has yielded just 18 of the last 39 available Premier League points; with captain Vincent Kompany sidelined by injury and his own future under scrutiny, Pellegrini has been backed by goalkeeper Joe Hart, who said players must take responsibility for the team’s struggles, while West Ham boss Sam Allardyce, whose side City face on Sunday, has cautioned full-back Aaron Cresswell against making the same “mistake” as others by moving to City amid reported interest.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia “man of honour” convicted in absentia in 1999 and given a seven-year sentence for Cosa Nostra membership, had fought extradition from his Uxbridge home since his 2013 arrest on a European arrest warrant. Although an Italian court of appeal last October declared his conviction extinguished—because under Italian law a sentence lapses once twice its length has passed—his European arrest warrant was only withdrawn recently, ending UK proceedings. His conviction remains on record but cannot be enforced, so Rancadore, known as “the Godfather of Uxbridge,” will stay in Britain without serving prison time.

Mr Mole, AP McCoy’s mount in Saturday’s Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in Barry Geraghty’s absence. This will be McCoy’s final ride in a Grade One contest, with his full book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey to be confirmed Friday morning. Ironically, McCoy announced his retirement after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other entrants in the seven-runner field include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter Marcia was raped, strangled and left in a cluttered, windowless garage under a shower curtain and child’s wading pool in 1975, her body discovered 33 days after she disappeared with her cookie money missing and a fractured neck bone. Advised by her then-husband to avoid viewing crime-scene photos, Ritter declined for decades even after neighborly suspects were cleared and Jerome Sidney Barrett was arrested in Memphis in 2006 following a DNA match, then convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years. Last year Ritter finally viewed the photos, was horrified by Marcia’s swollen, bloodied face and body, and now says she wants revenge.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, insists it is “unthinkable” that he won’t eventually win the Masters to complete golf’s career grand slam—becoming only the sixth player ever to win all four majors—and says his catastrophic final-round 80 at Augusta in 2011 was the most important day of his career because of what he learned. Now 25, he heads into his seventh Masters having posted only one top-10 there but remains convinced that, once he secures his first green jacket, he’ll contend for multiple titles. Since that collapse he has won the 2011 US Open by eight shots, the 2012 US PGA and both the 2014 Open Championship and US PGA, despite personal distractions including a called-off wedding and a costly legal dispute, and he views Augusta as a sanctuary where he can focus solely on playing his best golf.

CNN’s trending roundup this week includes a rare quadruple rainbow over New York captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis, China’s crackdown on exotic dancers at funerals, Robert Downey Jr.’s irritation during a UK Channel 4 interview, the viral “#kyliejennerchallenge” lip-plumping craze, 102-year-old Alice Barker’s time-travel film project, a bomb-referencing prom proposal accused of racism when rejected by a school, Ewan McGregor joining Beauty and the Beast as Lumière, Johnny Depp’s dramatic new look in the Black Mass trailer, a Fresh Prince–themed pregnancy announcement, and a military dad’s photobomb at his son’s event.

Last year in England 272 children were hospitalised with disabilities caused by foetal alcohol syndrome, though experts warn many more cases go undiagnosed; World Health Organization research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies—around 7,500 annually—suffers learning, behavioural and physical problems (such as limb deformities) due to prenatal alcohol exposure. Affected children never fully recover, says Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, and can face a range of medical issues from liver, kidney and heart problems to cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Fifteen-year-old Niamh Brown, who lacks a sense of danger and requires constant care, was diagnosed at five after struggles at playschool prompted her adoptive parents Julia and Simon to launch the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust in 2007. Although UK government advice allows up to two units of alcohol no more than twice a week during pregnancy, Ms Mitchell argues that women should be advised to abstain completely.

An axe-wielding Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender nicknamed “boomerang boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, burst into Shildon Post Office at 8 pm on March 15 and demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, but owner Sab Dhillon tackled him to the floor while his wife Sam struck him twice with a baseball bat to disarm him; blood could be seen from McKerry’s nose as Dhillon restrained him until police arrived minutes later, and he has since pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and been sentenced to six years’ imprisonment.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, 23; Craig Stoner, 24; Simon Radford, 31; and Darren Smalley, 35—have been charged in Nova Scotia with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after an alleged gang rape of a young Halifax woman at a party on April 10 following a navy ice hockey tournament. Granted bail of over £2,000 each, they surrendered their passports, must remain in Nova Scotia living and working at Stadacona naval base under continued Royal Navy pay, avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses, stay employed by the navy, and return to court May 27.

Valerie Jackson’s four-year-old son RJ suffers from the extremely rare genetic skin disorder Netherton’s syndrome, which makes his skin appear bright red, scaly and sore and requires him to be slathered in moisturizing creams multiple times a day; because the disease affects only around 70 people worldwide and can look like scalds or burns, strangers have accused her of child abuse—once even prompting armed police to surround them in a Las Vegas Walmart—and RJ has been denied entry to play centers and taunted by both adults and children. Despite no cure existing, the Jacksons learned to manage his painful symptoms—bathing him twice weekly, covering cracked skin with Vaseline every few hours and using mittens to stop him scratching—through an online support group, and Valerie hopes that greater awareness of Netherton’s will spare her son further cruelty as he grows up.

Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” posters, featuring 24-year-old model Renee Somerfield in a bikini, sparked more than 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition, over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority and widespread online defacement and criticism for promoting an unrealistic body image. Transport for London confirmed the ads would be removed at the end of their paid three-week run but said customer feedback would inform future campaigns. Protein World defended the unretouched image on social media, responded harshly to critics and reported both violent and bomb threats to police. On Good Morning Britain, presenter Susanna Reid described the campaign as “anxiety inducing,” while the company’s head of marketing insisted the goal was to inspire healthier lifestyles. The ASA is reviewing complaints, and the controversy unfolds amid booming UK protein-powder sales, projected to rise from £170 million in 2012 to £358 million by 2017, and supportive voices like Katie Hopkins and writer Samantha Brick who said the ad motivated them.

Rail firms have announced unregulated fare hikes of up to 87 per cent just days after the election, despite both main party leaders promising price freezes—most controversially, First Great Western’s off-peak return from Charlbury to London will jump from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to demand an urgent review. Unregulated fares, which account for around half of rail revenue and include off-peak and advance-purchase tickets, may be increased three times a year; FGW justifies its rise as aligning the North Cotswolds service with others and offers advanced singles for around £20. Other significant increases include a London Midland off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton rising from £30 to £37, a Virgin anytime return Stafford–Liverpool up 24.5 per cent (£26.50 to £33) and a Virgin first-class day return Manchester–Stoke rising 22 per cent (£29 to £35.30); Virgin says most hikes apply to its “trains-only” fares and its overall West Coast rise is just 1.65 per cent, while industry analysts note many rural and on-the-day tickets have already gone up by around 40 per cent.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were sitting in their Oldham home writing wedding thank-you cards when yobs began hurling stones at their front window; after a brick shattered the glass, Mr Young opened the door to remonstrate and was struck in the left eye by another brick, suffering a forehead wound and irreversible eye damage that left him blind in that eye. Despite emergency surgery, his sight could not be saved, leaving him fearful in his own home and prompting plans to move away. Greater Manchester Police have launched an investigation—unable to identify any motive and describing the attack as possibly senseless vandalism—and are appealing for witnesses to come forward. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, who missed the entire 2014 season after sustaining leg injuries in a road accident that killed his father, Keith, has signed a one-year contract extension running through the end of the 2016 season; following an ankle operation and a successful playing comeback on Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi, Poynton will be available for the start of the new season, and elite performance director Graeme Welch praised his exceptional character and form in training and Abu Dhabi, expressing confidence that the new deal will allow him to continue performing strongly.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs and bones and endured 80 days of chemotherapy, a kidney-tumour operation, a stem-cell transplant and radiotherapy—during which he decorated his immobilisation mask as a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle to boost his courage. After his story appeared in the press, Nickelodeon sent him Ninja Turtle gifts, Cancer Research UK gave him a Little Star Award and he became the face of its Kids & Teens campaign, and now doctors have declared him cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups, and his parents say they look forward to him returning to school full time.

Tim Sherwood believes 19-year-old Jack Grealish should focus on cementing his place in Aston Villa’s first team rather than worrying about whether to represent England or the Republic of Ireland, though both associations are vying for his allegiance. Sherwood, impressed by Grealish’s confident, dribbling display in Villa’s 2-1 FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, said Grealish must play more club games before making a decision and go with his heart—just as Nabil Bentaleb chose Algeria over France under Sherwood’s guidance. Grealish’s father, Kevin, agreed that club form must come first and predicted the international choice will follow once his son’s performances remain strong.

Private jet travel is booming—2.5 million flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013—with landing fees at major airports varying widely and peaking in unexpected hubs. Based on charges for a 767-400 jet, Tokyo’s Haneda tops the list at £4,559 ($6,850) per landing, followed by Narita (£3,728/$5,600) and Osaka’s Kansai (£3,594/$5,400). Other costly fees include Toronto Pearson (£3,461/$5,200), Darwin (£3,059/$4,600), Bristol (£2,929/$4,400), Nagoya’s Chūbu Centrair (£2,863/$4,300), Dublin (£2,729/$4,100), LaGuardia (£2,630/$3,950) and Salzburg (£2,530/$3,800). Peak private-jet traffic coincides with events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with New York–Glendale round-trip costs estimated at $38,000–$54,000 and London–Cannes around £8,835. Top private routes include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan–Rome ($5,880 one-way).

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, runs Dogpatch Resort and recently took her Labrador Cooper and smaller pup Daisy through a McDonald’s drive-thru for ice cream, where Daisy daintily licked the cone while Cooper devoured it in one bite—a habit Gallegos says is typical for the speedy eater, who always lets Daisy finish first. The video clip has drawn over seven million views, evoking both praise for its cuteness and criticism over feeding dogs ice cream, but Gallegos defends the treats, noting Cooper’s robust health—she once had a large breed mutt who lived to 19 eating weekly ice cream—and explaining that Daisy’s smaller size limits her to occasional licks. The duo’s fast-food fondness extends to Starbucks “pup-uccinos,” which are simply cups of whipped cream without coffee.

Gary Locke, who joined Kilmarnock last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston, has been appointed permanent manager on a three-year contract after leading the team to only one defeat in seven games since taking over as interim boss in February.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp of Eustis, says Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because the doTERRA essential oils she applies to his head and neck—scents like lavender, chamomile and sandalwood that help him stay calm and focused—were deemed too fragrant and distracting after a teacher’s aide complained. Although Kemp has used the oils all year without incident, a school board letter cited them as a “problem” for staff and students. Kemp insists the natural treatment should be allowed, and the Lake County school district later told a local station it would not suspend Logan, calling the matter a health issue.

A massive fire tore through the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday at 3 p.m., destroying all 90 condos and causing the building to collapse as plumes of smoke—visible three miles away—drifted toward the ocean; despite the deployment of twelve fire crews and the use of cranes, firefighters were unable to enter the fiercely burning structure, which melted paint off nearby buildings, and investigators are probing reports that the blaze may have begun near a car parked by the complex, a seasonal holiday home open from May through November.

The 88-year-old queen, undeterred by an impending 89th birthday and a niggling knee injury, was seen riding her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park without a helmet—opting for a silk scarf—in keeping with her lifelong habit driven by hairstyle concerns. An avid equestrienne since age four, when she received her first Shetland pony Peggy, she has maintained royal stables stocked with successive mounts—including Betsy and Surprise—overseen a stud at Hampton Court and Balmoral that breeds fell and Highland ponies, and continues to involve her grandchildren in riding. Fell ponies, a hardy, docile breed native to Cumbria since Neolithic times, rose from Iron Age trade through Roman and Viking use as pack animals, served in Britain’s industrial transport of ore and coal, and by the 1950s became favored family riding ponies; they remain popular today, notably under the queen’s patronage.

In north Brisbane, a noise dispute between neighbours escalated on Thursday night when 28-year-old warehouse shift worker Phillip Pama confronted 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, who was reportedly drunk, playing loud music and yelling in his yard, and struck him with a single punch; Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 pm, and Pama has been charged with manslaughter.
