Pama—married with three children, with no history of violence—was granted conditional bail, ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a 6 pm–2 am curfew and report to police twice weekly, with the case due back in court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher in Shatura, Moscow region, attempted to hire a hitman for 100,000 rubles (£1,400) to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year-long affair for a classmate. In a police sting, an undercover officer posed as a killer and a hidden camera recorded Simonova detailing how she wanted the boy’s arms and legs broken, his kidneys damaged to make him bleed out painfully, and then to “finish him” together. After handing over expenses money, she was arrested in her car and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. Vanya, who ended the relationship, said he hoped the authorities would “throw away the key” to her cell.

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea manager and father of two, says he prays and speaks with God every day about personal matters—never about football—and only attends church regularly when he feels the need or is in Portugal; he strives to separate his intense professional life from his family life, considers himself a good family man and friend who supports people he doesn’t even know, and has worked with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, while his club, currently top of the Premier League, faces QPR this weekend and Mourinho was fined £25,000 earlier this season for alleging a “campaign” against Chelsea after Cesc Fàbregas’s booking.

Bob Barker, who hosted The Price Is Right for 35 years before retiring in 2007, made a surprise return on the April 1 edition of the show—his first appearance in eight years—kicking off the classic “Lucky Seven” pricing game before handing hosting duties back to Drew Carey, looking spry at 91 and demonstrating he hadn’t missed a beat.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington, D.C., after allegedly attempting to break into a residence; he faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Metropolitan Police officers returning to the scene took him into custody, after which the Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin, who is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch attached to the State Department, was slated for arraignment Friday afternoon; court records list no attorney for him. His arrest follows a recent leave for a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, an ongoing inspector general probe into that case, and a separate inquiry into two senior agents allegedly driving into a White House secure area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at the city’s safari park by exiting his car and crawling to within ten feet of a hungry male lion, firing off a few shots with his camera before the shutter sound alerted the animal and forced him to scramble back to safety; reflecting on the “pretty close encounter,” he admits he wouldn’t attempt such a stunt again despite wanting to capture the lion’s true character.

New York City police seek help identifying an unnamed woman, believed to be 25–45 years old, who was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on the evening of March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend section; she had no ID but bore a faded heart-and-rose tattoo on her right leg inscribed with the name “Monique,” and investigators, still awaiting the medical examiner’s report on her cause of death, ask anyone with information to call NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, returned from the UK unable to afford property, so over a year and a half they transformed a 1986 Hino flatbed truck into a wood- and steel-framed, solar-powered two-bedroom home for about NZ$25,000. Featuring stained glass windows, a wood-fired stove, gas-powered hot water, spring water supply and almost complete energy self-sufficiency, the movable house now sits on their Nelson lot amid cypress wood interiors, mature trees and a babbling brook, and they plan to build another one someday.

Kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year scored about 30 points higher on early literacy tests than peers who had individual devices or no iPads, according to Northwestern University researcher Courtney Blackwell’s study of 352 students in a Midwestern suburban district; she attributes the gain to “collaborative learning around the technology” and suggests schools rethink tablet use in younger grades, with her results to be presented at the 65th annual International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan, has learned to walk upright on its front trotters, wobbling as it forages with its snout to the ground and mixing happily with its fully legged littermates. Nicknamed “Super Pig,” it became an online sensation after a heartwarming video showed it repeatedly regaining its balance despite near-tumbles. Owned by farmer Ms Duan, the two-legged animal has drawn villagers’ curiosity much as a two-pawed rabbit did at Liuzhou Zoo.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana in Avondale, pit crew member Todd Phillips of Dayle Coyne Racing was struck in the leg by Francesco Dracone’s car after Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25 for tires and fuel; Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released, while Dracone, who had struggled with traction on the rain‐slicked track, did not finish and was classified 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, in their Rio de Janeiro apartment four days after their wedding, dragging her into the garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, then returning with a handgun to shoot her in the face five times; he later confessed he acted out of jealousy over other men looking at her, having accused her of being “a slut,” and fled in a stolen car—where police discovered four handguns, a shotgun and a bullet-proof vest—before crashing and being arrested, now facing life imprisonment.

Journalist and bestselling author Sarah Wilson has revealed that a combination of mounting stress, chronic anxiety, thyroid disease and isolation led her to believe her life wasn’t worth living and brought her close to suicide; now 41, she says she has recently “found some peace” and emphasizes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked, arguing that acknowledging this connection is crucial to addressing rising rates of anxiety among Australian women—one in three of whom will experience it in their lifetime—and urging anyone in need to seek help from Beyond Blue or Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant in November 2014, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend’s former girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar upon finding her shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom; prosecutors dropped the charge, citing Oregon law that permits physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave, and deemed Curtin “completely justified in her outrage.” Curtin gave birth in January and has since moved in with her parents; her defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, stated that the ex-girlfriend had repeatedly harassed and threatened Curtin and sought to draw her boyfriend—who struggled with heroin—back into addiction. Had Curtin been convicted, she faced nearly six years in prison, while the ex and the father of Curtin’s child have reconciled but the father is not involved in the new baby’s life.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed eagerly eating treats until her owner secretly added a broccoli spear, prompting her to make a disgusted face and spit the vegetable onto the floor; the video’s narrator hopes the two children she lives with won’t follow her lead, and other clips show Gemma enjoying sleep and time with her human family.

HSBC has apologised after a link on its official website meant to lead to the Young Entrepreneur Awards page instead redirected visitors to a pornographic site, because the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the domain was allowed to lapse; upon discovering the error, the bank removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, offered a public apology for the inconvenience, and insisted its website and internet banking services remain secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 shortly before 7 a.m. on Sunday after smelling smoke from a first-floor fire in his family’s Clinton home, calmly guiding Prince George’s County firefighters through an 11-minute call as he and his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah, trapped by heat in a second-floor bedroom, stayed low and breathed. He informed the dispatcher that their mother, stepfather and older brother were also inside, soothed Aaliyah when she feared they’d die, and directed rescuers to go up the back hallway steps to a black door. Firefighters broke a window to reach them; Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out first and then gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were treated at Children’s Hospital for non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Vibrant blue fluorescent algae known as Noctiluca scintillans recently lit up Jervis Bay on New South Wales’s south coast, producing neon waves captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who called it a “beautiful supernatural scene” created by millions of light-emitting plankton; this harmless phenomenon, driven by the carnivorous single-celled phytoplankton’s defensive glow when it feeds on diatoms, also appeared on Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014 and typically occurs naturally in spring and autumn.

New genetic-marker tests such as EndoPredict can assess a breast cancer tumor’s aggressiveness by screening cells removed during surgery and return a high- or low-risk score within days, enabling some women whose recurrence risk is as low as five percent to safely skip chemotherapy and avoid its severe side effects. Although most patients currently receive chemotherapy routinely after tumor removal, experts argue that tailoring treatment based on these tests—currently available privately for about £2,500 but hoped to be adopted by the NHS—could prevent unnecessary treatment and save costs. In one case, 49-year-old Becca Cornford was found to have only a five-percent chance of recurrence over ten years and thus chose to forgo chemotherapy, relying instead on vigilant monitoring.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships because of pregnancy—HMS Ocean alone saw five pregnant sailors medevaced over nine years, and at least one woman was flown off HMS Illustrious before its 2014 decommissioning—while 18 other vessels, including HMS Dragon, Enterprise and Richmond, have also carried out emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman noted a strict “no touching” rule at sea, implying pregnancies were usually conceived before deployment or during leave. This data follows the 2015 recall of Commander Sarah West amid allegations of a relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990 and made up about 9 percent of personnel in 2014; in May of last year three women became the service’s first female submariners. Separately, freedom of information figures show 99 servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan for pregnancy between January 2006 and December 2013 (16 in 2013 and 18 in 2011) and 102 from Iraq, as strict military rules bar expectant mothers from war zones and require their return at the first convenient opportunity.

A small, four-propeller drone carrying a plastic bottle with trace amounts of cesium was found on the roof of Japan’s prime minister Shinzo Abe’s residence in Tokyo, prompting a police investigation and sparking fears of drone-enabled terrorism, especially ahead of the Olympics and a G7 summit. The find coincided with a court’s approval to restart two Sendai nuclear reactors—more than four years after the Fukushima Daiichi disaster—and reignited public unease over nuclear energy. Government officials, led by Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga, warned that current Japanese law only restricts drone flights near airports, leaving key sites such as the prime minister’s residence and other government buildings unprotected, and pledged to review drone regulations to guard against future threats.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang, China, cares for his 84-year-old mother who has Alzheimer’s by bringing her to work on the back of his motorbike every day. After his father’s death left no one else to look after her—and because she’d repeatedly wandered off—he wakes her at 5 am, fastens them together with a sash, and rides four kilometers slowly so she feels safe and they can chat; the trip takes an hour. At his job in a bank, his employers provide her with a room, and he checks on her regularly to ensure she hasn’t wandered. Lu says he feels it is his duty to repay his mother, who devoted her life to her children.

A study by the University of Washington’s Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent from 2005 to 2012—driven largely by women—and binge‐drinking episodes similarly increased, with women’s rates rising more than seven times those of men nationally and by 36 percent in Santa Clara County versus 23 percent for men. In 2012, 8 percent of U.S. adults were heavy drinkers (more than one drink per day for women, two for men) and 18 percent were binge drinkers (four drinks per occasion for women, five for men), even though overall alcohol use remained stable. County extremes ranged from a 6 percent binge rate in Madison County, Idaho, to 36 percent in Menominee, Wisconsin, and 2 percent heavy‐drinker prevalence in Hancock County, Tennessee, versus 22 percent in Esmeralda County, Nevada. Excessive drinking cost the U.S. over $220 billion annually and contributed to about 88,600 deaths in 2010. Researchers and public‐health experts attribute the rise to changing social norms for women, greater affluence (especially in urban tech hubs), cheaper alcohol relative to inflation, increased liquor advertising, and weakened alcohol‐control policies.

UN officials, led by the World Health Organization, warn that England’s caesarean section rate—just over a quarter of births and more than double its early-1990s level—is too high and should ideally remain between 10 percent and 15 percent. They stress that C-sections, while lifesaving when medically necessary, often cause infections, significant complications, disability or death, and divert funds—an average planned C-section costs the NHS £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth. This critique directly challenges current NHS and NICE guidelines, which permit women to request planned C-sections for anxiety about childbirth (tokophobia), previous complicated births, age over 40 or conditions such as asthma, diabetes or depression.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins of West Wareham, has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after allegedly breaking into a Martha’s Vineyard summer home worth $800,000, living there for at least a week, and selling or giving away the owners’ belongings in a yard sale. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her inside on April 17, and she fled in a gray Nissan pickup when confronted, returning hours later only to be arrested. Police found a broken front window covered by a blanket and have listed missing items—including deck chairs, lamps, tables, a grill, cookware, linens, framed posters, and a painting—and are asking anyone who received these items to return them or contact the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend’s birthday party in Melbourne and it was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW–Victoria border the next morning; discovering the phone was unlocked and logged into her Facebook account, officers posted a series of humorous selfies and pun-laden status updates—such as placing the phone in a “holding cell,” offering to “charge” it fully, and “releasing it for good behaviour”—to prompt her to collect it, and by the time she arrived they recognized her from the Facebook posts, returned the device without even asking her name, and she has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was fatally mauled and hurled into the air during a prolonged fight between two adult males in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa; its mother, who had stayed with her herd to avoid danger, watched helplessly as one of the battling sub‐adults grabbed the calf, bit down harder when attacked on the neck by the mother, then flicked the baby into the air before dragging it through the muddy water, with the calf succumbing to its injuries hours later, as witnessed in horror by tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A three-bedroom, two-bathroom maisonette on Egerton Place in Knightsbridge has been listed for £575,000—equivalent to about £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month—because it has only three years left on its lease and requires full modernisation; despite its unmodernised state, its 1,990 sq ft of “bright and well-proportioned” space, lift, parking and communal garden have attracted strong interest, and extending the lease—estimated to cost between £3.35m and £4.5m for 90 years—could boost the flat’s value to around £6m (and up to £7.5m for the larger neighbouring maisonette), whereas modernised properties in the area fetch between £2,750 and £3,000 per sq ft.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage late Friday that disabled registers at 8,000 company-operated stores across the U.S. (7,000) and Canada (1,000), forcing baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods because they couldn’t process credit cards, although some took cash; many locations closed early to stem losses. The glitch, blamed on a failure during a daily system refresh, began around 7:30 p.m. ET and was resolved by Saturday morning, with Starbucks announcing business would return to normal. During the outage, Twitter users shared photos and posts celebrating free frappuccinos and lattes, even as some stores preemptively shut their doors. This incident followed the chain’s record quarterly earnings announcement of $4.6 billion in net revenues, which had just driven its share price up 4.4 percent.

Terrorists have been using rural west Wales locations in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire to radicalise and train Muslims, Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit warned, noting participants often engage in ordinary-seeming community activities with hidden agendas. Extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998 when hate preacher Abu Hamza allegedly sent recruits to train in the Brecon Beacons, a military training area whose rugged terrain also hosted SAS exercises. In 2005, 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer were spotted white-water rafting in Bala, north Wales, and in 2010 three Cardiff-based, Al-Qaeda-inspired plotters held secret country-park meetings in Ceredigion. More recently, Michael Adebowale, one of Lee Rigby’s murderers, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, reputedly set up by Iraqi clerics. Jones stressed that terrorism is not confined to large cities and urged communities to share any intelligence they may have.

A species of whale once feared extinct, the Omura’s whale, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68 m juvenile female proved difficult to identify until DNA profiling confirmed its species, which was only described in 2003 and is known from tropical and subtropical waters of Indonesia, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. With a sleek body, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, the specimen will yield critical data to improve field identification guides, clarify regional distribution and inform scientific understanding; its carcass has been buried pending skeleton recovery for further study and potential museum display.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, sparked controversy by claiming that women’s hormones make them too unstable to be president and suggesting Hillary Clinton could start an unnecessary war, even as she ignored that male hormones have long driven risky decisions by male leaders; studies show women leaders take fewer needless risks, Time called postmenopausal Clinton “biologically primed” to lead, and research by Wharton’s Adam Grant and Sheryl Sandberg documents pervasive gender bias—from male-dominated corporate boards to students rating male professors as “geniuses” and women as merely “nice”—which, critics argue, poses a greater obstacle than biology to women’s leadership, despite clear evidence that gender equality boosts company performance, family well-being and societal strength.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is downsizing his Cotswolds home and selling more than 200 antiques—including a 1960s hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000–£6,000), a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, a portrait of Hardy with the bow (£2,000), Gillows of Lancaster cabinets (up to £4,000), swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers and dozens of books dating back to the 17th century—in a £100,000 auction of 238 lots at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, this Saturday. A keen military historian who studied English under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, published two books on the medieval longbow and advised on the Mary Rose raise, Hardy rose to fame as Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small (1978–1990), frequently portrayed Winston Churchill and Franklin D. Roosevelt on screen, and later played Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films. Saddened to part with his treasured collection, he plans to continue television work despite retiring from the stage after a fall two years ago.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery on law enforcement with a history of bipolar disorder and a prior psychiatric hold after a suicide attempt, has been on the run since Saturday after authorities named him a suspect in the killing of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found that day in their Winter Garden home following a welfare check by an out-of-state relative. Shemansky drew police attention when he failed to appear at a court-ordered supervised visit with his son—the same day his mother was discovered dead—and neighbors at the Winter Garden RV Resort suggested tensions over divorce proceedings and a domestic violence injunction filed by his estranged wife may have provoked him. Investigators have recovered the murder weapon, though they have not released details on the cause of death; surveillance reportedly shows him requesting water at the park’s office shortly after the crime before fleeing on foot without supplies or medication. Authorities urge anyone with information to call 407-656-3636.

Eugene, Oregon has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF Council decided to bypass the usual bidding process, citing a unique strategic opportunity to bring the event to the USA for the first time. Eugene had failed in its bid for the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF that the city, backed by public authorities, the private sector, the US Olympic Committee, broadcaster NBC and an enthusiastic local audience, could successfully stage the event. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized that, although this decision departs from normal procedure, it advances the global development of the sport by accessing a key market, a move comparable to the 2007 championships in Osaka, which were also awarded without bidding.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter for luring 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a West End casino honey trap; she befriended him at the Palm Beach Casino, returned with him to his Islington flat, excused herself and left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and his accomplice Nicholas Chandler, who bound, kicked and fatally injured Hassan while ransacking his flat for hidden cash. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years.

Cesc Fàbregas, who starred for Chelsea early in the season—amassing 15 Premier League assists by mid-January—has suffered a familiar post-Christmas slump, delivering just one assist in his past five club games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015; his dip in form was epitomized by a 4/10 performance for Spain in their 2-0 loss to Holland, prompting concerns from José Mourinho as Fàbregas, playing almost every minute, shows signs of fatigue. Despite a bright start that suggested he might surpass Thierry Henry’s single-season assist record of 20, Fàbregas’s contributions have waned late in the campaign—a pattern noted since his Barcelona days—though six of Chelsea’s nine remaining fixtures are against teams he has previously supplied, offering him a final opportunity to rediscover his creative spark and help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham United are close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford—recently on trial after leaving Montego Bay United—having been invited to train with the club’s academy earlier this month and impressed coaches during his two-week stay; Beckford, regarded as one of the Caribbean’s top emerging talents, also holds offers from Belgian clubs and has been linked with several European sides. Meanwhile, in preparation for their move to the 54,000-seat Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season, the Hammers have announced season tickets starting at £289, making theirs the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League.

Three months after a balaclava-clad group of about 15 hunt saboteurs armed with iron-bar-tipped ropes assaulted Tedworth Hunt joint master Mike Lane at Everleigh—knocking him unconscious, fracturing teeth, causing concussion, memory loss and facial swelling—a video, suspect photograph, names and car registrations supplied to Wiltshire Police have failed to prompt any charges, the inquiry now shelved as “undetected” pending further evidence. Outraged, Lane and colleagues call the decision “pathetic” and accuse the force of inaction despite clear footage of the attacker kicking Lane in the head, while supporters and campaigners urge a ban on face coverings to aid future prosecutions.

Adam Gadahn, born in 1978 as Adam Pearlman and later taking the name Abu Suhayb or “Azzam the American,” was a California-born convert to Islam who left for Pakistan in 1998 and rose through al Qaeda’s ranks to become its chief English-language propagandist. Although never a top military leader, he featured in numerous videos—sometimes disguised or speaking Arabic—threatening attacks on Western targets, encouraging lone-wolf assaults in the U.S., praising incidents like Fort Hood and Benghazi, and criticizing both Presidents Bush and Obama. Indicted for treason and material support in 2006, he appeared on the FBI’s Most Wanted list. The White House announced he and fellow U.S. citizen operative Ahmed Farouq died in separate U.S. counterterrorism strikes in January, the same operation that killed hostages Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto. Gadahn’s final recorded message, released in September 2014, urged Muslims to overthrow governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

Chinese parents’ drive to raise prodigies has spawned a new basketball sensation in five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, whose viral video shows him sinking successive hoops, dribbling two balls while staring at the camera and maintaining perfect rhythm—skills he’s been honing since age two and a half. The display has fueled legions of fans in basketball-crazy China, drawing thousands of amazed comments, from disbelief and speculation about special effects to self-deprecating remarks on one’s own abilities, while evoking comparisons to the country’s biggest basketball icon, Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll, once a key activist in the Paedophile Information Exchange—which from 1974 allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties to campaign for lowering the age of consent to ten (provided the child “understood the nature of the act”) and legalizing incest—has joined Hacked Off’s supporters and on February 25 attended a free, public rally in the Houses of Parliament (chaired by John Cleese) lobbying MPs for statutory press regulation as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. Now 69 and jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals,” O’Carroll confirmed his attendance on his blog, prompting embarrassment for Hacked Off, which campaigns against what it sees as the “biased and unfair” Independent Press Standards Organisation.

Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a catwalk for Ten Pieces’ monochrome, unisex capsule collection—designed by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss to comprise ten items worn in twenty different ways—presented as part of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against a backdrop of blue ocean and sky on an unseasonably warm 28°C day, while guests enjoyed Icebergs’ nibbles, Santa Vittoria drinks and minimal, androgynous designs, and beachgoers looked on from the sand and nearby road.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, where he and his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa posed with giraffes and sea lions and fed a rare white tiger, and earlier this week he confirmed his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, despite speculation linking him to bouts with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was briefly listed on Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl memorial for fallen soldiers and terrorism victims ahead of Israel’s Memorial Day. His family, led by his father Hussein, and the Israeli victims’ advocacy group Almagor objected, arguing that no one sought permission and that Abu Khdeir’s killing was an individual criminal act, not terrorism. After Almagor threatened to remove its own victims’ names if Abu Khdeir remained, Israel’s National Insurance Institute agreed to remove his name from both the memorial wall and its website. Meanwhile, a judicial panel has been hearing evidence against his alleged killers since January.

A California YouTube user captured his young son repeatedly using the family cat as a makeshift pillow: the boy plops himself onto the cat’s belly, the cat shifts spots, and the child follows and rolls down to rest again, a cycle that repeats until the cat retreats indoors. In a later clip, the pair reunite peacefully as the toddler gently feeds the feline treats.

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old former marijuana dealer, lost his varsity basketball coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy in suburban Bryn Mawr after testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial that undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner, who had passed a 2010 background check on the basis that his 2007 charges were expunged under probation, acknowledged on cross-examination that he pleaded guilty to a 2008 DUI and was arrested again in 2011, receiving four years’ probation. He maintains he never meant to deceive the school, considers the 2007 incident a closed chapter, professes his innocence for the 2011 charges, and continues to coach in a Narberth summer league. The trial centers on six former Philadelphia drug-squad officers charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing, whose lawyers argue the government’s case relies on testimony from 19 alleged lying dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion triggered by an oil leak at a paraxylene (PX) storage facility in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, injured six people—five of whom suffered glass-related wounds—and ignited a large fire that was brought under control by more than 600 firefighters; no toxic chemical spill has been reported. The plant, which manufactures the potentially carcinogenic PX used in polyester films and fabrics, previously experienced an explosion in July 2013 without casualties or leaks, and its construction provoked protests in Xiamen in 2007 over pollution concerns, leading authorities to relocate it to a more remote site.

Jack Grealish, the Ireland under-21 international and Aston Villa teenager, insists he will continue wearing his socks low over children’s-size shinpads despite Premier League referees’ warnings, citing a lifelong superstition. He made his first Premier League start in Villa’s dramatic 3-3 draw with QPR, which he acknowledged was a tough debut in a relegation battle but welcomed as a show of faith from his manager and a boost to earn more starts before season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with global and irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive after coming out of a medically induced coma, her grandmother Cissy Houston and a CNN source say; she does not respond to visitors, track movement with her eyes and requires a tracheostomy. Despite her father’s onstage claim that she was awake and watching him, family attorney Christopher Brown and Bobby’s wife Alicia Etheredge-Brown emphasize that while she has left the ICU and begun a long rehabilitation, the extent and quality of her recovery will only become clear over years.

Russia surged to a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany after Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Görges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova overcame Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, saving a match point in the second set. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with 13 double faults, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved costly. Lisicki admitted she couldn’t find her rhythm against Pavlyuchenkova’s power, and although she reached match point, she lost the decisive tiebreak. With just one more win needed from Sunday’s three matches, Russia is poised to reach the final and secure its first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents already coping with last week’s east coast low are being warned that a similar weather system could return Thursday through Saturday, bringing heavy rain—particularly to the far northern coast and Hunter region—and raising flood levels on already saturated ground. The State Emergency Service, which still has over 4,000 outstanding jobs from 24,196 requests, fears another storm will hamper cleanup, damage uprooted trees and exacerbate flooding in hard-hit areas. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills urged communities to prepare homes and families, while meteorologists and the Bureau of Meteorology predict the new low will move quickly, likely delivering intense rainfall and strong winds mainly north of Sydney, with peak impacts between Thursday and Saturday, though its severity remains uncertain.

Nina Moric, the 38-year-old model known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, explaining on Instagram that she was hospitalized after collapsing from low blood pressure and suffering a head injury in a domestic accident while her boyfriend was away in Naples. She shared photos of bruises on her arms, reassured fans she was recovering at home, and called the suicide rumors “not entirely correct.” Moric, who was once married to celebrity photographer Fabrizio Corona—later jailed for blackmail—has a son, Carlos Maria, born in 2002.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov survey of 2,200 Britons for the Sunday Times finds Diana is the favorite name for a girl (12%), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each), while for a boy James tops the list (13%) with Alexander second; 25% of respondents hope for a daughter versus just 3% for another son, and many expressed delight on social media at the prospect of a baby princess named Diana, while 68% of those polled back William’s decision to take six weeks’ paternity leave.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday at around 10 a.m., killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker; the protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor, and while the Taliban denied responsibility, no group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final offer—a three-year extension conditional on his participation in 60% of matches—ending seven highly successful years in which the Brazilian right-back won four La Liga titles and two Champions Leagues, his agent Dinorah Santana confirmed at a press conference.

Pablo Osvaldo, who joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton and has scored three goals in six games, has urged Italian stars Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to follow him to the Argentine club, praising their south-American style, saying they’d be a perfect fit at La Bombonera and that fans would go “absolutely crazy” for them.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from Merrion Square in the 4.20 pm race at Wincanton but emerged with only a cut on his nose. Despite becoming an internet sensation with hundreds of thousands of views, he returned to Paul Nicholls’s yard the next morning, mucked out stalls as usual, and plans to get back in the saddle. Ferguson said he only realized what happened after watching the replay, received concerned reactions from fellow jockeys, endured some teasing and gained Twitter followers, and even joked about pursuing gymnastics after his racing career.

England flanker James Haskell, captain of London Wasps, celebrated the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Robert Downey Jr.’s Iron Man, captioned “avengers movie is out so thought i would release the inner iron man” with #transformyourself #iwill #avengersageofultron. Windsor-born Haskell began his Wasps career in 2002, winning his first England cap in 2007, then spent two seasons at Stade Français, four months with Japan’s Ricoh Black Rams and a brief stint at New Zealand’s Highlanders before returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since made over 100 appearances and earned 57 England caps.

The passage highlights the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key SS15 trend—whether in denim, prints, stripes or cropped styles—offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans that dates back to 1970s fashion. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp praise their flattering volume when paired with high-heeled shoes and simple tops or knits to maintain proportion and elongate the leg, especially in high-waisted or longer cuts. Designers such as Gucci, Celine and Stella McCartney have showcased flared denim or dressier versions on their runways, while high-street retailers like Topshop’s Miller jean and online labels like Finery London deliver more accessible takes. The wide-leg silhouette can be worn year-round and requires no special weather, making it a versatile wardrobe update.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel an on-campus screening of American Sniper after over 200 students petitioned against it—citing concerns about its portrayal of the Iraq War and Middle Eastern people—and a counter-petition supported the film’s free showing. Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper said canceling the event ran counter to the university’s commitment to freedom of expression and student choice, so the film will be shown as part of UMix social events, with Paddington offered as an alternative screening option.

On April 3 on Rottnest Island off Perth, two French tourists aged 18 and 24 allegedly sprayed an aerosol into a lighter flame, catching a quokka—the size of a domestic cat and native to small islands off Western Australia—alight and singeing it. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, and charged each with animal cruelty; they are due to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

At 102, former Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar chorus line dancer Alice Barker—who performed alongside Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra in the 1930s and ’40s—saw herself on film for the first time after all her original footage and memorabilia had been lost; thanks to Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers who compiled “soundies” music videos, Barker viewed the newly assembled footage at her nursing home and was delighted.

A recent OSV survey of 1,100 British adults finds that the once-ubiquitous Sunday ritual of washing one’s own car is in decline: 31 percent of men and 75 percent of women say they’ve never cleaned their own vehicle, just 12 percent of those who do wash regularly, and only 5 percent enlist their children for pocket-money work. Contributing factors include Sunday shopping hours, live televised football, the proliferation of hand-car-wash services and larger modern vehicles, though holidays still prompt about 15 million owners to wash—and one in four admit it’s simply an excuse to get outdoors. Weekly owner washes are most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield and least in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh; Audis, Toyotas and BMWs top the owner-wash list, while Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes rank lowest. OSV’s Andrew Kirkley notes that time pressures, bigger cars and affordable commercial options have supplanted the old Sunday tradition.

Martin Skrtel has lauded Steven Gerrard’s influence since his 2008 arrival at Anfield, crediting the captain with helping him settle at Liverpool and calling him “still one of the best players in the world” and synonymous with the club. Gerrard, preparing to play in Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and, if victorious, a final versus Arsenal on his May 30 birthday before moving to LA Galaxy, has set an example Skrtel says will be hard to replace. Nevertheless, Skrtel believes Liverpool possess capable candidates for Gerrard’s iconic No. 8 role and, with proper support and teamwork, can overcome the challenge of his departure. both Skrtel and Gerrard are available for the Villa match after serving three-game bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus aced the 130-yard fourth hole during the Augusta National par-3 contest, marking his first hole-in-one at the Masters as he played with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; despite his shot spinning back into the cup and delighting the crowd, Camilo Villegas matched him with five aces that equaled the tournament record, and Kevin Streelman ultimately won the contest in a playoff. Nicklaus, the youngest green jacket recipient in 1963 and six-time champion, remains one of five to complete golf’s career grand slam—a feat Rory McIlroy could match with a third straight major.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as spotters reported a twister six miles northwest of Goddard—about 17 miles west of Wichita—that tracked northeast without hitting the city but threatened nearby communities, while additional tornado reports emerged near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. The National Weather Service also noted a possible touchdown in Potosi, Missouri, where CNN affiliate KMOV documented wind damage, flooding and downed trees, and residents in nearby Leadington and Farmington shared images of ominous clouds and baseball-size hail. More storms are forecast Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and southern Great Lakes.

Reserve Tulsa County deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris on April 2—what Bates says was a mistaken gunshot intended as a Taser deployment during a weapons sting. At Tuesday’s hearing, a judge allowed Bates to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting Harris’s family to decry the decision as callous. Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2; his lawyer, Clark Brewster, said they look forward to presenting facts in court. Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized to the family, while Harris’s attorneys allege Bates was unqualified and received special treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff—claims the sheriff’s office denies. Over the weekend Bates’s defense released his training records to demonstrate proper qualification, and two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest have been reassigned after receiving threats.

Conor McGregor, 26, has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach ahead of his July 11 featherweight title fight against champion José Aldo in Las Vegas, adding to the gorilla-on-chest ink he already sports; posting “if you see the tiger, it’s too late. you’re food,” McGregor claims superior motivation over Aldo—whose eighth title defense he challenges—highlighting their tense rivalry, which included McGregor snatching Aldo’s belt during a Dublin promotional event.

Australian prime minister Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after enthusiastically skolling a schooner of beer in about six seconds at a University of Technology Sydney Australian rules event—cheered on by players chanting “skol” and “Tony”—because, critics argue, it glamorises binge drinking and links masculinity to rapid alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert called his “performance and display” problematic, warning that it promotes a drinking culture focused on speed and quantity rather than socialising and ignores growing concerns about heavy drinking. Opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked Abbott’s past reluctance to drink straight beer, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, and observers noted that although televised beer-skolling by prime ministers isn’t new—Bob Hawke famously did it—it clashes with current attitudes toward binge drinking.

Indiana’s state health officials report that more than two weeks into Governor Mike Pence’s 30-day emergency needle-exchange program in Scott County—approved March 26 to combat an outbreak fueled by intravenous use of the prescription painkiller Opana—confirmed HIV cases have risen from 106 to 120, with 10 preliminary positives. The county, which normally records about five HIV cases annually, has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants (with 1,400 returned) and deployed a mobile unit to build trust among users. Pence is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond April 25, even as he and Senate President Pro Tem David Long express concern that needle exchanges might encourage drug use. Meanwhile, legislation sponsored by Rep. Ed Clere that would allow 23 high–hepatitis C–rate counties to start their own exchanges has passed the House and awaits a conference-committee hearing, but faces political and funding hurdles—especially given the federal ban on public funding for such programs since 1989.

An obsessive Arsenal supporter made his girlfriend, Saskia, sit a 50-point, school-style exam on everything from Arsenal’s “FC” meaning, nickname and current manager to the starting XI, FA Cup final details and why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard; she scored 43.5/50 (87%), earning an A and sparing herself from a break-up. She shared photos on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla), admitting confusion over positions and creative answers—such as Sánchez being “buff” and “Chilean”—while the boyfriend annotated mistakes with red pen and angry faces. Online reactions ranged from praise for Saskia as “proper girlfriend material” and admiration for the boyfriend’s legend status to criticism that he’d gone too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellín cartel, spent 27 years as an unpaid DEA informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s; in exchange for intelligence that helped bring down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, he was promised U.S. citizenship but never received it. Now retired for health reasons and with his temporary visa expired, Toro is technically undocumented, unable to secure a green card, passport or social security benefits, and faces deportation—something he says would mean certain death back in Colombia. Despite public appeals and a $5,000 donation from his former DEA handler Mike McManus, the DEA has refused to assist with his citizenship, leaving Toro in legal limbo and fearing for his life.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Mathura district, Uttar Pradesh, allegedly gang-raped by five men while relieving herself outside her home, set herself ablaze with kerosene on Tuesday—reportedly at her family’s urging to keep silent about the attack—and is now fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70 percent burns; the accused have been arrested. This incident comes amid heightened sensitivity in India over sexual violence following the recent ban on the documentary India’s Daughter—which examines the 2012 gang rape and murder of 23-year-old Jyoti Singh Pandey—and a wave of public protests and vigilante killings, including mob-lynchings in Nagaland of men accused of rape, that have intensified calls for better protection of women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he’s “dreaming” of beating local rivals Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford, though he must do so without injured forward Robin van Persie—who despite claiming fitness, is deemed unfit to play—as well as Luke Shaw. Van Gaal wants all three points to move United into second or third place and secure direct Champions League qualification, ahead of a potentially tougher summer qualifier. He insists the team has learned from their 1-0 away defeat to City earlier this season, stressing the need to control aggression, and acknowledges City will still pose a stern challenge. Ahead of his first home Manchester derby, he praised his squad’s training performances in the sunshine and lauded the fans’ unwavering support.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a joint protest at the Emirates Stadium by leaving seats empty for the first ten minutes of their lunchtime Premier League match to decry soaring ticket prices in the wake of the league’s new £5.14 billion TV rights deal. With tickets for the sold-out 12.45 pm kickoff starting at £64—among the highest in the league—fans displayed banners inside and outside reading “£5 bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “football without fans is nothing.” Organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 groups, the protest highlighted the burden on working-class supporters, criticized fixture changes and kickoff times, and warned that unaffordable prices risk alienating a generation of fans unless authorities act; further demonstrations at the Emirates are anticipated.

A newborn in Barnsley was diagnosed with biliary atresia days after birth when persistent jaundice revealed blocked bile ducts; after an initial surgery failed, doctors said she needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable donor, so her mother’s twin sister, Shanell, volunteered and donated part of her liver. The transplant in November saved the baby’s life, and after six weeks in hospital she went home, requires lifelong anti-rejection medication and regular liver function tests, and is now on track to lead a normal life thanks to her aunt’s selfless act.

Chelsea pair Eden Hazard and Nathan Aké faced teammates Loïc Rémy and Willian in Audi’s football challenge, consisting of three head-to-head rounds: firing footballs into a car boot from close range (Hazard and Aké won 5–3), lobbing balls over an R8 V10 Plus acting as a tennis net (Hazard and Aké won the decider to lead 6–0), and shooting from long range through the top of a convertible Audi (Rémy and Willian prevailed). During the final round, Willian accidentally smashed an Audi’s wing mirror with a shot, much to Rémy’s dismay.

Former PPG Industries executive Robert Dellinger, 54, who previously held high-level posts at Sprint, Delphi and GE, pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide for causing a December 7, 2013 highway crash in Lebanon, New Hampshire that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy—who was eight months pregnant—and her fiancé, 29-year-old Jason Timmons, and faces 12 to 24 years in prison; prosecutors say Dellinger told investigators he had tried to kill himself by steering his pickup across the median at over 100 mph, though he told the court at sentencing that he had never been suicidal, and his attorneys have attributed the crash to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric-drug effects and advanced multiple sclerosis, while his wife testified to his ethics and modesty and both families continue to pursue a wrongful-death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life after being convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt via his feeding tube while he was hospitalized, a crime prosecutors said she committed to draw attention to herself by exaggerating his medical problems; during her sentencing at a New York courthouse she showed no emotion, prompting the boy’s father, Chris Hill, to post on Facebook that she belonged in general population and should be beaten to death, while the judge acknowledged her mental illness but called the act “unfathomable in its cruelty.” Spear’s defense attorney has blamed hospital negligence, plans to appeal, and noted she was a hardworking single mother, and evidence at trial included her social media posts, photos of her son’s hospitalizations and final hours on life support.

Stocks of an improved influenza vaccine—delayed by a month—are arriving in Australia with added protection against influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket after those strains caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US due to a poor match in the northern-hemisphere vaccine. From April 20, high-risk groups (the very young and old, and most Indigenous Australians) can receive free government-funded shots. The updated vaccine also covers influenza A H1N1 and is expected to match circulating global strains, with the same formulation to be used next northern winter. Dr Alan Hampson urges everyone to book their flu shots now to protect both themselves and vulnerable contacts.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield are defending the site against National Geographic’s critique that its interior feels “like an office lobby,” as looming state budget cuts threaten the historic preservation agency that manages it. Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner has proposed folding the agency into another department, and last year’s $1.1 million funding cut has reduced staff and hours at the tomb. Agency spokesman Chris Wills and Lincoln Monument Association president Pam Vanalstine argue the tomb—designed by Larkin Mead, dedicated in 1874 by President Grant, and rebuilt in 1899 and 1930—has undergone more than $2.5 million in recent repairs, including a $730,000 interior lighting upgrade, and is in excellent physical condition. A $390,000 project is currently waterproofing the receiving vault, repairing stonework, and improving drainage, while visitors such as William Sparks dispute the negative review and praise the site’s appearance.

Nineties and early noughties styles—from oversized JNCO rave jeans with 50-inch leg openings to bucket hats, camouflage prints, all-over designer logos and double denim—are staging a comeback among today’s young celebrities, sparking criticism from those who remember the era firsthand. Other retro revivals include shapeless Ugg boots, ultra-short “Daisy Duke” denim cut-offs, velour Juicy Couture tracksuits in garish hues, rainbow-tinted sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear and harem trousers with wide baggy legs. While these pieces were once championed by pop stars like Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, Destiny’s Child and Paris Hilton, modern adopters such as Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, Nicki Minaj and Selena Gomez prove the trends endure, even if fashion insiders wish some of them would stay buried in the past.

A roundup of this week’s top trends includes a quadruple rainbow captured over New York after heavy rain, China’s new ban on hiring exotic dancers at rural wakes, and Robert Downey Jr. growing agitated during a UK interview about his private life. Pop culture highlights feature the jar-sucking “#kyliejennerchallenge” for lip-plumping, 102-year-old Alice Barker’s filmmaker-aided “time travel,” and a bomb-themed prom proposal that a school rejected amid accusations of racism. In entertainment casting news, Ewan McGregor will play Lumière in Beauty and the Beast, and Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer. Finally, creative personal announcements included a Fresh Prince–inspired pregnancy reveal and a military dad photobombing his son.

At the Miami Open, giant cakes have become the celebratory hallmark after Andy Murray marked his 500th career win and Serena Williams her 700th. Williams clinched her milestone with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 victory over Germany’s Sabine Lisicki in the quarter-finals, avenging her 2013 Wimbledon loss, and advanced to face third-seeded Simona Halep—who herself reached the semis by beating Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5—for a place in the final. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

Sabeen Mahmud was a Karachi‐based human rights and free‐speech activist who ran The Second Floor (t2f), a colorful café and community space for discussions on technology, women’s entrepreneurship, art and politics. Undeterred by past death threats, she had just hosted a banned university‐sponsored panel on enforced disappearances in Balochistan when two gunmen fatally shot her at point‐blank range and wounded her mother as they locked up for the night. Mahmud, celebrated nationwide as a symbol of secularism, tolerance and open debate, died of five bullet wounds; no group has claimed responsibility or provided a motive. Her café—crammed with graffiti, books and young people hungry for free thought—became a focal point for progressive discourse in Pakistan, and her killing prompted an outpouring of grief and calls for continued dialogue in her memory.

Healer Mangu Ram, now 82, fled what became Pakistan in 1947 and has spent nearly 70 years in Jammu and Kashmir as one of some 100,000 “West Pakistan refugees” (WPRs) denied state citizenship—unable to own land, vote in state elections or work in the state government—because of a pre-independence law meant to protect Kashmir’s Muslim-majority status; as a result, three generations live in slum conditions and poverty despite most never having set foot in Pakistan. Under that law, only those born in the former princely state—or their descendants—qualify as “state subjects,” while a separate provision granted citizenship to about 35,000 Hindus who fled from Pakistan-administered Kashmir. With Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party entering the state government for the first time, many WPRs—including Ram and activist Labha Ram Gandhi—hope the BJP will fulfill its pledge to normalize their status, though Gandhi warns his community is prepared to resort to protests if promises fail to materialize.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto has confirmed he is weighing a summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who reportedly bid around £4 million and plan to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem; the 22-year-old says he must join a team “where I can play and develop.” Muto’s former coach Ranko Popović praised his intelligence, speed, strength and confidence, while Chelsea boss José Mourinho, mindful of financial fair play and commercial ties with Yokohama Rubber, acknowledges Muto’s potential but insists the club only signs proven players or top prospects.

The passage applauds Australia’s decision to allow overseas‐based players into their national rugby side and criticizes England’s outdated policy barring such selections, arguing that coaches like Stuart Lancaster should be free to choose their best players regardless of where they play. It cites Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell’s resurgence with Toulon, Steffon Armitage’s impact in the Champions Cup, and Nick Abendanon’s and Jonny Wilkinson’s improvements after moving to France as evidence that top performance often comes from abroad. The author insists that for a home World Cup England must field its strongest XV without being hamstrung by RFU or club restrictions, noting that other nations such as South Africa and Wales already pick overseas stars like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny.

Open Garden’s FireChat app, launched last year and downloaded over five million times, uses Apple’s iOS 7 Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and a similar Android feature) to create wireless mesh networks that let users send messages and photos within about 30 feet of each other without mobile or data signals; messages hop between phones as nodes and are encrypted and anonymous, with “nearby” and “everyone” chatrooms extending reach up to about 200 feet by relaying through intervening devices. To bridge gaps in connectivity further, Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped beacon that stores up to 1,000 recent messages, holds a one-year charge and currently works within about 20 feet to boost FireChat traffic—ideal for planes, subways, festivals or any setting where networks might fail—while broader commercial availability depends on manufacturing partnerships.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses her 5'3", 240-lb frame to reclaim “fat” as an honest, body-positive self-description and argues in her TED Talk that it needn’t be synonymous with “ugly”; she joins “short” and “wife” alongside “fat” as neutral descriptors of her identity, highlights a 66% rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and the fact that girls aged 11–17 most wish to be thinner, and cites research showing that exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance and preference for different shapes. Bustle began performing in 2012 after seeing her first burlesque show, found it empowering despite early nerves about her arms jiggle, and now encourages others to use a personal “courage reference” to boost self-esteem. Though her 2014 talk was only posted recently and attracted some negative comments, it has earned nearly 38,000 views and overwhelmingly positive feedback, including heartfelt messages from viewers who say it changed how they see their own bodies.

Theo Walcott, 26, has spent much of the season on Arsenal’s bench—named among the substitutes in 17 of 33 Premier League games and most recently featuring for the final six minutes of a 0-0 draw with Chelsea—yet he joined teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Özil (alongside runway model Olga Sherer) for a photoshoot with Paris fashion house Lanvin, Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013. The squad will wear the same outfits at Wembley for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30, and Walcott, whose last start came in a 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14, hopes to return to the starting XI when Arsenal visit Hull at the KC Stadium.

An extraordinary no-reserve auction of 417 original props and puppets from Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio—spanning more than 50 productions over his 30-plus-year career—will take place May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via propstore.com, with the entire collection estimated at $746,100. Highlights include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black ($40,000), the Mikey costume from the same film ($30,000), the Grinch suit from How the Grinch Stole Christmas ($8,000), a Two-Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), the Harry creature suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000), Gremlins 2 puppets ($6,000–$8,000 each), a worm guy from Men in Black II ($10,000), a Frosty thug statue from Batman & Robin ($4,000) and other pieces from An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker and more, all offered to the public for the first time.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, a confident, outgoing Welsh schoolboy and competent skier since age three who idolized Bear Grylls, became separated from his mother on the final run of his family’s ski holiday in Flaine, France. After his sister fell on a jump, Carwyn pressed on alone, entered dense woodland and tumbled 164 ft down a ravine. Investigators followed his footprints—interrupted by sliding marks—to discover his body. His family described him as loving and laughter-filled, and they remain devastated by the “vast void” his loss has left. Friends, schoolmates and the local community have rallied around the Scott-Howells in grief.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressured by “size zero” ideals; by age 13 she was surviving on about 100 calories a day—often just a piece of fruit—hiding food under mashed potato and down her bed, and lying to her mother. Over two years her obsession deepened until she collapsed at home, was placed on a heart monitor for a week at North Tyneside General Hospital, and finally received help from eating-disorder services. Having recovered with the support of ED teams and CAMHS, her body image and confidence have improved to the point that she’s now a semi-finalist in Miss Teen GB, a contest promoting positive, non–size-zero role models.

Liverpool officially unveiled their 2015/16 home kit—a red gingham-style strip with all-white New Balance branding and a Hillsborough memorial flame and “96” tribute—at Anfield’s Centenary Stand, marking New Balance’s £300 million, four-year deal replacing Warrior. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel, Simon Mignolet, Adam Lallana, Jordan Henderson and Philippe Coutinho joined club legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush to model the new design and relay the rallying cry “hold nothing back.” Despite Sterling’s recent rejection of a £100 000-a-week extension and flirtation with Arsenal talk, supporters loudly urged him to remain, a sentiment the club shares as he has two years remaining on his contract. With the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley imminent, Sterling and Sturridge both praised the fans’ “12th man” role and expressed hopes that cup success could springboard further achievements under Brendan Rodgers.

A University of Manchester team led by Dr Sarah Bridle has produced the first high-definition map of dark matter over 0.4 percent of the sky by measuring the distortions of 130 million galaxy images captured with the 570-megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4 m Blanco telescope at CTIO. Using gravitational lensing to infer the unseen matter, the map reveals clumps, filaments and voids that confirm galaxies form in regions of greater dark-matter density. As part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey, which will cover 12.5 percent of the sky in 3D by 2018, this work will probe how dark-matter clumpiness evolves and shed light on dark energy driving the universe’s accelerating expansion.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old Dutch winger Memphis Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years; United manager Louis van Gaal, familiar with Depay from Holland’s third-place 2014 World Cup run, aims to make him one of his first summer signings amid interest from Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club. Depay broke into PSV’s first team in 2011 after progressing through their youth ranks, has made over 100 appearances, and is known for his pace, silky dribbling (most dribbles in 2013/14 Eredivisie), powerful right-foot shot and goal-scoring from distance, though he can sometimes hold onto the ball too long or misplace passes. Tipped by PSV’s Phillip Cocu to reach the top and compared by scout Ed van Steijn to a young Cristiano Ronaldo, Depay has also scored at the World Cup and been nominated for best young player in Brazil.

Chelsea’s youngsters clinched the Youth Cup final at the Academy Stadium with a 3-1 win over Manchester City’s side, taking a 3-1 aggregate lead back to West London. Tammy Abraham powered Chelsea ahead with two first-half volleys before Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly levelled for City shortly after the break. Dominic Solanke sealed the victory late on. Chelsea’s defence, marshalled by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, contained City’s attack, while Charlie Colkett and Charly Musonda helped control midfield. City’s Pablo Maffeo, Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant put in solid displays, but missed chances from Aaron Nemane, Brandon Barker and Kean Bryan saw them fall short. 2389fdsi2389432ksad

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and recent presidential candidate, told CBS’s Face the Nation that he believes people are born with a sexual preference yet that the definition of marriage—he says should be between one man and one woman—ought to be decided by state legislatures rather than courts. He clarified in a Fusion magazine interview that he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about, despite disagreeing with the decision, just as he would continue to love someone who divorces. Rubio, a Catholic, announced his White House bid last week and has already secured donor pledges toward the roughly $51 million he’ll need to compete in a crowded Republican primary.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, ditched their Manchester restaurant jobs in 2014 to fulfill a dream of pedaling across the globe with no fixed agenda or schedule, and in 356 days they’ve already logged nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries—from London down France’s west and south coasts via Spain and Portugal, then across Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia and Greece into Turkey, Georgia and now Armenia—while living on under €3 per person per day (about €0.10 per kilometer) by camping free (161 nights), using Couchsurfing (66) and Warmshowers (44), accepting stranger hospitality, dumpster-diving or foraging for food, and planning to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and down the Americas in an open-ended odyssey.

A Texas couple married in 2012 at the Bell Tower in northwest Houston discovered months later that their rented photo booth from Premiere Photos had printed the phrase “poor n***** party” on their wedding snapshots. They’ve sued owner James Evans—who denies the allegations, refused to apologize and told them to “sue” him—under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Attorney Cathy Hale says the bride’s sister withheld the information to protect her from distress on her wedding day, and that the couple, horrified by the slur, initially didn’t want to sue but pressed charges after Evans did nothing. Mediation is scheduled for tomorrow, with trial set for July if no agreement is reached, and the couple’s primary demand is a genuine apology.

Mike Brown, England and Harlequins full-back, has taken a cautious approach to his latest concussion after withdrawing from Harlequins’ Aviva Premiership match against Saracens following headaches post-France game, and remains unsure when he’ll return; he emphasises he won’t rush back to avoid long-term risks seen in players like Johnny Sexton and George North (who has been advised not to play again this season after his fourth rapid concussion and will consult a neurosurgeon), and credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules for helping him recognise symptoms and insist on sitting out England’s Ireland match despite its importance.

Since the rise of the internet and constant smartphone connectivity, Britons have been having progressively less sex—an average heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month compared with four times in 2000 and five times in 1990, according to Cambridge statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book Sex by Numbers. He attributes the decline not only to more people living alone but chiefly to the blurring of boundaries between work, home and leisure: checking emails and messages at all hours leaves couples with less undistracted time together, pushing sex down the list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs—once prized status symbols in China that sold for as much as £1.2 million—have fallen out of favor and are now often sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather after a government anti-corruption campaign discouraged their exchange as gifts, and urban bans on dogs over 50 kg further dampened demand. Originally bred in Tibet as loyal herders weighing up to 80 kg, the breed’s popularity boomed from 2005, spurring profit-driven cross-breeding that degraded its quality and created an oversupply of unsellable animals. Animal-welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs en route to an abattoir—some dead and others malnourished or injured—and charities warn that ruthless gangs and unscrupulous breeders nationwide are stealing or dumping unwanted dogs into the cruel trade.

A poll of 600 women in and around Paris conducted for the high council for gender equality found that every respondent had experienced sexual harassment or assault on the city’s buses and trains—ranging from catcalls, insults and unwanted touching to rape—with half reporting their first incident before age 18. As a result, six in ten women say they fear using public transport (versus three in ten men) and routinely change routes, schedules and clothing to avoid confrontation, effectively excluding them from public space. The council’s report, delivered to the French women’s rights ministry, prompted calls for a campaign to curb sexist and threatening behavior, and officials stressed that assaults such as groping carry up to five years in prison and a €75,005 fine, while urging better education for women, witnesses and perpetrators about what constitutes unacceptable conduct.

Leeds-based insurer Direct Line has launched the #everydayfix competition in partnership with design school Makerversity to turn prototype solutions for common daily hassles—identified in a survey of 2,000 people—into real products via a Kickstarter campaign. From ten top “everyday emergencies” (led by sleeplessness at 46%), three finalists were picked: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure uninterrupted sleep; the Forget Me Lock, which clips onto your key and swivels green or red to show whether your front door is unlocked or locked; and Nipper, a pocket-sized mobile charger that taps any household battery for power. Voters can retweet #everydayfix tweets about their favorite of the three prototypes by April 26, and the most popular will go into full development.

Vera Baird, Northumbria’s police and crime commissioner, is under a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a victims-support charity she co-directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim. The funding was enabled by a recent rule letting PCCs commission victims’ services, and Baird says all MoJ protocols were followed. Critics, including Labour MP Keith Vaz, have denounced the arrangement as an inappropriate conflict of interest and “soap opera” within the force. Sim, who faces past bullying allegations and will retire in June, and Baird established the charity after referrals to its predecessor, Victim Support, fell sharply. A MoJ spokesman confirmed its power to investigate conflicts and withdraw funding if rules were breached.

Three members of a Philadelphia gang dubbed the “tattoo terrorists” have been sentenced for brutally torturing 53-year-old Greg Valeccé in March 2014 after their leader, 21-year-old Corry “Corey” Campbell, accused him of injuring his cat, Pebbles, and stealing money and drugs. Over roughly 42 hours in the basement of Campbell’s mother’s Mayfair rowhouse, Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng (19), and friend Carl Halin (18) repeatedly beat, spat on and insulted Valeccé, tied him to a chair, and forcibly tattooed “rip pebbles,” a vomit-eyed smiley face and other hateful symbols, including swastikas, Stars of David, racial slurs and a homoerotic design. Valeccé escaped on April 1, suffering multiple fractures, PTSD and nightmares; police later seized the tattoo gun, needles, ink, 155 grams of marijuana, prescription drugs and Valeccé’s stolen debit card. Campbell and Halin each received 20-year prison terms, Ng got 23 months, while David Thomas (28) and Jennifer Pratt (40) await their sentences or trial.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Holland winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings after having worked with him during Holland’s third-place World Cup finish in 2014; PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirms United, Paris Saint-Germain and another big European club are willing to pay significantly more than the £15 million Tottenham offered last year. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie matches as PSV clinched their first league title in seven seasons, bringing his professional tally to over 100 appearances since his debut in September 2011; pacy, strong on the ball and noted for dribbling and long-range shooting, he still occasionally holds onto the ball too long or makes the wrong pass. Born in 1994 to a Ghanaian father and Dutch mother, he rose through Sparta Rotterdam’s and PSV’s youth systems, has been compared to Arjen Robben and, according to scout Ed van Steijn, showed more versatility at his age than Cristiano Ronaldo did, and after making his Oranje debut in 2013 starred in Brazil 2014—scoring against Australia and Chile and earning a Best Young Player nomination.

Chelsea’s youth side claimed a 3-1 win at Manchester City’s Academy Stadium in the Youth Cup final thanks to a Tammy Abraham brace in the first half and a late Dominic Solanke strike, despite Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly levelling for City. In goal, Kjetil Haug looked uneasy under pressure; Pablo Maffeo and Tosin Adarabioyo marshalled the defence alongside Cameron Humphreys-Grant and José Angeliño, while Kean Bryan’s injury and missed chances from Aaron Nemane and Bersant Celina limited City’s attacking threat. Brandon Barker and Manu García showed promise but were largely contained by a strong Chelsea backline of Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke-Salter, Ola Aina and Jay DaSilva, with Bradley Collins distributing well. In midfield Charlie Colkett impressed for Chelsea, Charly Musonda was quiet, Isaiah Brown posed a constant threat but missed his big opening, and substitute Kasey Palmer injected pace late on.
