Marco Rubio, who recently announced his 2016 presidential bid, told CBS’s Face the Nation that while he doesn’t oppose same‐sex marriage on a personal level—he’d even attend a gay wedding of a family member or staffer—he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman and that states, not the courts, ought to regulate it. He asserted that sexual preference is inborn for the vast majority of people and said that although, as a Catholic, he considers divorce wrong, he wouldn’t stop loving someone who’s divorced. Rubio’s campaign has already received donor commitments exceeding the $47 million he’ll likely need to compete in a Republican primary crowded with well‐funded contenders.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, quit their Manchester restaurant jobs to cycle the world with no fixed agenda, covering nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries in 356 days while living on under €3 per person per day. They rely on free camping (161 nights), Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), carry all their gear on two bicycles, and spend €2.74 daily on food—pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, occasional wild foraging, dumpster diving and invitations from locals. Beginning in London, they pedaled through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece and Turkey’s northern coast, then into Georgia and Armenia, and now plan to continue across Asia, the Pacific and the Americas.

Mike Brown has withdrawn from Harlequins’ recent Aviva Premiership fixture and admits he is unsure when he will return after suffering concussion symptoms—including headaches following England’s France match—so he is taking a cautious, staged approach to recovery rather than risking prolonged absence like others such as George North (ruled out for the season after four concussions) or Johnny Sexton (12-week layoff). Brown credits World Rugby’s online education modules for helping him recognise warning signs and prioritise long-term health, and says he will gradually progress through activities (starting with a 20-minute bike test) before resuming full training. As an ambassador for Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” campaign, he urges teammates to be honest about symptoms and resist playing on when concussed.

Since the rise of the internet and smartphones, the average frequency of heterosexual couples’ sex has declined—from about five times a month in 1990 to four in 2000 and now three, according to Cambridge statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter. He attributes much of this drop to our constantly connected lives eroding the boundary between work, home and personal time, leaving less opportunity for intimacy. While living alone has also increased, Spiegelhalter and researcher Catherine Mercer note that late-night work emails and competing demands on our time mean that by bedtime people often remain too “plugged in” to focus solely on their partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols in China—fetching up to £1.2 million in 2014—have fallen so out of favor that many are now sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat or their skins. Their precipitous decline is attributed to the government’s anti-corruption campaign, which ended lavish gifting of these dogs to officials, and recent bans on pets over 50 kg in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai. An oversupply of cross-bred, low-quality mastiffs exacerbates the collapse: breeders unable to sell imperfect dogs offload them to abattoirs, while gangs steal healthy animals off the streets. Animal-welfare rescuers recently intercepted 20 mastiffs in cramped, food-and-water-deprived cages, one-third already dead, highlighting a wider crisis that may affect hundreds of animals. Originating as loyal herders in Tibet, these 80-kg dogs have also been deemed unsuitable for urban life amid China’s rapid urbanization.

Leeds-based insurer Direct Line and London’s Makerversity ran the #everydayfix “design makeathon” after surveying 2,000 people to rank their top ten daily emergencies—led by sleeplessness (46%), lost keys (37%), traffic delays (35%), misplaced documents (33%), parking woes (32%), printer failures (31%), dead phone batteries (31%), missing loo roll (30%), machine-operated customer service (26%) and forgotten bank cards (25%)—and invited teams to prototype fixes. Three finalists went to a public Twitter vote using the #everydayfix hashtag: Instruments’ “Snooze” alarm clock that links to your phone to mute notifications overnight; ONN Studio’s “Forget Me Lock,” a color-swivel key attachment showing green for unlocked and red for locked; and Impulse’s “Nipper,” billed as the world’s smallest phone charger powered by any household battery. The winning concept by April 40 will be funded via Kickstarter, while non-shortlisted ideas included a bone-conduction “Hat Nav” cycling helmet, a parking-space alert “Parking Pin” and a “Relay” app to redirect messages when your phone dies.
